questions.text: All of the following myotomes contribute to the diaphragm muscles except?
questions.solution:
Option A: C2

  • This is a case of diaphragm paralysis, which is caused due to the injury of the phrenic nerve.

Phrenic nerve:

  • Phrenic nerve root value is C3, C4, and C5. So, according to this case, C2 doesn't contribute to the diaphragm.
  • The phrenic nerve is a bilateral, mixed nerve that originates from the cervical nerves in the neck and descends through the thorax to innervate the diaphragm.
  • It is the only source of motor innervation to the diaphragm and therefore plays a crucial role in breathing.
  • Following is the anatomy of the phrenic nerve – its anatomical course and motor and sensory functions.
  • Nerve roots – Anterior rami of C3, C4, and C5.
  • Motor functions – Innervates the diaphragm.
  • Sensory functions – Innervate the diaphragm's central part, the pericardium, and the mediastinal part of the parietal pleura.

Option B: C3

  • Out of 8 cervical somites, C3, C4, and C5 contribute to the skeletal muscles of the diaphragm.

Option C: C4

  • Out of 8 cervical somites, C3, C4, and C5 contribute to the skeletal muscles of the diaphragm.

Option D: C5

  • Out of 8 cervical somites, C3, C4, and C5 contribute to the skeletal muscles of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which structure on the anterior abdominal wall is likely to be defective in degenerative malformation of the transversalis fascia during development ?

choices.text: Sac of a direct inguinal hernia

questions.solution:
Option B: Deep inguinal ring

 

 

The picture above shows that:

  • The deep inguinal ring lies in the transversalis fascia, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • The defective structure in the anterior abdominal wall leads to degenerative malformation of fascia transversalis.
  • The deep (internal) inguinal ring is a defect in the transversus abdominis fascia that allows the contents to enter the canal and leave the abdomen before extending obliquely, medially, and inferiorly through the canal to exit at the superficial (external) inguinal ring.
  • The deep or internal ring is located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament and lateral to the epigastric vessels.
  • The deep ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, which provides the posterior covering of the contents of the inguinal ring.

 

Option A: Superficial inguinal ring

  • The superficial inguinal ring is in the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle.

Option C: Inguinal ligament

  • The inguinal ligament and the anterior wall of the inguinal canal are formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. So, it doesn't have any role in the degeneration malformation of the transversalis fascia.

Option D: Sac of a direct inguinal hernia

  • The peritoneum forms the sac of a direct inguinal hernia.
  • It is not formed by fascia transversalis.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical facts is true about the stomach?

choices.text: Lymph from the superior two third of the stomach drains into the supra-pancreatic nodes.
All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.
The gastric branches of the vagus are given at the greater curve.
The lower esophageal sphincter is supplied by the nerves of Latarjet.

questions.solution:
Option B: All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.

  • The lymphatic system of the abdomen represents a network of vessels that collect and transport lymph. The lymphatic helps in the removal of cellular waste, water, and proteins from the interstitial fluid.
  • All the lymph from the stomach eventually drains into the celiac nodes and then into the cisterna chyli.
  • The lymph from the stomach drains into the right and left gastric nodes on the right side, pancreaticosplenic nodes and supra-pancreatic nodes on the left side, and the inferior portion drains into the pyloric nodes.
  • The stomach receives innervation from the autonomic nervous system (ANS). The parasympathetic innervation arises from the anterior and posterior vagal trunks, which arise from the left and right vagus nerves (CN X).
  • The anterior vagal trunk mainly supplies a portion of the anterior surface of the stomach, as well as the pylorus. The larger posterior vagal trunk supplies the remaining anterior surface, as well as the entire posterior surface.
  • The anterior and posterior vagi pass along the lesser curvature of the stomach and give off gastric branches as they descend.
  • The nerve of the latarjet, also known as the posterior nerve, supplies the pylorus of the stomach. It is a branch of the anterior vagal trunk and is transected in selective vagotomy.

Option A: Lymph from the superior two third of the stomach drains into the suprapancreatic nodes

  • Lymph from the superior portion of the left side drains into the inferior pancreaticoduodenal and supra pancreatic lymph nodes.

Option C: The gastric branches of the vagus are given at the greater curve.

  • Gastric branches of the vagus are given at lesser curvature.

Option D: The lower esophageal sphincter is supplied by the nerves of Latarjet

  • Nerves of latarjet supply the pylorus and pyloric sphincter.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with burning in the mid-epigastric region, a sour taste in his mouth after meals, and a red tongue-like mucosa observed during endoscopy with biopsy showing columnar metaplasia. At what distance from the gastroesophageal junction is the Z line seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: 5 cm

  • The above given is a case of barret esophagus.
  • The mid-epigastric burning pain + sour taste is a classic symptom.
  • The biopsy findings of columnar metaplasia and red mucosa on endoscopy confirm the diagnosis.
  • Z-Line:
    • Zig–zag line.
    • Squamous columnar junction at lower 2 cm of the esophagus.
    • The lower 2cm of the esophagus is lined by columnar epithelium.
    • Prone to metaplasia/ dysplasia.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.

Option A: 2 cm

  • In normal individuals, the zig-zag line is located 2cm above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.

Option B: 3 cm

  • Squamous columnar junction at lower 2 cm of the esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.

Option C: 4 cm

  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction, not 4cm.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with shoulder pain, neck stiffness, headache, raised blood pressure, and constipation. An X-ray revealed extra bone growth on the cervical vertebrae, and an MRI showed a pinched nerve. Regarding the structure involved, which statement is not true in the context of the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cervical - kyphosis

  • This is a case of cervical spondylosis.
  • The correct pair is Cervical - lordosis.
  • Cervical kyphosis is pathological.
  •  At 2 months Cervical lordosis is due to - neck holding.
  • Concave posteriorly.
  • The concavities align the center of gravity of the body through the pelvis, thereby contracting the weight of the thoracoabdominal viscera, allowing the head to balance on top of the vertebral column and enabling upright posture.
  • However, in initial development, the fetal vertebral column has only one continuous anterior concavity.
  • As the development proceeds, the lumbosacral angle appears at the junction of the L5 and S1 vertebrae, forming 2 anterior concave curves.
  • After birth, the cervical curve forms in association with the child raising his or her head and keeping it poised on the vertebral column.

Option A: Lumbar-lordosis

  •  It is a correct pair.

Option C: Thoracic-kyphosis

  •  It is a correct pair.

Option D: Pelvic - Antero-inferiorly concave

  • It is a correct pair.

questions.text: In which phase of meiosis do Leptotene and Pachytene occur?
questions.solution:
Correct option :

Option C: Prophase I phases are

  • Prophase I phases are
    • Leptotene
    • Zygotene
    • Pachytene
    • Diplotene

Incorrect options :

Option A: Anaphase II

  • Sister chromatids of every chromosome separate and start to move towards the opposite pole of the cell.
  • The separation and the movement are because of the shortening of the kinetochore microtubules.

Option B: Telophase II

  • Nuclear membranes form around each set of chromosomes and decondensation of the chromosomes occurs.
  • Cytokinesis splits the sets of chromosomes into new cells, four haploid cells.
  • It is the Final step of meiosis

Option D: Metaphase I

  • Alignment of paired chromosomes in the center

questions.text: Which among the following is a remnant of notochord?
questions.solution:
Option A: Nucleus pulposus

  • It arises from the axial mesoderm and is completely formed by the beginning of the fourth week.
  • The main function of the notochord derived from the mesoderm is the development of the vertebrate and as a midline tissue providing directional signals to surrounding tissue during development.
  • It is a defining structure which has an important role in the development of the vertebrate. The primary function of the notochord is to support the body of the organism. It becomes an integral part of the backbone as it grows.
  • Nucleus pulposus is a vestigial remnant of the notochord found in the intervertebral disc.

Option B: Annulus fibrosus

  • It is a connective tissue made of fibrous collagen.
  • It is derived from the mesenchymal cells.
  • It covers the nucleus propulsus.
  • It is the tough circular exterior of the intervertebral disc.
  • Composition:

           It is composed of

  • A ring of ligament fibres 
  • Layers of collagen and proteins called lamellae
  • Function:
  • Encases the inner core of the disc
  • Securely connects the spinal vertebrae above and below the disc.
  • Anchors of the intervertebral disc to the vertebra merge anteriorly and posteriorly with the longitudinal ligaments.
  • Annular Tear:
    • There are many causes of annular tears, and the most common cause is the natural ageing process.
    • Our discs become less hydrated and brittle as we age, making them prone to tears. Along with ageing, a tear can also be caused by Traumatic events such as a car accident or sports injury.
    • Treatment: Most annular tears improve and heal over time with rest, spine-specialized physical therapy, and over-the-counter anti-inflammatories.
    • In some situations, symptoms may warrant prescription strength anti-inflammatories or possible pain or muscle relaxant medication.

Option C: Intertransverse ligament

  • It attaches to the transverse processes of adjacent vertebrae.
  • It is a ligament that is located in between the transverse process of the spine.
  • It is derived from the ectoderm
  • Function:
  • The intertransverse ligaments often blend with the intertransverse muscles.
  •  It limits lateral flexion of the spine.

Option D: Ligamentum flavum

  • The notochord does not form it.
  • Ligamentum flavum is made of elastin fibres.
  • Flavum (Latin for yellow ligament)
  • These are the ligaments that connect the ventral parts of the laminae of adjacent vertebrae.
  • Function:
  • They help to preserve an upright posture
  • Preventing hyperflexion
  • Ensure that the vertebral column straightens after flexion.
  • Thickening: Ligamentum flavum can lose strength and elasticity, causing it to thicken and buckle towards the spinal column. This is due to the loss of elastic fibres, increasing collagen fibres' thickness.
  • These events cause the deposition of Ca+2 in the ligament.
  • Treatment: Operative treatment includes such procedures as excision of the LF, decompressive laminectomy, and minimally invasive decompression.

questions.text: Which tongue muscle is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve?
questions.solution:
Option A: Palatoglossus

  • Palatoglossus is the only tongue muscle supplied by the vagus nerve. The hypoglossal nerve supplies all other tongue muscles.

Option B: Genioglossus

  • It is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve.

Option C: Hyoglossus

  • It is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve.

Option D: Styloglossus

  • It is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: All of the following structures are attached to the lateral condyle of the femur, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Plantaris

  •  Plantaris does not attach to the lateral condyle. It arises from the lower end of the lateral supracondylar line just above the lateral head of the gastrocnemius.

Option A: Capsule

  • The capsule is attached along a line 1 cm above the articular margins of the medial (as well lateral) condyle. It is important to note that the groove for popliteus is intracapsular.

Option B: Fibular collateral ligament

  • The lateral surface of the lateral condyle presents a prominence called lateral epicondyle, which provides attachment to the fibular collateral ligament of the knee joint.

Option C: Anterior cruciate ligament

  • The anterior cruciate ligament is attached below to the anterior part of the intercondylar area of the tibia. It runs backward, upward, and laterally (BUL) and is attached to the posterior part of the medial surface of the lateral condyle of the femur.
  • It is taut during extension of the knee and prevents the posterior dislocation of the femur on the tibia and anterior dislocation of the tibia on the femur.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents unconscious after a roadside accident. Examination reveals contralateral lower limb weakness. Occlusion of the artery supplying the marked area will lead to all the symptoms mentioned below EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rectal incontinence

 

  • Area marked: Medial aspect primary motor area & Somatosensory area - Paracentral lobule
  • Ischemic injury to the region leads to sensory-motor disturbance in the contralateral lower body (pelvis, perineum and lower limb), alongwith bladder/bowel disturbances.
  • This is a controversial question, but rectal incontinence has been chosen as the answer of exception, since it is not mentioned in standard textbooks in the symptomology, whereas urinary incontinence is well explained.
  •  
  • Medial aspects of the sensory-motor homunculus:
    • Contralateral lower limb & part of pelvis & perineum
    • Cortical micturition center (CMC): Located in the medial aspect of the frontoparietal cortex.
    • Apraxia: Inability to perform motor tasks on command d/o a lesion in the cerebral hemisphere (Parietal lobe).
  • So, occlusion in the marked area will develop Urinary incontinence, Apraxia, and Perianal anesthesia.
  • Arteries supplying the parietal lobe are
    • Basilar Artery: Pons, upper medulla, and midbrain
    • PICA: Posterior cerebellum and lateral medulla
    • Posterior cerebral artery: Posterior cerebrum, occipital visual cortex/striate cortex, calcarine sulcus, midbrain, and thalamus
    • Posterior communicating artery: Thalamus
    • Anterior Cerebral Artery: Medial cerebrum [major contribution], paracentral lobule, and lateral cerebral (pelvis, perineum)
    • Middle Cerebral Artery: Lateral cerebrum [major contribution], Wernicke's area, Broca's area, and macular area.

 

Option A: Urinary incontinence

  • The anterior cerebral artery supplies the Cortical micturition center (CMC), which is located in the medial aspect of the frontoparietal cortex.
  • The occlusion in the marked area will develop Urinary incontinence. Hence, it is a true statement.

Option C: Apraxia

  • Apraxia: Inability to perform motor tasks on command d/o a lesion in the cerebral hemisphere (Parietal lobe).
  • This area is supplied Anterior cerebral artery. So, occlusion in the marked area will develop Apraxia. Hence, it's a true statement.

Option D: Perianal anesthesia

  • The contralateral lower limb and part of the pelvis & perineum and the Cortical Micturition Center (CMC) are located in the medial aspect of the frontoparietal cortex, which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
  • The occlusion in the marked area will develop perianal anesthesia. Hence, it's a true statement.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented with involuntary rhythmic movements of her hands for the past 3 months, worse at rest and affecting both hands, with a history of chronic liver disease, hypertension, and peripheral artery disease. What is the most likely diagnosis based on examination findings and the structure involved in the patient's pathology, as shown in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Options C: Paralysis agitans

  1. This is a paralysis agitans, also known as Parkinson's disease.
  2. The marked structure is the substantia nigra of the brain (dark due to neuro melanin) (in the mid-brain).
  3. Produce dopamine
  4. Lesion + → dopamine decreases → resulting in Parkinson's disease/paralysis agitans.
  5. A neurodegenerative disorder that affects predominately the dopamine-producing ("dopaminergic") neurons in a specific area of the brain called the substantia nigra.

Symptoms:

  • Symptoms generally develop slowly over the years. The progression of symptoms is often a bit different from one person to another due to the diversity of the disease. People with Parkinson's disease may experience:
  • The tremor, mainly at rest and described as pill rolling tremor in hands; other forms of tremor are possible
  • Slowness and paucity of movement (called bradykinesia and hypokinesia)
  • Limb stiffness (rigidity)
  • Gait and balance problems (postural instability)

Options A: Dementia

  • The most common cause of dementia is Alzheimer's disease.
  • Although Parkinson's disease can also cause dementia, it has other causes also, such as brain injury, infections etc

Options B: Alzheimer

  • It is a neurodegenerative disorder that is slow and progressive.
  • The most common cause of dementia is Alzheimer's disease.
  • Caused by neurofibrillary tangles and A-beta plaques in the hippocampus.

Options D: Chorea

 

  • Chorea is a purposeless involuntary movement, which may occur due to involvement of basal ganglia structures like Caudate nucleus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl comes to the emergency department with an incised wound in the front of her wrist. The patient has had a history of untreated depression for the last 5 years. The patient is unable to oppose the tips of the little finger and the thumb. Which of the following nerves is/are involved?
questions.solution:
Option C: Median and ulnar nerves

  • Opposition is the position of the thumb in which the thumb is diametrically opposite to the distal pad of the middle finger.
  • This movement is very important as it helps to grasp objects and tools very efficiently by rotating the thumb.
  • Incised wounds in front of the wrist damage the median nerve often, but the ulnar nerve may also get involved.
  • The opposition of the tips of the little finger and thumb requires opponens pollicis (supplied by median nerve) and opponens digiti minimi (supplied by ulnar nerve).
  • In Carpal tunnel syndrome, the patient is also unable to oppose the thumb.

Option A: Ulnar nerve alone

  • Ulnar nerve palsy alone cannot cause the failure of thumb opposition as opponens pollicis is supplied by the median nerve.

Option B: Median nerve alone

  • Median nerve palsy alone cannot cause the failure of opposition as opponens digiti minimi is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

Option D: Radial and ulnar nerves

  • The radial nerve doesn't play any role in the opposition of the thumb. It only supplies extensors of hand.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the hospital by his parents due to a high-grade fever, swollen hands and feet, and a rash over his body. The fever developed five days ago and did not respond to paracetamol. On physical examination, there is cervical lymphadenopathy, swollen, erythematous palms, and soles with peeling skin. The eyes are red and injected. Identify the correct statement regarding the most likely diagnosis.

choices.text: It is an acute febrile mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome
It is not a common vasculitic disorder in childhood
In the acute stage, only aspirin is used in the treatment
In the convalescent stage, both IVIG and aspirin are used in the treatment

questions.solution:
Option A: It is an acute febrile mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome

  • It is a case of Kawasaki disease.
  • It is an acute febrile mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.
  • The child usually presents with a short history of high-grade fever associated with the rash on any main body part, palpable lymph nodes in the neck, red swollen palms and feet with peeling of skin from palms and soles.
  • Other signs may include diarrhoea, weight loss and irritability.

Option B: It is not a common vasculitic disorder in childhood

  • Kawasaki disease is the commonest vasculitis disorder in childhood.
  • It affects children younger than 5 years of age.

 Option C: In the acute stage, Only aspirin is used in the treatment

  • In acute stage IV, immunoglobulin 2 g/kg over 10-12 hours is used along with Aspirin 80-100 mg/kg/day every 6 hours orally.
  • Only aspirin is used in the convalescent stage.

 Option D:  In the convalescent stage, Both IVIG and aspirin are used in the treatment

  • Aspirin 3-5 mg/kg once daily is used in the convalescent stage until 6-8 weeks after illness onset if normal coronary findings throughout.
  • IVIG is used only in the acute stage.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for an evaluation of developmental delays and mental retardation. The patient has a history of multiple seizure-like episodes. His parents also describe that the boy often appears restless and constantly moving. He also experiences tremors. On examination, the boy has a musty body odour and blue eyes. If the incidence of the disease this patient suffers from in the general population is 1 in 10,000. How often is the disease transmitted?
questions.solution:
Option A: 1/50

  • This patient is suffering from phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • Patients with PKU have a mutation in the PAH gene that leads to the deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase. It is responsible for the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.
  • The inability of the body to make tyrosine makes it an essential amino acid.
  • Excess of phenylalanine and reduced tyrosine lead to clinical symptoms of phenylketonuria, such as mental retardation, seizures, blue eyes, fair skin, musty or mousy body odour, tremors, and hyperactivity.
  • PKU is an autosomal recessive disorder, and both copies of a particular gene should be mutated to cause the disease.
  • Both parents must have at least one mutated copy of a particular gene to transmit the disease to the offspring.
  • If the incidence of an autosomal recessive disorder is known, its carrier frequency can be calculated using the Hardy-Weinberg principle.
  • In this case scenario, PKU incidence is 1 in 10,000, then q2 is equal to 1/10,000, and q is equal to 1/100.
  • As p+q=1 and p=99/100.
  • Now carrier frequency can be calculated by putting these values in Hardy-Weinberg equation 2*99/100*1/100 (2pq), which is approximately equal to 1/50.
  • Therefore, it can be said that the carrier frequency for an autosomal recessive disorder equals twice the square root of disease incidence.

Option B: 1/100

  • PKU is an autosomal recessive disorder, and the incidence of PKU in a given population is 1/10,000.
  • It means that q2 is equal to 1/10,000, and the value of q is equal to 1/100.
  • The carrier frequency is calculated by 2pq, which is equal to 1/50.

Option C: 1/500

  • According to the Hardy-Weinberg equation, the carrier frequency is represented by 2pq.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is 1/50.

Option D: 1/1000

  • Hardy-Weinberg equation states p2+2pq+q2.
  • In this equation, 2pq represents the carrier frequency of an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • 1/1000 is the wrong answer as per the Hardy-Weinberg equation. The carrier frequency is equal to 1/50

questions.text: An infant is evaluated in the nursery. The infant was born by vaginal delivery about an hour before. The mother has a history of preeclampsia during pregnancy. The mother had a vesicular rash over her body two days ago, but the rash spread towards the body. APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The boy weighs 3 kg . The vital signs are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate step for this infant?

choices.text: Test for the presence of antibody

questions.solution:
Option C: Passive immunization with monoclonal antibody

  • The mother's fever and vesicular rash are indicators of the outbreak of varicella-zoster virus or chickenpox.
  • They spread through droplets, and both are highly contagious.
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is giving immunoglobulins or vaccines to the patient after exposure to the virus to prevent future infection.
  • If the patients are not immunized or have not received two doses of the varicella-zoster virus vaccine, then post-exposure prophylaxis should be recommended. If the patient is immunocompetent, the post-exposure prophylaxis is limited to immunization with the live varicella-zoster virus vaccine.
  • For high-risk patients (as in this infant), who can't receive the varicella virus vaccine, post-exposure prophylaxis is given through immunoglobulins against the varicella-zoster virus. This is also called  VZIG or Varicella zoster immunoglobulins. The indications of varicella zoster immunoglobulins are neonates, immunocompromised patients, and pregnant women. In infants, it is effective if the mother gets infected  5 days before and two days after delivery.

Option A: Active immunization with live attenuated virus

  • The varicella-zoster vaccine is recommended for immunocompetent patients. Neonates have compromised immunity, so the live virus vaccine is contraindicated at less than 1 year of age.

Option B: Close observation

  • Follow-up and close observation is not indicated in this case because there is a 95% chance that exposed infants may get an infection.
  • Neonatal varicella infection is a severe disease involving multiple systems, e.g. meningitis, encephalitis or hepatitis.

Option D: Test for the presence of antibody

  • Testing for immunoglobulins is not helpful in this case because the infant has not had enough time to make his immunoglobulins. After all, it takes two to three weeks to develop after the infection, and the mother can't transfer her immunoglobulins (IgG) to the infant through the placenta; that's why this infant is at risk of infection, so proper treatment should be indicated

questions.text: A 1-year-old male is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by his mother for his routine evaluation. She is concerned about the patient’s height. Physical examination reveals that the patient’s weight is tripled, and the length has increased by 50% since birth. Which of the following gives the exact time for the height to become twice as long as it was at birth?
questions.solution:
Option D: 4 years

The approximate anthropometric values by age are as follows:

Age

Height (cm)

Birth

50

1 year

75

2 years

90

4 years

100

12 years

150
  • So, the child's length increases by 50% in the first year.
  • Birth length doubles by the age of 4 - 4 ½ years.
  • By the age of 12 years, the height becomes triple as compared to length at birth.

Option A: 1 year

  • Calculation of expected height of child = (6x + 77) cm, where x is the age in years.
  •  Based on this formula, at the end of one year, the height will not be doubled; instead, it will increase by 50%.

Option B: 2 years

  • Based on the formula, the length at 2 years of age would not be doubled but will increase by 80%.

Option C: 3 years

  • By 3 years of age height of the child will not become double; instead, it will increase by 90%.

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child is brought to the pediatric OPD by her mother, who was normal at birth having normal early development. However, she now presents with microcephaly, regression of acquired language and motor milestones, and abnormal stereotypic hand-wringing movements. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rett syndrome

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette is a classical case of Rett syndrome. The hallmark of the disease is the loss of motor skills and language and regression of the previously attained milestones of life. (child starts to lose their skills). Other features of Rett syndrome are:-
    • X linked dominant inheritance
    • Gene involved - MECP2 gene
    • Mostly females (almost exclusively the females)
    • Normal head circumference at birth and normal early development.
    • Deceleration of head growth and acquired microcephaly
    • Loss of purposeful hand movements with the development of stereotypic hand-wringing movement

Option A: Angelman syndrome

  • It is a defect of gene silencing.
  • It is characterised by seizures, ataxia, mental retardation, and inappropriate laughter (happy puppets)

Option C: Asperger syndrome

  • It is characterised by significant social inheritance, nonverbal communication difficulties, and restricted and repetitive patterns of behaviour and interest.

Option D: Metachromatic Dystrophy

  • Lysosomal storage disease
  • Causes progressive demyelination of the central (white matter) and peripheral nervous system.
  • It is characterised by muscle wasting and weakness, stiff muscles, delayed development, and loss of sight that worsens over time and leads to blindness, convulsions, trouble swallowing, paralysis, and dementia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the hospital with complaints of fever associated with retro-orbital pain. The patient gives a typical history of a mosquito bite that presents with white dots. On examination, the patient presents with narrow pulse pressure with cold extremities. Which of the following clinical features are seen in the condition, as mentioned earlier?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pleural effusion

  • The above-mentioned clinical scenario is dengue shock syndrome.

  • The dengue virus causes dengue fever.

  • Four distinct antigenic types of dengue viruses are known.

  • Dengue shock syndrome is seen in dengue hemorrhagic fever. Simultaneous or sequential infections with multiple dengue viruses lead to dengue hemorrhagic fever.

  • Pleural effusion is a complication seen in dengue hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome.

  • Pleural effusion occurs due to the plasma leakage into the pleural cavity in dengue hemorrhagic fever.

  • Breathlessness observed in dengue hemorrhagic fever is due to pleural effusion.

  • Venous pooling of blood also increases the hydrostatic pressure and contributes to the development of pleural effusion in dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Option A: Cardiomegaly

  • Cardiomegaly is not seen in dengue hemorrhagic fever.

  • Dengue shock syndrome develops due to the following reasons:

    • Plasma leakage

    • Venous pooling of blood

  • Shock is not due to congestive heart failure in dengue hemorrhagic fever.

  • Cardiomegaly is seen in the following viral diseases:

  • Coxsackievirus

  • Adenovirus

  • Parvovirus

  • Influenza virus

  • Cytomegalovirus

Option C: Thrombocytosis

  • Dengue hemorrhagic fever causes thrombocytopenia.

  • Thrombocytopenia seen in dengue hemorrhagic fever is due to the following reasons:

  • Increased platelet destruction and clearance

  • Decreased platelet production

  • Scattered petechiae, spontaneous ecchymosis, easy bruising and bleeding are manifestations of thrombocytopenia in dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Option D: Decreased haemoglobin concentration

  • Haemoglobin concentration is increased in dengue hemorrhagic fever, due to plasma leakage and increased capillary permeability.

  • As a result of plasma leakage, complete blood count shows elevated hematocrit, packed cell volume and haemoglobin levels.

questions.text: A child was admitted to the pediatric department Upon improvement in her health, she was making cooing sounds and laughing aloud. However, she was not able to sit. She was not able to engage in mirror play and did not have any stranger anxiety. While the senior doctor was taking a clinical class for the final-year students, one of them asked, What is the developmental age of this child?
questions.solution:
Option B: 4 months

  • A child laughs aloud at the age of 4 months.
  • 1 month → alerts to sound
  • 2 months → Vocalizes
  • 3 months → Coos
  • 4 months → Laughs aloud

Personal social and cognitive milestones

Spontaneous smile

Neonatal period

Recognizes mother

3 months

Hand regard

Begins at 12 weeks and ends at 20 weeks

Smiles at a mirror image

5 months

Vocalizes or jumps while looking at a mirror image

6 months

Object permanence

9 months

 

Option A: 2 months

  • At the age of 2 months, a child just vocalizes.
  • In the above scenario, the child was laughing loudly, which was not present at the age of 2 months.

Option C: 6 months

  • At the age of 6 months, the child is able to speak monosyllables.
  • The above child is just making a cooing sound.

Option D: 9 months

  • At the age of 9 months, the child speaks syllables.
  • At the age of 9 months, the child responds more to looking in the mirror or holding objects.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to urology OPD by his father with a complaint of increased penile size and excessive pubic hair. Upon further investigation, his three younger brothers have no history of similar issues. On examination, bilateral testicular enlargement is evident. A comprehensive hormonal evaluation showed an elevated serum testosterone value (4.0 nmol/L) and a prepubertal gonadotropin hormone value. What is the most common cause of peripheral precocious puberty in males?
questions.solution:
Option A: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a rare inherited autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a deficiency of one of the enzymes required to synthesize specific hormones (glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen). Congenital adrenal hyperplasia affects the adrenal glands present at the top of each kidney.
  • Many individuals with congenital adrenal hyperplasia present with enlarged adrenal glands, also known as hyperplastic adrenomegaly, which produce excessive male steroid hormone.
  • Due to an enzyme deficiency, the body will be unable to produce one or more of these hormones, which will lead to the overproduction of another type of hormone precursor to compensate for the loss.
  • Males with congenital adrenal hyperplasia have large size of genitalia before reaching puberty. Other symptoms include fast body growth, deep voice, early beard, excessive pubic hair and premature completion of development, leading to short stature if they are not diagnosed and treated in early life.

Option B: Constitutional

  • In males, puberty begins at the age of 9 to 11 years.

  • The sequence of puberty in males is as follows: Testicular enlargement → Penis enlargement → Pubic hair growth→ Peak growth velocity →Axillary hair →Facial hair
  • Precocious puberty is the onset of puberty of fewer than eight years in girls and less than nine years in boys.

Option C: Klinefelter’s syndrome

  • Boys with Klinefelter’s syndrome do not begin or complete pubertal development.
  • There is the failure of the testes to grow normally, incomplete virilization and gynecomastia.

Option D: CNS pathology

  • Many space-occupying lesions, like hamartoma, CNS irradiation, hydrocephalus, etc., can cause precocious puberty.
  • These are associated with other neurological deficits.

questions.text: At 38 weeks of pregnancy, a 32-year-old lady with poorly controlled diabetes delivered a healthy child. Pancreatic islets in the neonate would be expected to demonstrate which of the following morphological responses to injury resulting from maternal hyperglycemia during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hyperplasia

  • Infants born to diabetic moms have a 6% to 10% chance of developing serious developmental abnormalities such as heart and great vascular malformations and neural tube problems.
  • The islet cells of the pancreas have a proliferative capacity during fetal development, and they respond to increasing demand for insulin by experiencing physiologic hyperplasia.
  • A fetus may develop pancreatic hyperplasia, which can produce insulin and induce hypoglycemia at birth.

Option A: Atrophy

  • Atrophy is a decrease in the size of a cell or organ
  • This can be due to the disuse of your muscles in neurological conditions.

Option B: Dysplasia

  • Dysplasia is the abnormal growth or development of cells or organs
  • Examples are cervical dysplasia, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, etc.

Option D: Metaplasia

  • Metaplasia is the transformation of one cell type to another cell type.
  • This change from one cell to another cell is called Metaplasia.
  • Types are intestinal Metaplasia and squamous Metaplasia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old guy has a persistent cough, a low-grade fever, night sweats, and overall malaise. An X-ray of the chest reveals abnormalities "compatible with a Ghon complex." Acid-fast bacilli are seen in sputum culture. Which of the following pathologic alterations would be most likely to be found in this patient's hilar lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Option A: Caseous necrosis

  • A type of necrosis characterized by granular debris results from macrophages walling off a pathogen.
  • Seen in tubercular, fungal, and Nocardia infections.
  • Histopathological examination shows cellular debris, lymphocytes, and macrophages that form granulomas.
  • Caseous necrosis is associated with granulomatous infections such as nocardiosis, tuberculosis (including renal tuberculosis), and histoplasmosis. 
  • Histologic examination of Caseous necrosis would show acellular material that appears granular and is surrounded by  macrophages, T-cells, and giant cells
  • Caseous necrosis refers to necrosis in tuberculosis that appears granular and cheesy on the surface.
  • This necrotic material appears amorphous, structureless, eosinophilic, granular debris under the microscope, with no cellular features visible (as opposed to coagulative necrosis, in which cell outlines are preserved).

Option B: Coagulative necrosis

  • Coagulative necrosis occurs due to tissue ischemia in solid organs such as the heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys (e.g., splenic infarction).
  • Ischemia is characterized by decreased oxygen delivery, which reduces the amount of ATP produced via aerobic glycolysis.
  • The hypoxic cells have to switch to anaerobic metabolism, which increases lactic acid production, resulting in acidosis. Acidosis causes the denaturation of proteins (including proteolytic and particularly lysosomal enzymes), preventing the cell from dissolving (autolysis).
  • For this reason, coagulative necrosis is characterized by a temporarily preserved cellular architecture without cell nuclei or nuclei still undergoing karyolysis.

Option C: Fat necrosis

  • A type of necrosis in which adipose cells die off prematurely, either caused by an enzymatic reaction or traumatic injury.
  • Enzymatic fat necrosis: release of lipase and triglycerides from the cytoplasm of damaged cells → breakdown of triglycerides by lipase→ binding of fatty acids to calcium → saponification → chalky-white appearance
  • Combination of fat saponification and calcium → dark blue appearance on H&E stain
  • Enzymatic: acute pancreatitis (due to saponification of peripancreatic fat)
  • Non-enzymatic: traumatic breast injury 

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is most commonly seen in blood vessels in patients with vasculitides or malignant hypertension. It is characterized by an immune complex and fibrin deposition in the blood vessel wall.
  • This patient's ischemic infarct was in the spleen, which is not subject to fibrinoid necrosis.
  • Histologic examination of fibrinoid necrosis would show protein-rich, eosinophilic acellular material in damaged vessels.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is a condition that occurs in people who have necrotizing vasculitis.

questions.text: With more than 1 in 10 new cancer diagnoses yearly, breast cancer is the most common cancer in women. It is the second most frequent cancer-related death among women worldwide. Breast cancer is connected to:
questions.solution:
Option A: BRCA1

  • The BRCA1 gene in humans encodes a protein known as breast cancer type 1 susceptibility protein.
  • The BRCA1 and BRCA2 (BReast CAncer genes 1 and 2, respectively) generate proteins that aid in repairing DNA damage. Each of these genes is in two copies, one from each parent.
  • Inheriting damaged copies of the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes can increase the risk of breast cancer and ovarian cancer in women, breast and prostate cancer in men, and other cancers.
  • Women with BRCA1 and BRCA2 Mutations
  • Few Medical Options:
    • Among other drugs, tamoxifen, raloxifene, and aromatase inhibitors reduce the risk of breast or ovarian cancer.
    • Mammograms and breast MRIs should be used annually for screening, starting earlier.

Option B: CA19-9

  • It is a tumour  marker associated with colon cancer

  • it is an incorrect option as the question is regarding breast carcinoma

Option C: TP53

  • Tumour protein P53, also known as p53, cellular tumour antigen p53, the Guardian of the Genome, phosphoprotein p53, tumour suppressor p53, antigen NY-CO-13, or transformation-related protein 53, is any isoform of a protein encoded by homologous genes in various organisms, such as TP53 and Trp53.
  • Instructions for producing a protein known as tumour protein p53 are found in the TP53 gene (or p53).
  • This protein acts as a tumour suppressor, which regulates cell division by keeping cells from growing and dividing (proliferating) too fast or uncontrolled.
  • Mutations (changes) in the TP53 gene may cause cancer cells to grow and spread in the body. These changes have been found in a genetic condition called Li-Fraumeni syndrome and in many types of cancer.
  • The TP53 gene is a type of tumour suppressor gene. Also called the p53 gene and tumour protein p53 gene.

Option D: ATR

  • ATR is associated with ataxia telangiectasia.
  • The portion of the brain that regulates speech and motor movements degenerate
  • The disease's initial symptoms are slurred speech and shaky gait, typically in children under five.
  • The disorder is caused by changes (mutations) of a gene known as ATM (for “AT mutated”) that has been mapped to the long arm (q) of chromosome 11 (11q22. 3).
  • The ATM gene controls (encodes for) the production of an enzyme that plays a role in regulating cell division following DNA damage.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of pain in the lower limbs upon walking and blackening of the tips of his fingers. He has an 80-pack-year history of smoking. Laboratory investigations show haemoglobin of 15 g/dL, WBC of 8,300/μL, cholesterol of 223 mg/dL, and fasting blood sugar of 97 mg/dL. Tests for antinuclear antibodies are negative. Biopsy of the affected area (shown in the image) shows intraluminal thrombi in medium-sized arteries and inflammation extending from arteries to neighbouring veins and nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Buerger disease

  • Thromboangiitis obliterans, often known as Buerger disease, is an occlusive inflammatory illness that affects the small and medium arteries in the distal hands and legs.
  • The etiologic role of smoking has been highlighted by the observation that smoking cessation might be recognised through remission.
  • Small to medium-sized arteries and veins can develop thrombosis, accompanied by microabscesses, multinucleated giant cells, and extensive polymorphonuclear leukocyte aggregation. End-stage lesions exhibit a well-organised thrombus and fibrosis of the blood vessels.
  • A microscopic examination of the afflicted vessels indicates a polymorphonuclear infiltration that extends to nearby veins and nerves.
  • Patients usually have signs and symptoms of ischemia in the distal arteries of the upper or lower limbs, such as claudication in the calf and the foot arch.
  • This condition, which manifests as pain in the hands, feet, and fingers when at rest, is known as the Raynaud phenomenon or livedo reticularis.
  • Thrombosis and the obliteration of the afflicted arteries are associated with endothelial inflammation. The various choices are unrelated to smoking and no longer highlight those noteworthy histologic results.

Option B: Churg-Strauss disease

  • Churg-Strauss syndrome is characterised by nonspecific findings, which frequently include flu-like symptoms such as fever, malaise, generalised weakness and exhaustion, anorexia, weight loss, and muscle discomfort (myalgia).
  • It is also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA).
  • The histology of EGPA demonstrates tissue eosinophilia, necrotising vasculitis, and granulomatous inflammation that is eosinophil-rich.

Option C: Wegener granulomatosis

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly known as Wegener granulomatosis (WG), is a small-to-medium vessel necrotising vasculitis that is a part of a wide range of conditions known as anti-neutrophil-cytoplasmic-antibody (ANCA) linked vasculitides (AAV).
  • Hallmark features include necrotising granulomas and pauci-immune vasculitis that most commonly affects the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis

  • Takayasu arteritis, also known as pulseless disease, is a chronic inflammatory illness that damages the medium and large arteries and their branches.
  • It primarily affects girls and women younger than 40.
  • It typically affects the aorta and its major branches, especially the carotid, subclavian, and renal arteries, and causes stenosis, occlusions, or aneurysmal degeneration of these large arteries.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to acute, severe left-sided chest pain for 20 minutes. She was admitted to the hospital 3 weeks ago for acute myocardial infarction. Her blood pressure is 80/40mmHg, and her pulse is 100/min. Physical examination reveals an anxious person with elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) and reduced heart sounds. Appropriate measures are taken, but the patient fails to survive. An autopsy is carried out to find the cause of death. The image below shows the changes in the patient's heart:



Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cardiac tamponade

  • The image above shows a tear in the left ventricular wall.
  • The patient presents with the clinical features of cardiac tamponade, i.e., hypotension, raised JVP, and decreased cardiac sounds.
  • Myocardial rupture occurs in 1-5% of cases and is usually fatal.
  • The most common site of rupture is the left ventricular wall. The free wall rupture leads to hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, which is rapidly fatal.
  • Ventricular septal rupture may cause ventricular septal defect with a left-to-right shunt.
  • Papillary muscle rupture causes severe mitral regurgitation.
  • It occurs between 3-7 days after infarction when the necrotic myocardium is being lysed, and the infarct is converted to soft, friable granulation tissue.
  • Risk factors for myocardial rupture include age greater than 60 years, anterior or lateral wall infarction, female gender, absence of left ventricular hypertrophy, and first myocardial infarction.

Option B: Ventricular aneurysm

  • Ventricular aneurysms (as shown in the image above) can cause mural thrombus, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
  • They do not cause myocardial rupture and cardiac tamponade.

Option C: Mural thrombus

  • Mural thrombus fills up the ventricular cavity (as shown above).
  • Any infarct combined with decreased contractility, chamber dilation, and endocardial damage can cause the formation of a mural thrombus.
  • This can lead to left-sided thromboembolism.
  • It does not lead to myocardial rupture or cardiac tamponade.

Option D: Septic shock

  • Septic shock presents with fever, hypotension, multiorgan failure, and leukocytosis.
  • The patient did not have clinical features of septic shock, and the image (in the question) shows ventricular rupture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oligodendroglioma

  • The tumours are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm, giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumour typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Perineuronal Satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma.
  • Most commonly presented in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (mainly in the temporal or frontal lobes).

  • Image on the left showing perinuclear halos giving rise to a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • Image on the right showing Perineuronal satellitosis.

Option A: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma is a Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • It is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumour with one-year median survival.
  • It is found in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • It can cross the corpus callosum "butterfly glioma" associated with EGFR amplification.
  • It is of astrocyte origin, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumour cells with central border areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • It is a low-grade astrocytoma. Most common primary brain tumour in childhood.
  • Usually well circumscribed.
  • In children, most often found in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellum), but supratentorial can also be found.
  • It has a benign course and a good prognosis.
  • Histology shows it is of astrocyte origin, GFAP positive, with bipolar neoplastic cells with hairlike projections.
  • Associated with microcysts and Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic, corkscrew fibres)

Option D: Medulloblastoma

  • Most common malignant brain tumour in childhood.
  • It commonly involves the cerebellum and can compress the 4th ventricle causing non-communicating hydrocephalus causing, headaches and papilledema.
  • It can involve the cerebellar vermis causing truncal ataxia.
  • It can send "drop metastases" to the spinal cord.
  • Histology shows it is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET).
  • "Homer-Wright rosette" (small blue cells surrounding the central area of the neuropil)
  • It is positive for synaptophysin.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with a high-grade fever and neck pain. He was suffering from an upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago. On examination, his thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and tender. Laboratory analysis shows elevated leukocytes and ESR. After a thorough clinical evaluation, de Quervain's thyroiditis is diagnosed. Which of the following is the feature of de-Quervain thyroiditis?

choices.text: In the early phase, follicles are disrupted and replaced by neutrophils forming microabscesses
Orphan Annie nuclei are seen on histology
Bacterial infection is a trigger in most patients
It is the most common cause of painful, multinodular thyroid

questions.solution:
The correct option is:

B. Orphan Annie nuclei are seen on histology

Explanation:

De Quervain thyroiditis, also known as subacute granulomatous thyroiditis or giant cell thyroiditis, is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland. It is typically a self-limiting condition that can cause thyroid pain and dysfunction. Here's why the given option is correct:

 Orphan Annie nuclei are seen on histology: This is a characteristic histological finding in De Quervain thyroiditis. "Orphan Annie" nuclei refer to the appearance of enlarged, pale, and empty-appearing nuclei within thyroid follicular cells. These nuclear changes are seen in the affected thyroid tissue and are a key feature of the condition.

Now, let's discuss the incorrect options:

A. In the early phase, follicles are disrupted and replaced by neutrophils forming microabscesses: This statement is not typical of De Quervain thyroiditis. While inflammation is a feature, it is not characterized by neutrophilic microabscess formation. Instead, the condition is associated with granulomatous inflammation.

C. Bacterial infection is a trigger in most patients: De Quervain thyroiditis is typically considered a viral infection-triggered condition, not bacterial. It often follows a viral illness, such as an upper respiratory infection.

D. It is the most common cause of painful, multinodular thyroid: De Quervain thyroiditis can cause painful thyroid enlargement, but it is not the most common cause of a painful, multinodular thyroid. Other thyroid conditions, such as subacute thyroiditis and Graves' disease, can also present with thyroid pain and multinodularity.

So, option b is the feature specific to De Quervain thyroiditis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to the hospital with burning upper abdominal pain for 2 months. Pain is burning and relieves with antacids or food. Moreover, she has a history of hyperparathyroidism.

Subsequently, her laboratory tests show microcytic and hypochromic anaemia, and her gastroscopy shows a bleeding mucosal defect in the antrum. Which of the following statements best characterises the pathogenesis of upper abdominal pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increased Secretion of Gastrin

  • Given clinical features point towards Peptic ulcer disease, secondary to hyperparathyroidism.
  • The incidence of peptic ulcer disease is increased in patients with hyperparathyroidism because hypercalcemia increases serum gastrin, thereby stimulating gastric acid secretion.
  • Peptic ulcers in the context of MEN-1 may be secondary to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Option A: Decreased Serum Calcium levels

  • Decreased serum calcium levels will not increase the levels of gastrin.
  • Hence no effect on gastric acid excess secretion and peptic ulcer disease

Option B: Decreased Serum levels of PTH

  • A decrease in parathyroid hormone will cause decreased serum calcium levels and will not increase the levels of gastrin.
  • Hence no effect on gastric acid excess secretion and peptic ulcer disease.

Option C: Decreased Secretion of Gastrin

  • It is rare to have gastrin levels that are too low. 
  • But if they are, the stomach might not absorb nutrients properly. 
  • It might also have a higher risk of infection in the digestive system.
  • Drugs that can decrease gastrin levels include caffeine and corticosteroids

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with newly developed diabetes mellitus died on the way to the hospital after a car accident. He had a long-standing history of diabetes that is poorly controlled with medication. If an autopsy is performed, which of the following findings would be least likely to be consistent with type II diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Insulitis

Type I diabetes:

  • Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β cells in genetically susceptible individuals HLA association: HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4 positive patients are at increased risk of developing T1DM.
  • Associated with other autoimmune conditions, Hashimoto thyroiditis, Type A gastritis, Celiac disease and Primary adrenal insufficiency

Insulinitis:

  • Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a chronic autoimmune disease in which autoreactive T-cells and inflammation cause severe loss of pancreatic beta cells. Insulitis, the pathologic hallmark of T1D, is an inflammatory lesion consisting of immune cell infiltrates around and within the islets.
  • Genetic susceptibility and environmental triggers (often associated with previous viral infection) → autoimmune response with production of autoantibodies, e.g., anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibody (anti-GAD), anti-islet cell cytoplasmic antibody (anti-ICA) → progressive destruction of β cells in the pancreatic islets → absolute insulin deficiency → decreased glucose uptake in the tissues.

Option A: Amylin deposition in pancreatic islets

  • Amylin is secreted from the pancreas
  • It provides a better glycemic control
  • Deposition of amylin in the pancreas is seen in type II diabetes

Option B: Armanni-Ebstein lesion

  • The Armanni-Ebstein lesion is a histological change in the kidney consisting of sub-nuclear vacuolation of the proximal tubules.
  • It has been most associated with diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • The vacuoles have been reported to contain glycogen.
  • More recent studies show them to contain fat

Option D: Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules

  • Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodule is defined as a roughly round mass of any size within the glomerular tuft, eosinophilic and homogeneous after hematoxylin and eosin staining but laminated or fibrillar after periodic acid-methenamine silver staining, usually with a ring of nuclei at the periphery but sometimes with a few nuclei within the mass
  • Seen in diabetes

questions.text: A 55-year-old male comes to the outdoor patient department with complaints of severe muscle weakness and drooping eyelids. He states that his symptoms worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after a short rest. A chest X-ray reveals an anterior mediastinal mass. A biopsy of this mass would most likely reveal which of the following pathologic changes?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thymic hyperplasia

  • The patient's clinical features of severe muscle weakness, drooping eyelids, worsening symptoms with repetitive movements, and anterior mediastinal mass clue us into suspecting Myasthenia Gravis.
  • Myasthenia gravis is an Acquired autoimmune disease (Type II Hypersensitivity) characterised by abnormal muscular fatigability caused by circulating antibodies to acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction [post-synaptic].
  • It manifests as ptosis (drooping eyelids) or diplopia (double vision) because of weakness in extraocular muscles.
  • The pattern of weakness is distinctly different from most primary myopathic diseases, in which there is relative sparing of facial and extraocular muscles.
  • The repetitive firing of muscles makes weakness more severe, whereas cholinesterase inhibitors improve strength markedly. This phenomenon is diagnostically useful.
  • In 2/3rd of patients, Thymic hyperplasia is closely associated with Myasthenia gravis & 15% have Thymoma.
  • Conversely, 1/3rd to 1/2 of patients with Thymoma develop myasthenia gravis.
  • Thymectomy is often an effective treatment for these patients.
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors, immunosuppression, and plasmapheresis can also be used in treatment.

Option A: B-cell lymphoma

  • B-cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma that involves B-cells.
  • They present with weight loss, fever, flu, and other constitutional symptoms.
  • They can also show mediastinal mass, but drooping of eyelids and worsening symptoms with activity are uncommon.

Option B: Hodgkin lymphoma

  • Hodgkin lymphoma can also present as a mediastinal mass and show bilobed Reed-Sternberg cells on biopsy, but the clinical picture is different as it manifests constitutional symptoms.

Option C: Metastatic Carcinoma

  • Cancer can metastasise anywhere and present as a mass, but the clinical features presented in the patient are unlikely to be seen in a Metastatic carcinoma.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man who is a known case of Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 presents to the physician’s clinic with a 5-month history of weakness and fatigue. There is no history of drug or alcohol abuse. His nutritional history is good, as he eats a healthy balanced diet. On physical examination, he looks pale. The rest of his systemic examination is unremarkable. His complete blood count (CBC) shows megaloblastic anaemia and a normal reticulocyte count. Further laboratory investigations reveal vitamin B12 deficiency. Anaemia in this patient is most likely caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Autoimmune gastritis

  • Autoimmune gastritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that destroys parietal cells of the corpus and fundus of the stomach. The known consequence is vitamin B12 deficiency and, consequently, pernicious anaemia.  
  • Parietal cells are epithelial cells that produce hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factors.
  • The gastric H+ /K+ ATPase and the proton pump, recognized by CD4+ T cells, primarily manage the acidification of the stomach.
  • Chronic inflammation leads to atrophy of the mucosa and total loss of parietal cells during the progression of the disease resulting in increased pH of the stomach and loss of intrinsic factors.
  • Intrinsic factor is required to uptake vitamin B12, and vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anaemia) is a known consequence of Autoimmune Gastritis.
  • The loss of parietal cells creates a state of constant achlorhydria.
  • These cases could present with mild symptoms, such as pallor, weakness, and fatigue, or more severe cases, such as peripheral neuropathy or subacute combined degeneration.
  • The diagnosis of Autoimmune gastritis is made histologically through endoscopic biopsy.
  • Serologic testing for autoantibodies may or may not be used clinically as an adjunct for the diagnosis.

Option A: Acute erosive gastritis

  • Acute erosive gastritis is a self-limited inflammation of the gastric mucosa.
  • Clinically, it presents with epigastric burning, pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Variable amounts of blood may be found in the vomitus.
  • These mucosal changes may be caused by Aspirin and Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, Alcohol, Acid and alkali, stress, Shock-related mucosal ischemia and sepsis.

Option C: Helicobacter Pylori induced gastritis

  • Helicobacter pylori gastritis is chronic gastritis caused by infection with a Gram-negative curved rod. 
  • Helicobacter Pylori gastritis is much more common than autoimmune gastritis.
  • Autoimmune gastritis is restricted to the oxyntic mucosa of the stomach, sparing the antrum. 
  • Helicobacter pylori gastritis is most intense in the antrum.
  • Enterochromaffin-like–cell hyperplasia is usually seen in autoimmune gastritis but not a part of H pylori gastritis.
  • Infection with Helicobacter pylori does not cause B12 deficiency and Pernicious anaemia.

Option D: Menetrier Disease

  • Ménétrier disease is also known as Hyperplastic hypersecretory gastropathy
  • It is a rare disorder associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor (TGF)-α, an EGF receptor (EGFR) ligand, and hyperactivation of the epidermal growth factor receptor on gastric epithelial cells.
  • Excessive EGFR activation causes diffuse hyperplasia of foveolar epithelium within the body and fundus
  • Hypoproteinemia occurs to albumin loss across the gastric mucosa.
  • Secondary symptoms such as weight loss, diarrhoea, and peripheral oedema are common.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presented with a complaint of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. Histopathological examination showed arborization and pseudo-invasion. Gene responsible for the condition is LKB1/STK11. A colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps. What is the most common site of polyp formation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Jejunum

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder
  • Polyps are most commonly seen in the jejunum of the small intestine.
  • Germline loss of function mutations in the LKB1/STK11 gene is present
  • They may occur in the stomach, colon and with much lower frequency in the bladder and lungs
  • Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps are present, along with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.
  • Gross appearance shows that polyps are large and pedunculated with lobulated contour.
  • The proliferation of the muscularis mucosae characterizes histologic findings to form branching configurations covered by hypertrophic but otherwise normal mucosa.

Option A: Colon

  • Adenomatous polyps account for over 70% of all polyps, making them the most prevalent kind of colorectal polyp.
  • When this sort of polyp is discovered, it is examined for malignancy.
  • Only a tiny fraction develop into cancerous polyps; however, almost all malignant polyps begin as adenomatous polyps.
  • Fortunately, transforming these polyps into colon cancer often takes several years.
  • They can be detected and eradicated before this happens with frequent screening.

Option B: Rectum

  • Adenomatous polyps account for over 70% of all polyps, making them the most prevalent kind of colorectal polyp.
  • However the case describes Peutz-Jeghers syndrome in which the Polyps are most commonly seen in the jejunum of the small intestine.

Option C: Esophagus

  • The most prevalent oesophagal polyps are benign squamous oesophagal polyps, which are inflammatory polyps.
  • They mostly affect men near the lower oesophagal junction and are generally linked with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: A 41-year-old male patient was admitted to the surgical ward with advanced colorectal cancer. A left colectomy was performed. The specimen was sent for histopathology, which suggested poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Family history was taken in detail, which showed 6 members (one of them was a first-degree relative) with colon cancer. Their malignancy was diagnosed before 40 years of age. Doctors suspect an inherited syndrome in the family. Which of the following would be the most likely diagnosis if the patient also had multiple osteomas, desmoid tumours, and supernumerary teeth?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gardner syndrome

  • Gardner syndrome is an unusual variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
  • It is an autosomal dominant condition with a high risk of malignancy that is characterized by many adenomatous polyps lining the intestinal mucosal surface.
  • Its main features include the development of intestinal polyposis and colorectal cancer.
  • Intestinal polyposis, desmoids, osteomas, epidermoid cysts and dental abnormalities (supernumerary teeth) are extracolonic presentations. Gardner syndrome is characterized by osteomas of the jaw and skull, epidermal cysts, and fibromatosis.
  • These symptoms are frequently asymptomatic, although they can cause pruritus, irritation, and rupture.
  • Gardner syndrome has been linked to the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene, the colon cancer gene (DCC) deletion, and the TP53 gene.
  • Prevention is the most prevalent strategy for treatment for those who are aware of their familial inheritance or who discover it.

Option A: FAP

  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant polyposis condition with different degrees of penetrance.
  • A mutation causes FAP in the APC gene on chromosome 5. The APC gene functions as a tumour suppressor.
  • APC protein mutations limit apoptosis and allow for unregulated cell proliferation, resulting in the development of adenomas.

Option C: Peutz jeghers syndrome

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is a hereditary condition distinguished by GI polyposis, mucocutaneous pigmented macules, and a propensity for specific malignancies.
  • Mutation in the STK11 gene, also known as the LKB1 gene, causes PJS.

Option D: Cowden syndrome

  • Cowden disease, commonly known as Cowden syndrome or multiple hamartoma syndrome, is an unusual autosomal dominant genodermatosis caused by mutations in the phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene. 
  • The majority of Cowden syndrome patients develop a malignant tumour of the thyroid, endometrium, or breast

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine physical exam. The patient has no chronic medical conditions. The patient has had multiple sexual partners and takes oral contraceptives. She was previously uninsured and has not seen a physician for several years. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), her pulse is 67/min, and her blood pressure is 123/71 mmHg. A Pap smear is performed, and the results are notable for high-grade squamous epithelial dysplasia. Subsequent colposcopy with biopsy confirms the presence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) grade II. Which of the following best describes the portion of the cervix that is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Basal 67% of the epithelium

  • When assessing a cervical lesion, it is important to determine the degree of dysplasia and the depth of involvement.
  • A Pap smear can determine the former, whereas a colposcopy with biopsy can determine the latter.
  • There are two main grades of dysplasia:
    • low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL ) correspond to low-grade dysplasia,
    • whereas high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL ) correspond to moderate or high-grade dysplasia.
  • If a Pap smear shows abnormal results, a biopsy can be subsequently performed to determine the depth of involvement.

Option A: Near full-thickness epithelial involvement

  • Near full-thickness epithelial involvement is seen in CIN III.
  • However, this patient has CIN II, and only two-thirds of the epithelium is involved.

Option B: Apical 33% of the epithelium

  • Patients with CIN II have a disease that affects only the basal two-thirds of the cervical epithelium because the lesion originates from the basal side (i.e., the portion facing the basement membrane ), thus sparing the apical one-third of the epithelium.

Option D: Basal 33% of the epithelium

  • Patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 1 ( CIN I) have a disease that affects only the basal one-third of the cervical epithelium.
  • However, this patient has CIN II, which affects the basal two-thirds of the epithelium.

questions.text: A 2-hour-old newborn male is examined in the nursery. The boy was born to a 42-year-old G2 P1 female at 39 weeks gestation. She did not receive any prenatal screening or assessment. Apgar Scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The child is vitally stable and breathing normally. After a complete examination, the paediatrician suggests a diagnosis of Down syndrome. Which of the following Is a feature of Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A: Upward-slanting palpebral fishers

  • Down syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality in which a newborn has an extra chromosome 21, resulting in a total of 47 chromosomes. 
  • It is also called trisomy 21. 
  • The risk of Down syndrome increases as the mother's age increases. 
  • Common clinical features include
    • Upslanting palpebral fissures
    • Epicanthal folds
    • Brushfield spots
    • High-arched palate
    • Broad and flat nasal bridge 
    • Excess skin at the nape of the neck
    • Transverse palmar crease
    • Short stature
    • Atlanto-axial instability 
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Varying levels of intellectual disability

Option B: Upward and outward lens dislocation

  • Upward and outward lens dislocation is a feature of Marfan syndrome.
  • It is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder affecting the microfibrils and elastin in connective tissue throughout the body.
  • Other features include cardiovascular defects, tall stature, long extremities, and joint hypermobility 

 Option C: Cystic hygroma

  • Cystic hygroma is a feature of Turner syndrome, the most common cause of ovarian dysgenesis and primary ovarian insufficiency. 
  • It is a thin-walled sac-like structure that occurs due to damage to the lymphatic system during development.
  • Other features of Turner syndrome include short stature, a shield chest, a webbed neck, lymph oedema, and delayed puberty.

 Option D: Polydactyly

  • Polydactyly is a feature of trisomy 13. 
  • It is caused by meiotic non-disjunction resulting in an extra chromosome 13.
  • Clinical features include polydactyly, microphthalmia, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly, congenital heart defects, and rocker bottom feet.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the outpatient department with a history of mental confusion and unsteady gait for four days. He also gives a history of worsening night vision for two months. Lab investigations reveal extremely low levels of cholesterol at 40mg/dl. The peripheral blood smear reveals spur cells with irregularly spaced blunt-tipped spicules. The morphologic abnormalities demonstrated in this blood smear are most likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Abnormal spectrin in red cell membranes

questions.solution:
Option B: Chronic liver disease

  • This is the case of abetalipoproteinemia due to chronic liver disease in which a chronically alcoholic male presents with complaints of mental confusion and unsteady gait.
  • The patient also gives a history of worsening night vision for two months.
  • This indicates the neurological manifestations of abetalipoproteinemia, like progressive ataxia and ocular manifestations, like retinitis pigmentosa, in an alcoholic man with chronic liver disease.
  • Lab investigations reveal extremely low levels of cholesterol, while the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of burr cells with irregularly spaced blunt-tipped spicules, commonly called acanthocytes.
  • This confirms the diagnosis of abetalipoproteinemia.
  • Abnormalities in the lipid membrane due to a deficiency of apolipoproteins due to a mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein cause erythrocytes to become deformed and develop irregular spiny surface projections and centrally dense cytoplasm (acanthocytes or spur cells) in this disorder.
  • The most common cause of acanthocytosis is chronic liver disease, in which increased free cholesterol is deposited within the cell membrane.

Option A. Abnormal spectrin in red cell membranes

  • Spectrin is a plasma membrane protein that maintains its integrity and cytoskeletal structure.
  • Abnormal spectrin is the most common cause of hereditary spherocytosis.
  • A blood smear reveals small round cells with no central pallor (spherocytes) and anisocytosis.

Option C: Chronic renal failure

  • Chronic renal failure is associated with the presence of small, blunt projections that are regularly placed around the circumference of RBCs giving it a serrated appearance with central pallor, commonly called burr cells.
  • They are formed by the abnormal lipid composition of the RBC membrane.

Option D: Microthrombi in capillaries

  • Microthrombi in small vessels can be found in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria due to disseminated intravascular coagulation.
  • Flow cytometry is the confirmatory test for such cases showing the absence or reduced expression of CD55 and CD59 glycoproteins on RBCs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete training for a marathon race is advised by his coach to increase his carbohydrate intake after the workout. The carbohydrate uptake will help to build up glycogen stores in the muscles. Glycogen synthase is the main enzyme involved in glycogen synthesis in the muscles. Which of the following acts as an activator of muscle glycogen synthase?
questions.solution:
Option C: Insulin

  • Glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) in the resting muscle is an anabolic process.
  • Insulin is an anabolic hormone and therefore increases the rate of the anabolic pathways.
  • Insulin increases the activity of muscle glycogen synthase after the intake of carbohydrates & increases glycogen reserves in the liver & muscles.
  • It acts by cAMP-mediated dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase 
  • Simultaneously, it also decreases glycogen phosphorylase activity, thereby decreasing glycogenolysis.

Option A: Epinephrine

  • Epinephrine is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released in the fasting state.
  • It will decrease glycogen synthesis by inhibiting glycogen synthase.
  • It will increase glycogenolysis.

Option B: Glucagon

  • Glucagon also is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released mainly in the fasting state to promote glycogenolysis and suppress glycogenesis

Option D: cAMP

  • Phosphorylation of anabolic enzymes such as glycogen synthase and fatty acid synthase is carried out by cAMP.
  • The phosphorylated state of glycogen synthase is inactive, and glycogen formation is suppressed.

questions.text: Which transporter is responsible for the absorption of fructose?
questions.solution:
Option D: GLUT-5

  • As the patient’s liver enzymes are normal and her symptoms seem to correlate with her intake of fruit juices, most likely her problem is an inability to absorb fructose.
  • Lactase deficiency can be ruled out since the removal of cow’s milk from her diet did not eliminate the problem.
  • The primary transporter of fructose in the intestine is GLUT-5 and a deficiency in GLUT-5 would cause inability to absorb fructose in the gut. The fructose accumulated in the intestine will be fermented upon by bacteria to produce various gases, including hydrogen, as well as organic acids.
  • The most common carbohydrate sources for infant formula include lactose, sucrose & corn syrup. Fructose is present in sucrose and corn syrup also.

Option A: GLUT-2

  • GLUT-2 is involved passive absorption of glucose in Liver, pancreas and intestine. And its deficiency causes Fanconi Bickel Syndrome (Glycogen storage disease type XI)
  • Clinical features of this disease are
    • Hepatorenal glycogen accumulation
    • Growth retardation
    • Polyuria and polydipsia
    • Fasting hypoglycemia but post prandial hyperglycemia resembling diabetes

Option B and C: SGLT-1 and SGLT-2

  • SGLT-1 and SGLT-2 are secondary active transporters of glucose and galactose in intestine and kidneys, hence will not affect fructose absorption.
  • Deficiency of SGLT-1 and SGLT-2 causes glucose–galactose malabsorption and familial renal glycosuria respectively.

questions.text: Insulin is responsible for hypoglycemic action after a meal and acts through the combined activities of transporters GLUT-2 and GLUT-4. Which of the following DOES NOT depend on insulin for glucose uptake:
questions.solution:
Option A: Brain

  • In brain, glucose uptake is mediated by GLUT-1 & GLUT-3 which are involved in basal glucose uptake in fed and fasting state (mainly).
  • These GLUTs are active irrespective of presence or absence of insulin. So, there is no relation between insulin and these GLUTs or we can say that GLUT-1 and 3 are not dependent on insulin.
  • So, Brain does not depend on insulin for glucose uptake.

Option B, C and D: Cardiac muscles, Skeletal muscles and Adipose tissue

  • Glucose uptake occurs in muscles (cardiac & skeletal) & adipose tissue via GLUT-4, which is insulin dependent.
  • GLUT-4 is activated by insulin which is released from beta-pancreatic cell on stimulation by GLUT-2 dependent glucose uptake in fed state.
  • Once the blood sugar is lowered to normal levels, insulin release and GLUT-4 activation and synthesis is diminished.
