  • In skeletal muscle, glucose is converted to glycogen whereas in adipose tissues it is stored in the form of fat.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of high fever and erythema on his right forearm with an abscess formation. The culture sensitivity report from the pus shows strains of staphylococcus aureus. Increased activity of the enzyme hyaluronidase is found in the patient's serum. Which of the following compounds in this patient's serum confirm a connective tissue pathology?
questions.solution:
• Extracellular matrix of connective tissues is rich in hyaluronic acid. Some bacterial and viral pathogens produce hyaluronidase as a means of using hyaluronan as a carbon source and as a possible virulence factor.
  • Hyaluronidases are hyaluronoglucosidases i.e. they cleave the (1→4)-linkages between N-acetylglucosamine and glucuronate. The released N-acetylglucosamine can be converted to sialic acid by the action of two bacterial enzymes first by an epimerase to form N-acetylglucosamine-6-P and then by aldolase by transfer of three carbons from pyruvate to form sialic acid (N-acetyl neuraminic acid).
  • The other products which can be detected in serum will be glucuronic acid.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly and failure to thrive. A liver biopsy reveals glycogen with an abnormal, amylopectin-like structure, as shown below:



Which of the following enzymes would most likely be deficient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Branching enzyme

  • The above clinical features & findings are indicative of Anderson’s disease/Amylopectinosis (GSD Type IV) due to deficiency of branching enzyme.
  • In this disease, stored glycogen is abnormal, with long polysaccharide chains having only a few branch points which resemble the amylopectin component of the starch.
  • Other clinical features are hepatosplenomegaly and death from heart or liver failure before age 5.

​​​​​​​Option A: Alpha-amylase

  • Alpha-amylase secreted by the pancreas digests starch into Limit dextrins, maltose, and maltotriose.
  • Increased plasma levels of this enzyme in humans are found in:
    • Salivary trauma
    • Mumps
    • Pancreatitis
    • Kidney failure

Option C: Debranching enzyme

  • The main clinical feature associated with deficiency of debranching enzyme is the accumulation of limit dextrins (glycogen remains having shorter linear chains with very short branch points) in the liver under fasting.
  • In this patient, an amylopectin-like structure is observed, but no limit dextrins were noted.

Option D: Glucose-6-phosphatase

  • The deficiency of this enzyme does not affect the glycogen structure.
  • This enzyme’s deficiency is seen in Von Gierke’s disease.
  • The main clinical feature of this enzyme deficiency is severe fasting hypoglycemia, Hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: What is the accurate definition of isoenzymes and their significance in diagnosing tissue or organ injury or disease in organs like the liver, heart, and muscle?

choices.text: Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze a different reaction
Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same reaction
Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze a different reaction
Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze the same reaction

questions.solution:
Option B: Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same reaction

  • Isozymes/Isoenzymes are different forms of the same enzyme, catalyzing the same reaction in the same species.
  • For example, there are five isozymes of Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH-1 to LDH-5); all convert Pyruvate to Lactate.
  • So, the reaction and species will always be the same for isoenzymes.

Option A and C: Refer to explanation of B

Option D: Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze the same reaction

  • If two enzymes are from two different species, they are different but can still catalyze the same reaction in their respective species.
  • The term used for such enzymes is Allozyme and not isoenzymes
  • For example, DNA polymerase from different species has different structures but the same function as DNA polymerization by phosphodiester bonds.
  • Isoenzymes may be present in the same/different tissues but never in two different species.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female comes to the outdoor patient department complaining of lethargy, headache, and inability to concentrate. On investigation, her serum ammonia levels are high. After detailed laboratory investigations, a probable diagnosis of Urea cycle disorder is made. Which of the following drugs can be used to reduce ammonia levels in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Phenylbutyrate

  • Phenylbutyrate (PB) and sodium benzoate are ammonia scavenging agents used to treat urea cycle disorders.
  • It is available as glycerol phenylbutyrate, which is metabolized by ester hydrolysis and pancreatic lipases into phenylbutyrate.
  • Phenylbutyrate is then converted to phenylacetate by beta-oxidation.
  • PA is then conjugated with Glutamine, and the phenyl acetyl glutamine is excreted in the urine, disposing of two waste nitrogen molecules.
  • Nitrogen disposal by benzoate occurs via conjugation with glycine to form hippurate, which disposes of one molecule of waste nitrogen.
  • For 1 gram of sodium phenylbutyrate administered, nearly 0.15 grams of phenyl acetyl glutamine is produced.

Option A: Acetaminophen

  • Acetaminophen has analgesic and antipyretic role.
  • It acts on the hypothalamus to lower the body temperature, act peripherally to stop the pain impulse generation, and inhibit prostaglandin synthesis in the central nervous system.
  • It has no role in decreasing serum ammonia levels.

Option B: Carnitine analog

  • Carnitine analog is a quaternary ammonium compound in all tissues, particularly striated muscles.
  • It has a vital role in lipid catabolism and is essential for the normal transportation of FFA from the cytosol to mitochondria for their oxidation.
  • It has no role in the urea cycle.

Option D: Isoleucine

  • It is a nonpolar uncharged amino acid and a building block of various proteins.
  • It plays a role in wound healing, immunity, and blood sugar control.
  • In maple syrup urine disease, its metabolism gets affected due to enzyme deficiency.
  • It has no role in urea cycle disorders

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with elevated cholesterol levels of 325 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father consistently had high levels of cholesterol throughout his life and eventually died of a heart attack at the age of 42. He was prescribed lovastatin, and his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL. The most likely reason for the elevated cholesterol in this patient is due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Option D: LDL receptor

  • The patient's condition suggests that it might be a case of Familial hypercholesterolemia, which is either due to a defect in the LDL receptor present in the liver or defective Apo B100 protein present on LDL.
  • It is a genetically heritable disease passed in an autosomal dominant fashion in the family.
  • The condition leads to high levels of cholesterol in the blood of the patient leading to atherosclerosis and other cardiovascular diseases at a very young age.
  • The LDL receptor is required for liver uptake of LDL and further processing of the endogenous cholesterol, while apo B100 protein present on LDL acts as a legend for this receptor and helps in engulfment of LDL in the liver.
  • A defect in either of these results in the inability to clear excess endogenous cholesterol and leads to its accumulation in the blood vessels hence increasing the

Option A: Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein

  • Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein deficiency causes abetalipoproteinemia (ABL).
  • ABL is a rare autosomal recessive disorder which is characterized by the secretion of plasma apolipoprotein.

Option B: Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT)

  • Mutation in the LCAT gene causes Norum's and fish-eye disease.
  • It also causes hemolytic anemia and kidney failure.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase

  • The LPL gene gives instructions to produce the LPL enzyme.
  • Gene mutation in lipoprotein lipase cause familial LPL.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency day after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He has multiple lacerations to his upper extremities and sustained an open fracture to his lower extremity. Initial CBC reveals white blood cells count at 22 x 103 /µl, and subsequent complete blood count analysis after 5 hours reveals the white blood cells count at 7 x 103 /µl. Which of the following is the reason for the increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report?

choices.text: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow
Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.solution:
Option B: Release pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

  • A traumatic physical event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.
  • The increase in the given case may not be due to any inflammatory response, but instead, the increase is due to mechanical trauma and associated stress responses.
  • Stress causes an overproduction of white blood cells, which defend the body against diseases but can cause problems when produced in excess.
  • These extra cells can stick to artery walls, causing restrictions in blood flow and aiding the formation of clots that can cause blood-vessel blockages throughout the body.
  • When stimulation, like an increased level of cytokines, these stored WBCs are released into circulation.
  • But still, a physically traumatic event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.

Option A: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow

  • Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow defends your body against infections and disease. But, when too many white blood cells, it usually means you have an infection or inflammation in your body. Less commonly, a high white blood cell count could indicate certain blood cancers or bone marrow disorders.

Option C: Decreased destruction of WBCs

  • Decreased destruction of WBCs is usually caused by: Viral infections that temporarily disrupt the work of bone marrow.

Option D: Increased production of selectins

  • The selectins are physiologically important in inflammation, lymphocyte homing, immunological responses, and homing of bone marrow stem cells. They play a role in atherosclerosis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, inflammatory diseases, and the metastatic spreading of some cancers.

questions.text: The absorption of different substances occurs through different transport processes. The transporter that carries glucose and galactose into the enterocyte is the sodium-dependent hexose transporter, known more formally as SGLUT-1. Which of the following methods aids in Glucose absorption from the gut?
questions.solution:
Option D: Secondary active transport

  • Glucose absorption from the gut occurs as co-transport (secondary active transport) with Na+ via transporter SGLT-1 (sodium-glucose transporter).
  • SGLT1 mediates almost all sodium-dependent glucose uptake in the small intestine.
  • All SGLT proteins have 14 transmembrane helices in topology.
  • SGLT1 is the prime intestinal glucose transporter unequivocally, even at high luminal glucose concentrations.
  • This mechanism determines the rate of glucose entry into the bloodstream under both low and high carbohydrate loads in the gut.
  • SGLT1 mediates glucose-induced incretin secretion.

Option A: Simple diffusion

  • It is the process in which solutes are passed through the concentration gradient in a solution across a semipermeable membrane.
  • The assistance of membrane proteins is not required in this diffusion process wherein substances move from higher concentration to lower.
  • Due to its polar nature and large size, glucose molecules cannot traverse the cell's lipid membrane by simple diffusion.
  • After digestion, a few monosaccharides diffuse into the blood based on the concentration gradient. Example: Glucose, amino acids and ions like chloride.
  • Simple diffusion does not require energy:

Option B: Facilitated diffusion

  • Glucose exits the cell to the bloodstream via GLUT -2 (facilitated diffusion).
  • In facilitated diffusion, molecules diffuse across the plasma membrane with assistance from membrane proteins, such as channels and carriers.
  • A concentration gradient exists for these molecules, so they have the potential to diffuse into (or out of) the cell by moving down it.
  • Facilitated diffusion requires a source of ATP.

Option C: Primary active transport

  • Primary active transport, also called direct active transport, directly uses chemical energy (such as from adenosine triphosphate or ATP in the case of the cell membrane) to transport all species of solutes across a membrane against their concentration gradient.
  • In primary active transport, the energy is derived directly from the breakdown of ATP.
  • Primary active transport moves ions across a membrane and creates a difference in charge across that membrane.
  • The cells along the small intestine use primary active transport to ensure that glucose only flows one way: From digested food to the inside of the cells.
  • The sodium-potassium pump is an example of an active transport pump.

questions.text: Where in the gastrointestinal tract does the majority of iron absorption occur?
questions.solution:
Option B: Duodenum

  • Almost all iron absorption occurs in the duodenum.
  • The duodenum is the first part of the small intestine.
  • It is located between the stomach and the middle of the small intestine, or jejunum.
  • After foods mix with stomach acid, they move into the duodenum, where they mix with bile from the gallbladder and digestive juices from the pancreas.

Option A: Stomach

  • Absorption of iron occurs in the duodenum and upper jejunum and depends on specific carrier mechanisms.
  • The transporter protein Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1), located on the apical surface of enterocytes, facilitates the uptake of non-haem ferrous iron (Fe2+) from the intestinal lumen.

Option C: Jejunum

  • The absorption of most dietary iron occurs in the duodenum and proximal jejunum.
  • The middle part of the small intestine.
  •  It is between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and the ileum (the last part of the small intestine).
  • The jejunum helps to further digest food coming from the stomach.

Option D: Ileum

  • Almost all iron absorption occurs in the duodenum.
  • The last part of the small intestine. It connects to the cecum (the first part of the large intestine).
  • The ileum helps further digest food from the stomach and other parts of the small intestine.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating how folic acid is metabolized in the body. It is an essential and water-soluble vitamin in leafy green vegetables. It is absorbed in the proximal jejunum by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Option D: Both active & passive transport

  • In the diet, folates exist as polyglutamate and must be enzymatically converted into folate monoglutamates.
  • Folate reductase in the mucosa of the jejunum in the small intestine converts the polyglutamate form to the monoglutamate form of the folate, which is absorbed in the proximal jejunum via both active and passive transport.
  • Folic acid is absorbed two-fold better than folates. Natural food folates are quite unstable compounds, so loss in vitamin activity can be expected during food processing.
  • Folate or folic acid is not per se biologically active but is converted into dihydrofolate (by the enzyme dihydrofolate synthetase) in the liver and into tetrahydrofolate by dihydrofolate reductase; the anti-metabolite methotrexate inhibits this reaction.

Option A: Facilitated diffusion

  • Glucose and amino acids are transported by facilitated diffusion. Facilitated or carrier-mediated diffusion is the type of diffusion by which the water-soluble substances having larger molecules are transported through the cell membrane with the help of a carrier protein.

Option B: Active transport

  • Substances, which are transported actively, are in ionic form and nonionic form. Substances in the ionic form are sodium, potassium, calcium, hydrogen, chloride, and iodide. Substances in the nonionic form are glucose, amino acids, and urea.

Option C: Passive transport

  • Passive transport is the transport of substances along the concentration gradient, electrical gradient, or both (electrochemical gradient). It is also known as diffusion or downhill movement. It does not need energy.

questions.text: How does the implanted pacemaker address the underlying mechanism associated with intermittent shortness of breath, palpitations, sinus bradycardia, and sinus pauses in a patient experiencing lightheadedness?

choices.text: By generating a If (funny current) induced fast depolarisation
An inward calcium current through T-channels
An inward calcium current through L-channels

questions.solution:
Option C: An inward calcium current through T-channels

  • This is a case of sick sinus syndrome in which the patient presents with shortness of breath and palpitations.
  • This syndrome is caused due to sinus node dysfunction resulting from age-related degeneration and fibrosis.
  • The management of this case includes the implantation of a pacemaker.
  • The influx of calcium (through the T channel) results in prepotential or pacemaker potential formation.
  • The decreasing potassium efflux during late repolarisation cannot oppose the depolarising effect of sodium (through funny channels) and calcium (through T channel) influx which results in prepotential or pacemaker potential formation.

Option A: A hyperpolarisation-induced outward current

  • A hyperpolarisation-induced inward current is mainly caused by sodium influx through funny channels or HCN channels (activated by hyperpolarisation and gated by cyclic nucleotide).

Option B:  Increasing outward potassium current

  • The decreasing potassium efflux during late repolarisation cannot oppose sodium's depolarising effect (through funny channels).

Option D: An inward calcium current through L-channels

  • An inward Ca++ current through a transient (T) channel.

questions.text: Which of the following organs have the maximum blood flow per 100 gm per min?
questions.solution:
Option C: Kidney

  • The kidneys have the highest blood flow (100ml/100 gm of tissue/min.).
  • However, the Carotid body receives 2000 ml/100 gm of tissue/min., the highest for any tissue in the body.
  • Renal blood flow:
    • The blood volume flows through the kidney per unit of time.
  • Usually, the renal regulatory mechanism keeps 20% of cardiac output, i.e., 1.2L/min, at a constant rate.
  • It means the perfusion rate per tissue mass of the kidney exceeds that of any other organ.
  • RBF = RPF/(1- Hct)
  • Renal plasma flow (RPF):
    • The volume of plasma that flows through the kidney per unit of time.
    • The RPF has more clinical relevance than RBF because only the plasma components can pass through the glomerular filtration barrier.

Option A: Brain

  • It has the highest perfusion rate.
  • It comprises 2% body weight and receives 15-20% of total cardiac output.
  • So, the brain is one of the most highly perfused organs in the body.

Option B: Heart

  • The highest arterio-venous O2 difference is seen in the heart.
  • It is the least in the kidneys.
  • The heart has maximum cardiac output.

Option D: Liver

  • The liver has the highest blood flow (ml/min).
  • It has the greatest amount of blood pumped per minute in each circulation.

questions.text: Calculate the end-diastolic volume in a patient whose ejection fraction of 0.4, a heart rate of 95 bpm, and a cardiac output of 3.5 L/min.
questions.solution:
• Stroke Volume from the cardiac output and heart rate to be calculated first.
  • Cardiac Output (CO) = Stroke Volume (SV) × Heart Rate (HR).
  • Thus, stroke volume = cardiac output/ heart rate = 3500 mL/95 beats/min = 36.8 mL.
  • End-diastolic volume from stroke volume and ejection fraction is then calculated.
  • Ejection Fraction (EF) = Stroke Volume (SV)/ End-Diastolic Volume (EDV).
  • Thus end-diastolic volume = stroke volume/ejection fraction = 36.8 mL/0.4 = 92 mL.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is coronary blood flow at its maximum?
questions.solution:
Option A: Isovolumic relaxation phase

  • Based on the symptoms and the findings from CT angiography, the patient is likely suffering from ischemic stroke.
  • Ischemic stroke is the most frequent type of stroke. It occurs when a blood clot narrows an artery leading to the brain. A blood clot usually forms in the arteries damaged by the buildup of plaques called atherosclerosis. It can occur in the carotid artery of the neck as well as other arteries.
  • Maximum coronary blood flow occurs during the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase.
  • Isovolumetric/isometric relaxation time/IVRT:
    • Duration in the cardiac cycle, from the aortic component of the second heart sound, that is, the closure of the aortic valve, to the onset of filling by the opening of the mitral valve.
    • Ventricular pressure decreases to zero rapidly while aortic pressure decreases only to 80 mm Hg, i.e. it remains fairly high.
    • Therefore, intramyocardial compression of blood vessels is minimal, and perfusion pressure is maintained fairly high. So coronary blood flow rises sharply.
    • Maximum coronary blood flow occurs during this phase.
    • It can be used as an indicator of diastolic dysfunction. Prolonged IVRT indicates poor myocardial relaxation.
    • A normal IVRT is about 70 ± 12 ms and approximately 10ms longer in people over forty years.- In abnormal relaxation, IVRT is usually more than 110ms.
    • With a restrictive ventricular filling, it is usually under 60 ms.

Option B: Isovolumic contraction phase

  • Isometric contraction occurs in early systole, during which the ventricles contract with no corresponding volume change. This short-lasting portion of the cardiac cycle occurs while all heart valves are closed.

Option C: Ejection phase

  • This phase begins when the intraventricular pressures exceed the pressures within the aorta and pulmonary artery. Blood is ejected because the total energy of the blood within the ventricle increases from the total energy of blood within the aorta.

Option D: None of the Above

  • Maximum coronary blood flow is seen during the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase.

questions.text: An investigator is developing a drug. He develops a new drug that decreases the number of voltage-gated potassium channels in cardiac muscle cell membranes. As a result, less potassium outflux will occur in the myocardium in response to the mechanism of action of this drug. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug on the myocardial action potential?
questions.solution:
Option D: Delayed repolarization

  • A decreased number of voltage-gated K+ channels results in a decreased K+ outflow.
  • Repolarizing the cardiac myocyte depends on the efflux of K+ from the cell.
  • Once the action potential peak (∼ +30 mV) is reached, voltage-gated K+ channels will open, causing the cell membrane potential to repolarize towards the resting potential of K+ (∼ -70 mV to -90 mV).
  • Blockade of voltage-gated K+ channels will therefore delay repolarization.

Option A: Depolarization

  • The depolarization, also called the rising phase, is caused when positively charged sodium ions (Na+) suddenly rush through open voltage-gated sodium channels into a neuron.
  • As additional sodium rushes in, the membrane potential reverses its polarity. During this polarity change, the membrane develops a positive value for a moment (+40 millivolts).

Option B: Repolarization

  • The repolarization or falling phase is caused by the slow closing of sodium channels and the opening of voltage-gated potassium channels.

Option C: Hyperpolarization

  • Hyperpolarization is a phase where some potassium channels remain open and sodium channels reset.

questions.text: In a physiology seminar, a group of medical students gives a presentation on renal physiology. They elaborate on the process of filtration and reabsorption. Filtration is the mass movement of water and solutes from plasma to the renal tubule that occurs in the renal corpuscle. About 20% of the plasma volume passing through the glomerulus at any given time is filtered. This means that the kidneys filter about 180 liters of fluid daily. Thus, the entire plasma volume (about 3 liters) is filtered 60 times daily. A substance is present in a concentration of 2 mg% in the afferent arteriole and 0 mg% in the efferent. A true statement about the substance is?

choices.text: It is freely filtered at the glomerulus
Impermeable in the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Option A: It is freely filtered at the glomerulus

  • This is only a hypothetical situation. The filtration fraction is about 20%. It means that of the total plasma passing through the glomerulus per unit of time, about 20% is filtered out. Suppose a substance has zero concentration in the efferent arteriole. In that case, it means all that substance was freely and completely filtered out in the plasma that formed the glomerular filtrate.

Option B: Secreted in the cortical nephron

  • A substance is secreted in the nephrons after the filtration in glomeruli. This substance has a 0mg% concentration left in the plasma. Hence it cannot be secreted further.

Option C: Absorbed in the PCT

  • The concentration of 0mg% in the efferent arteriole represents free filtration of a substance.
  • Reabsorbed substances would lead to increased concentration in peritubular capillaries (not in efferent arteriole)

Option D: Impermeable in the loop of Henle

  • If a substance is impermeable in the loop of Henle, it cannot be reabsorbed.

  • However, a concentration of 0mg% in efferent arteriole represents that it is freely filtered.

  • It does not give information about the permeability of the loop of Henle

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hypocalcemia?

choices.text: Numbness and tingling of circumoral region
Hyperactive tendon reflexes and positive Chvostek's sign
Shortening of Q-T interval in ECG

questions.solution:
Option C: Shortening of Q-T interval in ECG

  • ECG changes the Prolongation of the ST segment and, consequently, QT interval; not shortening.
  • Reason: Low serum Ca++ decreases K+ permeability, lengthens phase 2 (plateau) of the AP, and slows the rate of repolarisation, thereby prolonging the Q-T interval.

Option A: Numbness and tingling of circumoral region

  • There are tingling and numbness of the extremities; in the circumoral region, it may be a rare manifestation of Hypocalcemia.

Option B: Hyperactive tendon reflexes and positive Chvostek's sign

  • Chvostek’s sign: Tapping of facial nerve over the angle of mandible causes unilateral spasm of facial muscles due to low serum calcium levels.
  • Hyperactive tendon reflexes due to low serum calcium levels.

Option D: Carpopedal spasm

  • Plasma Ca++ stabilises membrane potentials. Hence, Hypocalcemia may lead to various manifestations of increased membrane excitability.
  • For nerves and muscles, their threshold comes closer to RMP. Spontaneous action potentials are fired in the nerves. The hyperirritability of the motor nerves and the innervated muscles leads to the symptoms of “tetany”.

questions.text: During the menstrual cycle, which of the following is the main source of estrogen?
questions.solution:
Option B: Developing follicles

  • In the nonpregnant female, the only significant source of estrogen is ovarian follicles.
  • Menstruation begins when the corpus luteum degenerates.
  • The development of the follicles is stimulated by the pituitary gland's production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • Ripening the follicles then increases estrogen levels, as estrogen is secreted by follicular cells.
  • Menstruation ends when developing follicles secrete estrogen sufficiently to raise circulating concentration to a level that stimulates regrowth of the endometrium.

Option A: Corpus luteum

  • Corpus luteum is the main source of progesterone.
  • It does produce estrogen but in a very small amount.

Option C: Endometrium

  • Endometrium is not the source of a rapid rise in the level of estrogen hormone.
  • Rather, estrogen can act in the endometrium by interacting with estrogen receptors (ERs) to induce mucosal proliferation during the proliferative phase and progesterone receptor (PR) synthesis, which prepare the endometrium for the secretory phase.

Option D: Stromal cells of the ovaries

  • Ovarian stromal cells are hypothesized to have significant roles in the activation of primordial follicles and the recruitment/differentiation of theca cells.
  • Most follicle culture systems focus on secondary or multilayer follicles and produce antral follicles with fertilizable oocytes.
  • But these cells are not involved in the rapid rise of estrogen during menstruation.

questions.text: Baricitinib is used for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following is true about this drug?

choices.text: Also approved for use in moderate to severe Crohn’s disease
Dose reduction is not required in renal and hepatic impairment.

questions.solution:
Option A: Oral JAK inhibitor

  • All these are symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, and baricitinib is used to treat RA. Baricitinib is an oral JAK inhinitor.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, or RA, is an autoimmune and inflammatory disease.
  • In which your immune system attacks healthy cells in your body by mistake, causing inflammation (painful swelling) in the affected parts of the body.
  • RA mainly attacks the joints, usually many joints at once.
  • Signs and symptoms of RA include:
  • Pain or aching in more than one joint
  • Stiffness in more than one joint
  • Tenderness and swelling in more than one joint
  • The same symptoms on both sides of the body (such as in both hands or both knees)
  • Weight loss
  • Fever
  • Fatigue or tiredness
  • Weakness
  • Baricitinib and tofacitinib are oral JANUS kinase inhibitors (JAK).
  • These drugs are used in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Tofacitinib is also used in ulcerative colitis.
  • Major side-effects of these drugs are:
  • Increased risk of infection: TB, herpes zoster
  • Increased risk of malignancy like lymphoma
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • They require dose reduction in kidney and liver failure.
  • So, they are avoided in lymphopenia and anaemia.

Option B: Approved for use in moderate to severe Crohn’s disease

  • Baricitinib is not used in Crohn's disease
  • Tofacitinib is also used in ulcerative colitis.
  • Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
  • It causes swelling of the tissues (inflammation) in your digestive tract, which can lead to abdominal pain, severe diarrhoea, fatigue, weight loss and malnutrition.

Option C: Decreases triglycerides

  • Baricitinib inhibits the JAK proteins.
  • So it prevents phosphorylation and activation of STATs and modulates the signalling pathway of various interleukins, interferons, and growth factors.
  • Baricitinib also decreases the proliferation of JAK1/JAK2 expression in mutated cells and induces cell apoptosis.
  • It increases triglycerides.

Option D: Dose reduction is not required in renal and hepatic impairment

  • As baricitinib is mainly excreted via the kidneys.
  • In patients with moderate renal impairment with glomerular filtration rate (GFR) between 30 to 60 mL/minute /1.73 m2, the dose should be reduced to 1 mg daily.
  • The drug is not recommended for patients with GFR less than 30 mL/minute /1.73 m2.
  • Dose reduction is required for renal and hepatic impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following is an Incorrect example of antimicrobial drug synergism?

choices.text: Amphotericin B and flucytosine in cryptococcal meningitis
Carbenicillin and gentamicin in pseudomonal infections
Penicillin and tetracycline in bacterial meningitis
Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole in coliform infections

questions.solution:
Option C: Penicillin and tetracycline in bacterial meningitis

  • In most cases, a combination of a bacteriostatic and a bactericidal drug is antagonistic.
  • Bactericidal drugs act on fast-multiplying organisms, whereas bacteriostatic drugs inhibit the growth of the organism
  • Here, penicillins are bactericidal, whereas tetracyclines are bacteriostatic. The tetracyclines can antagonize the action of bactericidal Penicillin
  • Synergism is basically that both drugs produce a combined effect that is greater than their individual effects

Option A: Amphotericin B and flucytosine in cryptococcal meningitis

  • The combined effect of these two drugs is great than their mono effect, which is why this is an example of drug synergy

Option B: Carbenicillin and gentamicin in pseudomonal infections

  • Carbenicillin and gentamicin are both used together in pseudomonal infections because their combined effect is clinically more significant than their mono effect, so this is an example of drug synergy

Option D: Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole in coliform infections

  • TMP-SMX is the combination used because both the drugs are agonists to each other, and their combined effect is greater

questions.text: A pregnant female presents to you after coming in contact with a family member who has been admitted for Meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following drugs will you give for Prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ceftriaxone

Persons requiring antimicrobial Prophylaxis following Neisseria meningitidis exposure
  • Household members
  • Roommates or intimate contacts
  • Childcare centre workers
  • Persons directly exposed to respiratory or oral secretions (kissing, mouth-mouth resuscitation, endotracheal intubation/management)
  • Persons seated next to an affected person for > 8 hours (airline travellers)
  • Ciprofloxacin is usually used in a single oral dose, but it should not be prescribed during pregnancy or for anyone under 18.
  • Ceftriaxone can be administered intravenously once intramuscularly during pregnancy and in any age group. However, it has sometimes been reported that isolates have reduced sensitivity to Ceftriaxone.
  • It is recommended that antibiotic chemoprophylaxis be taken between the patient and close contact with invasive meningococcal infection to prevent secondary cases
  • Due to the high risk of side effects, the emergence of drug resistance, and the need to adhere to four doses, Rifampicin is now not commonly used.
  • So the drug of choice for the treatment of Meningococcal meningitis is Ceftriaxone
  • For Prophylaxis, the drug of choice is ciprofloxacin
  • The drug of choice for Prophylaxis in pregnant and <18 year individuals is Ceftriaxone

Option A: Ciprofloxacin

  • Ciprofloxacin is not used in pregnancy as it can cause fetal skeletal and muscle growth defects. That is why it is also not used in the <18 age group of patients

Option C: Cefalexin

  • Cefalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin, and it is not as effective as Ceftriaxone which is a third-generation cephalosporin

Option D: Rifabutin

  • Rifabutin is no longer recommended due to resistance by the Neisseria meningitis that causes the  meningococcal meningitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a potential adverse effect of fluoroquinolones?
questions.solution:
Option D: Blindness

  • Fluoroquinolones do not affect vision.
  • Their use is not associated with blindness.
  • Drugs that can cause blindness include:
    • Ethambutol
    • Isotretinoin
    • Alendronate
    • Chlorpromazine

Option A: Abdominal discomfort

  • Fluoroquinolone use is associated with abdominal discomfort.
  • They affect the gastrointestinal system.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Nausea
    • Vomiting
    • Diarrhoea

Option B: Hypoglycemia

  • Fluoroquinolones affect glucose metabolism in the body.
  • Their use is associated with dysglycemic changes.
  • Hypoglycemia is a known adverse effect of fluoroquinolones.

Option C: QT prolongation

  • Fluoroquinolones can prolong the relaxation phase of the myocardium.
  • This leads to a long QT interval.
  • Their use in genetically susceptible individuals can lead to ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fluconazole is most accurate?

choices.text: It is highly effective in the treatment of aspergillosis
It does not penetrate the blood-brain barrier
It is associated with an increased incidence of adverse events compared to Ketoconazole.
It inhibits the demethylation of lanosterol

questions.solution:
Option D: It inhibits the demethylation of lanosterol

  • Fluconazole inhibits fungal sterol (ergosterol) synthesis by inhibiting the cytochrome P-450 enzyme that converts lanosterol to ergosterol
  • Azoles- Clinical Uses:
    • Local and less serious systemic mycoses.
    • Fluconazole for chronic suppression of cryptococcal meningitis in people living with HIV and candidal infections of all types.
    • Itraconazole may be used for Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Histoplasma, Sporothrix schenckii.
    • Clotrimazole and miconazole for topical fungal infections.
    • Voriconazole for Aspergillus and some Candida.
    • Isavuconazole for serious Aspergillus and Mucor infections
  • Adverse effects:
    • Testosterone synthesis inhibition (gynecomastia, especially with Ketoconazole)
    • Liver dysfunction (inhibits cytochrome P-450)
    • QT interval prolongation

Option A: It is highly effective in the treatment of aspergillosis

  • Fluconazole is more effective against cryptococcal injections.
  • Voriconazole and Isavuconazole are effective against aspergillus

Option B: It does not penetrate the blood-brain barrier

  • Fluconazole can penetrate CNS.
  • That's why it is used against cryptococcal meningitis

Option C: Its oral bioavailability is less than that of Ketoconazole

  • For gastrointestinal absorption, fluconazole does not require an acidic environment like Ketoconazole.
  • About 80 to 90% of an orally administered dose is absorbed, yielding high serum drug levels

questions.text: Which antimalarial agent is most commonly associated with acute hemolytic reaction in patients with glucose-6- phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option D: Primaquine

  • Primaquine can cause hemolytic anaemia in patients with even mild deficiency of G-6-PDdue to its oxidative properties.
  • Symptoms include passage of dark-coloured urine, Jaundice, fever and weakness, which indicate hemolysis and the drug must be stopped.
  • Quinine, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can also cause hemolysis in G-6-PD deficient patients, but the frequency is less than that of primaquine.
  • The drugs that are safe to use in G6PD are  halofantrine, artemisinin derivatives, proguanil, atovaquone​​​​​​​

Option A: Chloroquine

  • Chloroquine has a possible risk of hemolysis in G6PD patients but has less risk than that primaquine

Option B: Clindamycin

  • Clindamycin is antibiotic and is safe to use in G6PD patients

Option C: Mefloquine

  • Mefloquine has a risk of hemolysis in patients with G6PD but is less than that primaquine

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with multiple joint pains and morning stiffness lasting for an hour. He has been prescribed aspirin for pain alleviation. Which of the following statements is true about aspirin?

choices.text: In an afebrile patient acute overdose of aspirin produces hypothermia
Aspirin suppresses flushing associated with a large dose of nicotinic acid
Aspirin therapy prevents granulomatous lesions and cardiac complications of acute rheumatic fever
Long-term aspirin therapy increases the risk of developing colon cancer

questions.solution:
Option B: Aspirin suppresses flushing associated with a large dose of nicotinic acid

  • Roles of aspirin:
    • Niacin induces flushing through dermal Langerhans cells, where the activation of G protein-coupled receptors increases arachidonic acid and prostaglandins, such as prostaglandin D2, prostaglandin E2 leading to activation of prostaglandin D2, E2, and E4 receptors in the capillaries resulting in vasodilatation.
    • This is by preventing the prostaglandin formation, blocking the PG receptors or regulating the rate of niacin absorption.
    • Nicotinic acid can cause flushing due to the release of Prostaglandins. This premedication with aspirin decreases this complication.
    • Therefore, aspirin is used to prevent flushing due to nicotinic ingestion
    • Aspirin can cause hyperthermia in overdose. It decreases the risk of developing colon cancer.

Option A: In an afebrile patient, an acute overdose of aspirin produces hypothermia

  • Aspirin's direct results affect the respiratory centre causing hyperventilation. As a result, higher anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs due to the body's reaction to hyperventilation (due to kidneys producing more bicarbonate and eliminating more potassium). The acidosis and inhibition of the Krebs cycle build up lactate and pyruvate, causing the suppression and decoupling of oxidative phosphorylation. This will result in more heat being produced and hyperthermia.

Option C: Aspirin therapy prevents granulomatous lesions and cardiac complications of acute rheumatic fever

  • It does not prevent or alter disease duration in granulomatous lesions, nodules, cardiac complications, valvular defects or chorea.

Option D: Long-term aspirin therapy increases the risk of developing colon cancer

  • It is used in patients with familial colonic polyposis to suppress polyp formation and afford symptomatic relief.
  • It prevents colon cancer. This is because the incidence of colon cancer among regular aspirin users is much lower.
  • COX-2 overexpression is associated with cancer progression. Aspirin causes inhibition of the COX-2 enzyme and thus provides anti-cancer effects.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with diplopia, slurred speech, breathing difficulty, drooping eyelids, and fatigue for 2 weeks, worsening progressively throughout the day and improving with rest. No other abnormalities or chronic illnesses reported. Vital signs stable, with no other physical abnormalities. Doctor prescribed neostigmine over physostigmine. What justifies this drug preference?

choices.text: It has a longer duration of action
It doesn't cross BBB effectively and has no central action

questions.solution:
Option C: It has additional direct agonistic action on nicotinic receptors at the muscle end plate

  • This is a case of myasthenia gravis in which the patient presents with complaints of diplopia, slurred speech, difficulty in breathing, drooping of eyelids and generalised fatigue for 2 weeks.
  • The patient further gives a history that his symptoms worsened progressively through the day, and he comparatively feels better with rest. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • All these symptoms suggest myasthenia gravis.
  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease which weakens the muscles. The symptoms of this disease usually appear after periods of activity and improve on rest.
  • The doctor prescribed neostigmine to the patient for the treatment of myasthenia gravis.
  • The doctor preferred neostigmine over physostigmine because neostigmine has additional direct agonistic action on nicotinic receptors at the muscle end plate.

Option A: It is better absorbed orally

  • Neostigmine is not preferred over physostigmine in the treatment of myasthenia gravis because of better absorption orally.
  • Actually, physostigmine has better GIT absorption than neostigmine.

Option B: It has a longer duration of action

  • The duration of physostigmine is longer than the neostigmine.
  • So, we can’t choose this option.

Option D: It penetrates the blood-brain barrier

  • Neostigmine and physostigmine both penetrate the blood-brain barrier.
  • In fact, the penetration of the blood-brain barrier of neostigmine is less than physostigmine.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A young 22-year-old male presents in an outpatient clinic with the complaint of cough and difficulty breathing while lying down; He was stung by a scorpion while camping. He is diagnosed with hypertension and pulmonary edema due to a scorpion sting. This patient can be best managed by?
questions.solution:
Option B: Prazosin

  • The patient in the above case has most likely suffered a scorpion sting.
  • Scorpion stings cause excessive stimulation of alpha-1 receptors.
  • Of the above-mentioned drugs, Prazosin acts by blocking alpha-1 receptors.
  • Therefore drug of choice for a Scorpion sting is Prazosin.
  • They are sympatholytic drugs.
  • They inhibit the production or release of catecholamines (norepinephrine), ultimately inhibiting the activity of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • They are also used for treating hypertension (as the second line) in combination regimens.
  • Common side effects include orthostatic hypotension, dizziness, headache and priapism.

Option A: Carvedilol

  • Carvedilol is a non-selective β-antagonist that also blocks alpha adrenoreceptors, but it is not a drug of choice in case of a scorpion sting.

Option C: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone is a direct antagonist of aldosterone, thereby preventing salt retention, myocardial hypertrophy and Hypokalemia.

Option D: Phentolamine

  • Phentolamine produces a competitive block of alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors but is not an appropriate choice in the case of scorpion sting since it only needs an alpha1 receptor blocking agent.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of headaches for the past four months. Resting blood pressure is measured at 164/100 mmHg while sitting. From the following, which anti-hypertensive agents must be recommended based on the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hydralazine

  • Hydralazine is a vasodilator and is used to treat blood pressure.
  • It works by relaxing vascular smooth muscles and decreasing peripheral resistance so that blood can flow easily through the body. Hence, lowering the blood pressure and decreasing afterload.
  • Many people using hydralazine do not have serious side effects and rarely cause nerve problems.
  • Even pregnant women can take this medication with clear instructions.
  • It usually starts affecting around 15 minutes and lasts up to six hours.

Option B: Phenytoin

  • It is used to treat and prevent seizures.
  • It can also be used to control irregular heartbeat. 
  • Adverse side effects include:
    • Difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep
    • Uncontrollable eye movements
    • Abnormal body movements
    • Loss of coordination
    • Confusion
  • This drug also causes Hirsutism.

Option C: Minoxidil

  • It is a potent vasodilator.
  • The active metabolite of minoxidil is an opener of ATP-sensitive K channels; it causes vasodilatation by hyperpolarising smooth muscle.
  • Minoxidil is avoided in young females because it causes Hirsutism.
  • Hirsutism is observed as a side effect of oral minoxidil. If applied topically, it promotes hair growth in male pattern baldness and alopecia areata.

 

Option D: Cyclosporine

  • Females who are taking cyclosporine might experience cramps and painful periods.
  • Adverse side effects include:
    • Numbness of the hands or feet
    • Swollen gums
    • High blood pressure 
    • Hirsutism

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents in the outdoor department with a complaint of headache and anxiety for two days. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg with other vitals in the normal range. He is a non-compliant hypertensive and has been on metoprolol therapy for the last two years. His echocardiogram shows mild mitral regurgitation with an ejection fraction of 47%. The intern wants to initiate verapamil as a second anti-hypertensive but is told by the consultant to review his prescription. Which of the following is likely to happen with the above combination therapy?
questions.solution:
Option D: Bradycardia with AV block

  • The patient is a non-complaint hypertensive and has developed cardiac failure because he has headaches and anxiety due to a decrease in cerebral blood flow. He is already on metoprolol. The ejection fraction is also markedly low, and the echocardiogram also demonstrates a finding of mild mitral regurgitation.
  • Metoprolol is a beta blocker, and it decreases conduction by depressing the heart.
  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker, and it also depresses the heart.
  • Beta-blockers should not be combined with any non-dihydropyridine calcium blockers like verapamil or diltiazem.
  • Negative chronotropic effects of both these drugs can result in heart block or bradycardia.

Option A: Torsades de pointes

  • Torsades de pointes is more linked to magnesium and potassium electrolyte deficiency.
  • Beta-blockers are used in the management of this disease.

Option B: Ventricular tachycardia

  • Both these agents result in a decrease in heart rate.
  • Dihydropyridines are, however, known to cause reflex tachycardia.

Option C: Ventricular fibrillation

  • Beta-blockers are associated with improved survival in patients who has ventricular fibrillation.
  • Both of these drugs are not the causative aetiology of ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old schizophrenic male, currently under the treatment of Haloperidol, presented with Parkinsonism-like symptoms. Which of the following would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Option C: Benzhexol

  • Benzhexol is used to reduce tremors, muscle stiffness and movement problems that are associated with Parkinson's disease
  • It is also used to lessen side effects that are caused by some medications used to treat mental conditions

Option A: Levodopa

  • Parkinson's can be treated with Levodopa, which boosts dopamine levels; schizophrenia is often treated with drugs that block the activity of dopamine
  • So Levodopa should not be used to treat Parkinsonism-like symptoms in patients who are diagnosed cases of schizophrenia

Option B: Benserazide

  • Benserazide allows more of the Levodopa you take to get into your brain before it is changed into dopamine
  • This medication block the dopamine receptors in nerve cells
  • The resulting reduction in dopamine levels causes Parkinsonism
  • Typically, when someone stops taking these medications, the symptoms of parkinsonism decrease over time

Option D: Selegiline

  • Selegiline is used in combination with levodopa or levodopa and carbidopa combination to treat Parkinson's disease
  • This medicine works to increase and extend the effects of Levodopa
  • It may help to slow the progress of Parkinson's disease

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor performance in school for the last year. He has difficulty sitting at his desk, does not follow the teacher's instructions, and frequently blurts out answers in class. He is often sent outside the classroom for failing to work quietly. He also has a history of inattentive spells when talking to his friends. He does not wait for his turn at hockey practice and has difficulty listening to his coach's instructions. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks to him and often forgets his books at home. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D : Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

This child has symptoms of hyperactivity, inattention spells, and impulsivity most likely suggests attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Symptoms of ADHD:

  • Inattention
  • Hyperactivity
  • Impulsivity
  • Other symptoms -
  • Destructive behavior
  • Irritability
  • Aggression

Option A: Emotional disorders

  • Emotional disorders include anxiety and depression.
  • This patient does not have emotional disorders.

Option B: Mania

  • Mania involves episodes of increased mood and a sense of grandiosity for more than 7 days.
  • Mania is also characterized by flights of ideas, not inattentive spells as seen in this patient

Option C: Normal behavior

  • This child meets the criteria for Attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder.
  • Normal behavior can have inattentive spells, which would occur during boring activities.

questions.text: A 40 years old male is brought to the hospital with suicidal ideation. Medical history includes arthralgia and major depressive disorder. His family history is significant for bipolar disorder, and he has a history of complete suicide in his family. After losing his job 6 months before, he is feeling extremely low. He is a nonalcoholic and non-smoker. Which of the following drugs is mostly used to decrease suicidal tendencies?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lithium

Figure: a flowchart shows from stress to suicidal behavior development

Lithium-

  • It is a mood stabilizer.
  • It shows good results in treating suicidal tendencies.
  • It helps reduce the suicidal thoughts of bipolar disorder and major depression.
  • A minimum of 18 months of treatment duration is required.
  • Lithium increase serotonin to facilitate serotonin transmission.
  • Lithium can influence impulsive and aggressive traits responsible for suicide.
  • By inhibiting glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK3), lithium shows anti-inflammatory effects and decreases suicidal tendencies.
  • Lithium reduces mood disorder relapse.

Option A: Fluoxetine

  • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.
  • It treats generalized anxiety disorder, bulimia, OCD, and social anxiety disorder.

Option C: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug.
  • This drug is used for partial seizure, tonic-clonic seizure, and trigeminal neuralgia.

Option D: Risperidone

  • Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic.
  • It is used in the treatment of Tourette syndrome.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient with acute psychosis is admitted to the hospital. He wakes up and asks for his wife, who is in the same room and location as him. When he sees her, he begins hitting her, believing she is the nurse disguised as his wife. He also says she is the same nurse who has given him incorrect medication two days prior and intends to damage him again. What is this likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient's symptoms most likely suggest Capgras syndrome.

Option A: Capgras syndrome

  • Capgras syndrome – Belief that a stranger has replaced a familiar person

 

  • It is a delusional misidentification syndrome.
  • Some of the risk factors for this disease are as follows:
  • Dementia
  • Parkinson's syndrome
  • It should be differentiated from Fregoli syndrome, in which a familiar person is imposing as a stranger and can take multiple different appearances.

HOW TO REMEMBER: Fregoli thinks everyone is friendly (strangers as someone known to him. 1 person but many faces). The opposite is true for Capgras. Capgras patients often attack health care workers as patient thinks that someone unknown to him has come under disguise of someone known to him)

Option B: Fregoli syndrome

  • In Fregoli syndrome, the patient thinks that a familiar person is imposing as a stranger and can take multiple different appearances.

Option C: Delusion of subjective doubles

  • In this type of delusion, the patient believes that there are multiple doubles of him/her living their own life.

Option D: Othello syndrome

  • Pathological jealousy or morbid jealousy that arises from multiple concerns. It is seen in heavy alcohol use.

questions.text: The age of onset of OCD seems to have a bimodal distribution, with a peak in childhood (at approximately 10 years of age) and another in early adulthood. There is evidence that brain activity differs in adults with childhood- onset OCD versus adult-onset OCD. Brain areas involved with obsessive compulsive disorder include all except:
questions.solution:
Corpus callosum

  • It is the primary commissural region of the brain consisting of white matter tracts that connect the left and the right cerebral hemispheres
  • This structure is not involved in development of OCD.

Orbito-Frontal Cortex

  • OCD patients have excess activity in the frontal regions of the brain, especially Orbito-Frontal Cortex

Basal Ganglia

  • Caudate Nucleus, which is a part of the Basal Ganglia, is affected in patients with OCD

Head of Caudate Nucleus

  • Caudate nucleus is affected in patients with OCD.

Neuroanatomical Structures Involved in OCD
  1. Orbito-frontal Cortex
  2. Caudate Nucleus (which is a part of Basal Ganglia)
  3. Thalamus
  • How to remember: In OCD - CBT is treatment of choice and OCT anatomical structures are involved.
  • Extra edge: Other important Brain areas and associated psychiatric disorders
Psychiatric Disorders Brain Areas involved
1. Anxiety disorders
  1. Locus ceruleus
  2. Raphe nucleus
  3. Caudate nucleus
  4. Temporal cortex
  5. Frontal cortex
2. Depression Damage to the left frontal lobe
3. Alzheimer's disease Hippocampus

questions.text: A 25 year old Primigravida woman was in 2nd stage of labour for more than an hour. She began to show signs of exhaustion like pulse rate of 105 beats/min and poor voluntary bearing down. Hence, the obstetrician opted for forceps delivery. Post delivery, examination of the skull revealed a depression that on CT showed the following injury. What is the injury sustained?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pond’s fracture

  • This is a smooth concave depression without a fracture line, resulting from in-buckling of the skull, occurring only in the elastic skull of infants and children (prior to 4 years of age).
  • It may also be caused by forcible compression with obstetric forceps or impact against some protruding objects, e.g. sacral promontory during delivery.

Option A: Communited fracture

  • Two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern.
  • Skull bone gets broken into multiple pieces by fracture lines, which are haphazardly or concentrically arranged, or stellate if they radiate from the site of impact.
  • It is caused by vehicular accidents, falls from a height on a hard surface or by blows with weapons having a large striking surface, such as a heavy iron bar, or from a bullet.

Option B: Signature fracture

  • When a portion of a fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known aa s depressed fracture. It is also called ‘fracture ala signature’ (signature fracture), as the shape often points towards the shape of the offending weapon.
  • They are caused by blows with a heavy weapon having a small striking surface, such as a hammer, axe, brick or chopper.

Option D: Ring fracture

  • It is a type of fissure fracture that encircles the base of the skull around the foramen magnum, running from the sella turcica, partly through petrous ridges and then going posteriorly and medially, joining in the posterior fossa.
  • It is associated with falling from a height and landing on the foot.

questions.text: Identify the below image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Incaprettamento:

  • The above-shown image is a type of ligature strangulation known as Incaprettamento.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Torture by ‘Parrot's perch’:

  • Parrot’s perch: Person is suspended head down from a horizontal pole placed under the knees with wrists bound to ankles.

Option B - Zsako’s Phenomenon:

  • Zasko’s Phenomenon: It is a contraction of the whole muscle due to propagated excitation following a mechanical stimulation, seen within 2–3 h after death.

Option D - Torture by ‘Campana’:

  • Campana: It is a type of torture method in which the victim’s head is placed within a metal container or pail which is then struck repeatedly, causing sudden loud sounds and reverberations.

questions.text: A Leading question is asked during the cross-examination of the witness, during examination-in-chief and re-examination after the court's permission. Which section of the Indian Evidence Act defines a Leading question?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - S. 141 IEA:

  • S.141 IEA: Definiton of Leading question.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - S.137 IEA: S.137 IEA: Examination in chief.

Option C - S.138 1EA: S.138 IEA: Order of trial in the court of the law.

Option D - S.165 IEA: S.165 IEA: Questions by Judge.

questions.text: After 4 days, the body of the 35-year-old woman had washed ashore on the Mahabalipuram beach in Chennai. A rigorous search by the coast guard team had proved to be futile as the sea had been rough for last week. The lungs of the woman were being examined by the forensic doctor to confirm death by drowning in the sea. What change among the following would one not expect in the lungs if death was indeed by drowning in the sea?

choices.text: Tend to flatten out on removing
Shape of a sectioned portion is not retained

questions.solution:
Option C: Crepitus is heard on sectioning

  • On the cut section, crepitus is not heard and a copious amount of fluid and froth oozes out.

Option A: Ballooned and heavy lungs

  • Sea/saltwater drowning show ballooned and heavy lungs.

Option B: Tend to flatten out on removing

  • In sea/ saltwater drowning: Lungs tend to flatten out on removal.

Option D: Shape of sectioned portion is not retained

  • The shape is not retained on taking out from the body and tends to flatten out.

questions.text: What is Taxidermy, in layman's terminology?

choices.text: Process of dissection of poisoning deaths
Process of digging the body out
Study of effects of poisons on individual organs
A way of preparing, stuffing, or mounting an animal for display or study

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Process of preparing the body for anatomical dissections:

  • Taxidermy is the process of preparing dead bodies for the purpose of anatomy dissections by injecting solutions of arsenic sulphide or oxide, lead sulphide, potassium carbonate with or without into the femoral and other big arteries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Process of dissection of poisoning deaths:

  • The process of dissection of poisoning deaths is post-mortem autopsy.

Option B - Process of digging the body out:

  • Exhumation is the legal digging out of an already buried body from the grave.
  • There is no time limit for exhumation in India.

Option C - Study of effects of poisons on individual organs:

  • The study of the effects of poisons on individual organs is termed "Toxicology".

questions.text: With respect to dating of a bone, a bone more than 100 years old contain:
questions.solution:
Option A: 7 amino acids

  • A bone > 100 years old will contain 7 amino acids.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is admitted to the surgical ward for a total thyroidectomy under anaesthesia. Her medical history is consistent with diabetes mellitus, hypertension and coronary artery disease. Her medications include aspirin, metformin, amlodipine and valsartan. Transthoracic echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 40% and no regional wall motion abnormalities. Which of the following inhalational anaesthetic agent to be avoided in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Halothane

  • Halothane is a direct myocardial depressant.
  • Halothane, Isoflurane, Desflurane, and Sevoflurane produce similar and dose-dependent decreases in mean arterial pressure.
  • But Halothane decreases blood pressure due to the decrease in myocardial contractility and cardiac output, whereas others decrease by lowering systemic vascular resistance.
  • Isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane increase heart rate.
  • Halothane causes an unchanged heart rate despite a decrease in blood pressure due to depression of the carotid sinus (baroreceptor reflex response) and drug-induced decreases in the rate of sinus node depolarization.
  • Junctional rhythm with the decrease in blood pressure reflects suppression of sinus node activity by Halothane.
  • It also decreases the speed of conduction of impulses through the AV node and His-Purkinje system.
  • Also sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine and is contraindicated in pheochromocytoma.
  • Isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane do not have much effect on the cardiac output as increased heart rate tends to offset the drug-induced decrease in cardiac output but not with Halothane is no change in heart rate.

Option B: Isoflurane

  • Isoflurane does not affect cardiac output as much as Halothane does.

Option C: Sevoflurane

  • Sevoflurane's cardio-depressant effect is very little.
  • Halothane has the maximum and direct cardio-depressant effect.

Option D: Desflurane

  • Desflurane increases heart rate.
  • It does not cause cardiac depression

questions.text: A 36-year-old female with a pregnancy of 36 weeks is admitted to the floor. She has two previous boys who were delivered via C-section. This delivery is also going to be performed via a C-section. What is the best anaesthesia option for elective LSCS?
questions.solution:
Option B: Spinal anaesthesia

  • For an elective cesarean section, spinal anaesthesia is preferred over other techniques.
  • The benefits of spinal anaesthesia over general anaesthesia include:
    • Less newborn exposure to potentially depressing medications;
    • Lower risk of maternal pulmonary aspiration
    • An awake mother throughout childbirth
    • Spinal opioids can be administered for postoperative pain management.
  • The following are the advantages of spinal anaesthesia over epidural anaesthesia:
    • A quick and predictable
    • Complete block (lower failure rate)
    • The lower danger of systemic toxicity or high spinal owing to inadvertent intravascular or intrathecal infusion seen with epidural anaesthesia
    • More cost-effective

Option A: General anaesthesia

  • In some emergencies, general anaesthesia is preferable, such as;
    • Massive bruising (placenta previa or accreta, abruption placentae, or uterine rupture)
    • Coagulopathy
    • Instability of the heart
    • Fetal distress syndrome
    • Maternal trauma
  • Disadvantages of general anaesthesia include the following:
    • Pulmonary aspiration of stomach contents
    • Difficult or unsuccessful intubation
    • Drug exposure to the foetus

Option C: Epidural anaesthesia

  • The following are the advantages of spinal anaesthesia over epidural anaesthesia:
    • A quick and predictable block 
    • Complete block (lower failure rate)
    • The lower danger of systemic toxicity or high spinal owing to inadvertent intravascular or intrathecal infusion seen with epidural anaesthesia
    • More cost-effective

Option D: Saddle anaesthesia

  • A degree of anaesthesia up to T4 is required for an elective caesarean section, which saddle anaesthesia cannot provide.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding propofol?

choices.text: Propofol is contraindicated in asthmatic patients
Propofol is the best anaesthetic option for hemodynamic instability
Propofol is contraindicated in malignant hyperthermia
Propofol has bronchodilatory and neuroprotective properties

questions.solution:
Option D: Propofol has bronchodilatory and neuroprotective properties.

  • Propofol is an intravenous anaesthetic agent used to induce and maintain general anaesthesia.
  • Propofol-induced depression of upper airway reflexes exceeds that of any other agent, thus allowing intubation, endoscopy or laryngeal mark placement in the absence of neuromuscular blockers. Compared with thiopental, propofol decreases the prevalence of wheezing after induction of anaesthesia and tracheal intubation in healthy and asthmatics.
  • Propofol is neuroprotective against ischemic injury, but only if the ischemic insult is mild and not sustained. The neuroprotective effect results from the attenuation of changes in ATP, calcium, sodium, and potassium caused by hypoxic injury
  • Propofol can worsens hypotension in hemodynamic instability because of its vasodilatory and negative inotropic effects.
  • Recovery from propofol is more rapid and is accompanied by minimal residual sedative effects and antiemetic properties, which help reduce post-operative nausea and vomiting, making it suitable for daycare surgeries. Propofol has a rapid onset of action and a faster recovery making it an ideal induction agent of choice for outpatient/ambulatory anaesthesia.
  • Effects of propofol on the respiratory system:
    • Propofol produces dose-dependent respiratory depression with apnea after induction. Opioids enhance ventilatory depression and maintenance doses of propofol decrease tidal volume and respiratory rate.
    • Depresses the ventilatory response to hypoxia by direct action on carotid body chemoreceptors.
    • It induces bronchodilation in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients.
    • Alters pharyngeal function and increases the risk of impaired airway protection and pulmonary aspiration. Subhypnotic doses decrease the pharyngeal contraction force.
    • It has an impact on the pathophysiology of adult respiratory distress syndrome

Option A: Propofol is contraindicated in asthmatic patients

  • Propofol has a bronchodilatory effect and it is a preferred option in asthmatics. Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option B: Propofol is the best anaesthetic option for hemodynamic instability

  • Propofol causes vasodilation that can lead to hypotension. Therefore, it should be avoided in patients with hemodynamic instability as it can deteriorate the condition.

Option C: Propofol is contraindicated in malignant hyperthermia

  • Propofol is a safe anaesthetic option in patients susceptible to malignant hyperthermia. Therefore, it is the wrong option.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who is a case of acute intestinal obstruction is being posted for laparotomy under general anaesthesia with rapid sequence induction. He has a history of 27% burns 8 months back and is currently recovering. Which of the following is the muscle relaxant of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rocuronium

  • Rocuronium in high doses (0.9-1.2 mg/kg) or Succinylcholine (1.5 mg/kg) can be used for rapid tracheal intubation because they provide adequate intubating conditions within 60-90 seconds. If Succinylcholine is undesirable or contraindicated, high doses of rocuronium can be used.
  • Rocuronium has the shortest onset time of all the non-depolarising neuromuscular blockers currently available. The maximal effect of either 0.25 mg or 0.5 mg/kg of rocuronium at the laryngeal muscles occurs after 1.5 minutes. Increasing the doses from 0.6 (twice the ED95) to -1.2 mg/kg (four times the ED95) shortens (89 to 55 seconds) the onset of the neuromuscular block but doubles the clinical duration (37 to 73 minutes).
  • It is primarily eliminated in the liver, with a small fraction eliminated through urine. It is taken up into the liver by a carrier-mediated active transport system. The elimination of rocuronium occurs predominately through its biliary excretion.

Option B: Rapacuronium

  • It is not the best muscle relaxant available due to its longer onset time than rocuronium.

Option C: Vecuronium

  • Rocuronium has a shorter onset time than Vecuronium and is currently the best neuromuscular blocking agent for burn patients.

Option D: Atracurium

  • It is not the best muscle relaxant available due to its comparatively longer onset time than rocuronium.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presents to the emergency ward complaining of vomiting and epigastric pain radiating to the back for 2 days. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and Hashimoto thyroiditis. His only medication is levothyroxine. He drinks 1–2 beers on the weekends and occasionally smokes marijuana. The patient appears distressed and is diaphoretic. The patient is vitally stable. Physical examination shows abdominal distention with tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. There is no guarding or rebound tenderness. Skin examination shows several clusters of yellow plaques over the trunk and extensor surfaces of the extremities. The CT abdomen of the patient is done, and the structure involved in the patient's pathology is marked with an arrow in the image. Which of the following structure is involved in the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pancreas

  • This is a case of acute pancreatitis in which the patient presents with complaints of vomiting and epigastric pain that radiates to the back for 2 days.

  • In this case, on abdominal examination, the abdomen is distended, and there is tenderness on palpation in the epigastric region.

  • The structure marked with an arrow in this image is the pancreas, which is the structure involved in acute pancreatitis.

  • Acute pancreatitis is the inflammation of the pancreas. It occurs suddenly and can last for weeks to months.

Option A: Spleen

  • The structure marked with an arrow in the CT scan is the pancreas, not the spleen.

Option B: Renal artery

  • The renal artery transport oxygenated blood to the kidney; it is not marked in the image of the CT abdomen given above in this case.

Option C: Bowel loop

  • Small and large intestines loops are called bowel loops; they are not marked in the CT scan in this case.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his father with the complaint of acute onset pain in the abdomen from the last 6 days. His father said that he noticed blood in his stool a few days ago. On examination, no obvious mass is felt. The Pediatrician advised an ultrasound suspecting it to be a surgical cause. The image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis seeing the symptoms and the radiological image?
questions.solution:
Option B: Intussusception

  • Intussusception will be the probable diagnosis seeing the symptoms and the radiological image of the patient.
  • On a plain radiograph, intussusception presents as a meniscus sign.
  • On USG, the target sign/doughnut sign is usually visible.
  • Another sign visible on USG is the pseudo-kidney sign: It is a longitudinal image through an intussuscepted segment - running down towards the 4 o'clock position) with several enlarged adjacent nodes.
  • On barium, the signs visible include the claw sign/pincer sign and the Coiled spring appearance.
  • Intussusception is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children younger than 3 years old.
  • The intestine is shaped like a long tube. In intussusception, one part of the intestine (usually the small intestine) slides inside an adjacent part. This is sometimes also called telescoping.

            

Option A: Midgut Volvulus

  • Midgut volvulus is a complication of malrotation in which clockwise twisting of the bowel (whirlpool sign) around the SMA axis.

Option C: Ascariasis

  • On plain radiographs, masses of worms in the jejunum may be outlined by bowel gas, and linear filling defects may be seen on barium examinations.

Option D: Appendicitis

  • An inflamed appendix is rarely visible radiologically.
  • Faecal loading of the caecum is associated with acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after encountering a road traffic accident. He is hemodynamically stable but has multiple lacerated wounds around the knee, ankle and elbow joints, with a severely fractured left ankle joint. On examination, his vitals are stable, but his left ankle is grossly deformed and produces severe pain on movement. The X-ray is given below. Which type of fracture would not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lover's fracture

Figure: Lovers fracture (B/L comminuted fracture of calcaneum)

Lover's fracture:

  • Lover's fractures, also known as Casanova fractures or Don Juan fractures, are a type of calcaneal fracture.

  • This fracture commonly occurs due to landing on heels following a fall from height.

  • Common symptoms of Lover's fractures include heel pain, bruising and trouble walking.

  • X-ray is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of Lover's fracture.

  • This patient's x-ray doesn't reveal any calcaneal fracture.

Option A: Pott's fracture

  • The bimalleolar fracture is known as Pott's fracture.

  • The injury is caused by a combined abduction external rotation from an eversion force.

 

Option B: Pilon's fracture

  • It is a type of distal tibial fracture (not calcaneal fracture).

  • It involves the tibial plafond.

 

Option D: Tillaux fracture

  • The distal tibial epiphysis fracture is called the Tillaux fracture.

  • It involves the physis and epiphysis of the distal tibia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with progressive forward bending with increasing stiffness of the spine. He has increased stiffness in his lower back, hip pain and difficulty breathing. A CT spine was performed and shown below. What is the most Likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Ankylosing Spondylitis

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a rare type of arthritis that causes pain and stiffness in your spine.

  • This lifelong condition, also known as Bechterew disease, usually starts in the lower back.

  • It can spread to the neck or damage joints in other parts of the body.

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a complex disorder that can cause some serious complications when left unchecked. However, symptoms and complications for many people can be controlled or reduced by following a regular treatment plan.

  • Diagnostic radiological features of Ankylosing spondylitis are

    • Bilateral symmetrical Sacroiliitis (earliest and most specific feature)

    • Bamboo-spine (knobby spine, poker back, or universal syndesmophytes) is a characteristic feature.

    • Syndesmophytes - ossifications of the outer fibers of the annulus fibrosis.

    • Enthesitis (earliest pathological change)

    • Uncommon involvement of small joints of hand and feet.
       

Option A: Rheumatoid Arthritis

  • Rheumatoid arthritis, or RA, is an autoimmune and inflammatory disease. The immune system attacks healthy cells in the body by mistake, causing inflammation (painful swelling) in the affected parts of the body.

  • Rheumatoid arthritis mainly attacks the joints, usually many joints at once.

  • Symptoms: Inflammation

  • An autoimmune disorder, rheumatoid arthritis, occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks its body's tissues.

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a very serious autoimmune disease in which the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's tissues and causes severe joint pain, stiffness, fatigue, and sometimes deformity, usually in the hands, shoulders, knees, and feet.

Option C: Reiter’s syndrome

  • Reiter's syndrome is a form of inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity).

  • Coming into contact with bacteria and developing an infection can trigger the disease.
