  • The disorder is believed to be due to an aberrant autoimmune response to a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection caused by salmonella, shigella, campylobacter, or chlamydia.

Arthritis symptoms

  • Joint pain and inflammation often affect the knees, feet, and ankles.

  • Inflammation of the tendon attached to the bone (called enthesopathy) may cause heel pain or the shortening and thickening of the fingers.

  • Heel spurs are bony growths in the heel that can cause chronic pain.

  • Reactive arthritis (ReA), formerly Reiter syndrome, is an autoimmune condition that develops in response to an infection.

Option D: Fluorosis

  • Fluorosis is a condition that results in white or brown speckles on teeth.

  • It is caused by overexposure to fluoride in the early years of life when permanent teeth develop.

  •  Fluorosis is a cosmetic concern and is not harmful to health.

  • Most cases of fluorosis are mild and do not need treatment.

  • In more severe cases, whitening of the teeth, veneers, or other cosmetic dentistry techniques can be used to correct permanent discoloration.

  • Once a child reaches the age of 8, they are no longer at risk for developing fluorosis.

  • Many cases of fluorosis can be prevented by keeping children from swallowing fluoride products like toothpaste.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female presented with complaints of fever associated with chills, sore throat, and facial rash for 5 days. Physical examination reveals an erythematous pharynx without exudates and a couple of red, painful patches on the child's cheeks. The lesions have increased in size over the last 2 days, as shown in the exhibit. What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Option D: Topical Antibiotics

  • This patient complains of acute onset fever, pharyngitis, and skin lesions characteristic of impetigo.
  • Impetigo is a cutaneous bacterial infection characterized by erythematous pustular skin lesions that develop rapidly and are associated with high-grade fever and bacterial pharyngitis.

Impetigo 

Type Non-bullous Bullous
Microbiology
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Group A streptococcus (S pyogenes
 S aureus
Clinical features
  • Painful non-pruritic pustules
  • Honey – crusted lesions
  • Rapidly enlarging flaccid bullae with yellow fluid
  • Collarette of scale at periphery of ruptured lesions
Treatment
  • Limited skin involvement topical antibiotics (eg, mupirocin)
  • Extensive skin involvement: Oral antibiotics (eg, cephalexin, dicloxacillin, clindamycin)

Impetigo

  • It primarily occurs in children.
  • It is caused by both Group A streptococci (S. pyogenes) and staphylococcal organisms.
  • Two types:
    1. Non-bullous type: More common, generally appears on the face.
    2. Bullous type: Characterized by large stable blisters that frequently involve the acral surfaces.
  • Bullous impetigo is almost always caused by S aureus and can evolve into SSSS.
  • Dried pustules with a superficial golden-brown crust are most commonly found around the nose and mouth.

Treatment options include

  • Topical:
    • Fusidic acid
    • Mupirocin
    • Retapamulin
  • Systemic:
    • Erythromycin for Non-bullous and Dicloxacillin for Bullous Impetigo.

Option A: Isotretinoin ointment

  • Topical Isotretinoin is the treatment of choice in acne vulgaris.
  • Acne vulgaris is a prevalent skin condition characterized by closed or open comedones on the forehead, chin, and nose.
  • It can progress to inflammatory pustules or nodules. Impetigo is an acute bacterial infection that requires topical or oral antibiotics depending on the severity.

Option B: Topical steroids

  • Topical steroids are used to treat allergic contact dermatitis.
  • It is a cutaneous inflammatory condition characterized by erythema and papules on the exposed areas of the body.
  • It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of materials, most importantly, poison oak and nickel. This patient's topical lesions on the cheeks and systemic symptoms of high-grade fever are suggestive of impetigo and require antibiotics.

Option C: Topical salicylic acid

  • Topical salicylic acid is used to treat cutaneous warts.
  • Warts are localized areas of benign keratinized growths on the planter surfaces of hands and feet.
  • The most common cause is human papillomavirus virus infection. This patient's skin lesions on the cheek and high-grade fever suggest impetigo and require antibiotics.

questions.text: An 85-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of skin lesions for the past 3 hours. She denies any fever or drug intake. On examination, multiple blisters on the trunk and thigh are noted. Bullae are tense. Nikolsky’s sign is negative. Oral mucosa is spared. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bullous pemphigoid

This patient with tense bullae sparing of oral mucosa most likely has bullous pemphigoid.

  • It is an Autoimmune disorder
  • IgG Antibodies are formed against BP Ag 2 [BP 180] > BP Ag 1 [BP 230] sub-epidermal bullae.
  • Seen in the elderly patient
  • Negative Nikolsky sign
  • Multiple blisters on trunk and thigh
  • Oral mucosa is spared.

Option A: Pemphigus vulgaris

  • P. vulgaris is the most common pemphigus
    • It has a worldwide distribution
    • Most common in middle-aged adults, rare in children.
    • Younger age at presentation in Indians compared to the West
  • Oral mucosa is involved in pemphigus vulgaris and nikolsky sign is positive in contrast to bullous pemphigoid

Option C: Lichen planus

  • Papulo-squamous inflammatory disorder characterized by flat purple pruritic papules is seen in lichen planus.
  • The treatment of choice is corticosteroids.

Option D: Lepra reaction

  • Lepra Reaction is an exacerbation of pre-existing disease due to a change in the immunological state of the patient [after starting treatment].
  • This patient most likely has bullous pemphigoid.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man visits the clinic with a complaint of intense itching, redness, and discomfort in the groin region for the last two days. He is a marathon runner and has been practicing a lot recently. He has no chronic medical condition and takes no medications. Examination findings are shown in the image below:



Based on these findings, this patient's underlying condition can be caused by all of the following organisms except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Aspergillus

  • This patient, with intense itching, redness, and discomfort involving his groin region, and physical examination findings showing an erythematous rash with raised borders along with slight central clearing, most likely suffers from tinea cruris. Dermatophytes most commonly cause it.
  • Dermatophyte infections differ according to their location on the body:
  • Scalp: Tinea capitis
  • Body: Tinea corporis
  • Nails: Tinea unguium
  • Inguinal area: Tinea cruris
  • Feet: Tinea pedis
  • The diagnosis is generally made clinically. However, KOH preparations of the skin scrapings can be helpful, showing branching segmented hyphae.

Aspergillus most commonly affects immunocompromised individuals and can lead to chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and ABPA. However, it has no role in causing infections related to tinea.

Option B: Microsporum

  • It is one of the dermatophytes and can cause tinea infection.

Option C: Epidermophyton

  • It is also one of the dermatophytes and can lead to tinea infections.

Option D: Trichophyton

  • It is a dermatophyte and the most common organism related to tinea infections.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic complaining of a rash over her body. Her family history is positive for asthma in her mother. On examination, the following findings are noted, as shown in the diagram:



Which of the following is  the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Atopic dermatitis

  • The above-mentioned patient has a Dennie-Morgan fold which is a single or double fold in the lower eyelid. This is seen in atopic dermatitis.
  • Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a common, chronic, inflammatory skin disorder characterized by the presence of pruritic, eczematous dermatitis.
  • Dennie-Morgan fold is a single or double fold in the lower eyelid due to eyelid edema caused by eyelid dermatitis. Infraorbicular folds are common findings in black children regardless of the presence or absence of atopic dermatitis.

The key features of the Infantile phase of Atopic Dermatitis are listed below:

  1. The lesions most frequently start on the face
  2. The napkin area is relatively spared. When the child begins to crawl, the exposed surfaces, especially the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows, are most involved.
  3. The lesions consist of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules.
  4. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  5. Secondary infection and lymphadenopathy are common.
  6. The disease runs a chronic fluctuating course, varying with such factors as teething, respiratory infections, emotional upsets, and changes in humidity.

Option A: Mastocytosis

  • Pediatric mastocytosis has a benign nature and usually resolves spontaneously by puberty. It typically presents as urticaria pigmentosa or solitary mastocytoma.
  • The above-mentioned patient has a Dennie-Morgan fold which is seen in atopic dermatitis.

Option B: Seborrhoeic dermatitis

  • Seborrheic dermatitis presents primarily with cradle cap and napkin dermatitis.
  • It usually appears by the age of 3 months and disappears spontaneously by 8 months of age. This child has a Dennie-Morgan fold which is seen in atopic dermatitis.

Option C: Sarcoidosis

  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that frequently affects young adults.
  • Early onset sarcoidosis (<5 years) is characterized by a triad of arthritis, uveitis, and rash. This patient has no such symptoms.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency depart with a high-grade fever and shortness of breath. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of acute epiglottitis is made. Which of the following is not true regarding acute epiglottitis?

1) Caused by Hemophilus influenza type B

2) Thumb sign-on X-ray.

3) Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice.

4) Diagnosis is made by indirect laryngoscopy.
questions.solution:
Option A: Only 4

  • The most common underlying cause for acute epiglottitis is Hemophilus influenza type B.
  • Acute epiglottitis may occur in all ages but is most commonly seen in children 2-6 years of age.
  • With the introduction of the H. influenzae vaccine, the incidence of acute epiglottitis has greatly reduced in children in developed countries. In developed countries, the most common cause is streptococcus pneumoniae or streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Acute epiglottitis has a rapid onset (1-3 hours) and presents with fever, sore throat, dysphagia, drooling, dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia.
  • The child appears acutely ill with classic tripod positioning (sitting, leaning forward, open mouth with neck and chin extended).
  • Any kind of instrumentation such as Indirect laryngoscopy (I/L) is contraindicated due to the high risk of glottic closure from spasms.
  • Diagnosis is made by X-ray Soft tissue Neck (Lateral View)
  • X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view) shows the epiglottis (which normally is thin leaf-shaped) to be swollen, appearing like a thumb, known as a thumb sign.
  • The diagnosis can be further confirmed with direct visualization of the larynx in an OR while performing intubation.
  • The treatment consists of securing the airways (endotracheal intubation, tracheostomy), IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone), and steroid nebulization.

Option B: Only 1 and 2

This is false because:

  • Hemophilus influenza type B is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis.
  • X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view) shows the epiglottis (which normally is thin leaf-shaped) to be swollen, appearing like a thumb, known as a thumb sign.

Option C: Only 2,3 and 4

This is false because:

  • Thumb sign is seen on the lateral neck X-ray.
  • Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice

Option D: only 3

This is false because:

  • Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male presents to the clinic due to severe throat pain and fever for 3 days. On physical examination, palatine tonsils are congested. A clinical diagnosis of tonsillitis is made. The patient underwent a tonsillectomy the following day. During the procedure, the patient develops bleeding. Which of the following is the source of haemorrhage during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Option B: Paratonsillar vein

  • Arterial supply: The tonsil is supplied by five arteries
    • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery. It is the main artery.
    • Ascending pharyngeal artery from external carotid.
    • Ascending palatine, a branch of the facial artery.
    • Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery.\
    • Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery.
  • Venous drainage: Veins from the tonsils drain into the paratonsillar vein, which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.
  • Immediate complications of tonsillectomy include:
  • Pain: Post-tonsillectomy sore throat is normal for at least 1 week.
  • Bleeding:
    • Primary haemorrhage occurs during the surgery. It results due to damage to the paratonsillar vein.
    • Reactionary haemorrhage occurs within 24 hours after the surgery due to clot formation, which prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle onto the vessels.
    • Secondary haemorrhage (delayed complication) is bleeding that occurs after 24 hours but within 2 weeks. Secondary bleeding is most likely due to streptococcal infection in the granulating tonsil bed.
    • The patient may experience temporomandibular joint dysfunction if the mouth is too wide during tonsillectomy. Dissection beyond pharyngeal musculature can lead to injury to the glossopharyngeal nerve and, rarely, the carotid sheath. Non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation (Grisel syndrome) can occur secondary to any inflammatory process in the neck.
    • Injury to tonsillar pillars, uvula, soft palate tongue, or superior constrictor muscle.
    • Injury to teeth.
    • Aspiration of blood
    • Facial oedema
    • Surgical emphysema
  • Delayed complications include:
    • Secondary haemorrhage
  • Infection: The first symptoms of post-tonsillectomy infection are fever and halitosis. Infection of the paratonsillar fossa can lead to parapharyngeal abscess or otitis media.
    • Lung abscess or atelectasis due to aspiration of blood, mucus, or tissue fragments.

Option A: Maxillary artery:

  • Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery supplies the palatine tonsils.
  • However, it is not the common cause of haemorrhage during tonsillectomy.

Option C: Lingual artery

  • Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery supply the palatine tonsils.
  • However, they are not the source of haemorrhage during tonsillectomy.

Option D: Middle meningeal artery

  • The middle meningeal artery supplies the middle ear.
  • It does not supply the palatine tonsils.
  • Therefore, it is not the source of haemorrhage in tonsillectomy.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a nosebleed for the past 20 minutes. His medical history is consistent with hypertension. On examination, his blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. After a series of treatments, the bleeding does not stop. An endoscopy is ordered. Endoscopy shows bleeding in Kiesselbach's plexus. Which of the following is TRUE regarding anterior epistaxis?

choices.text: Patient is kept in a sitting and slightly leaning forward position while compressing the nares
Topical phenylephrine is contraindicated as it increases blood pressure
Commonly from Kiesselbach's venous plexus in the anteroinferior part of the septum
Foley's nasal tamponade is a treatment option

questions.solution:
Option A: Patient is kept in a sitting and slightly leaning forward position while compressing the nares

  • For patients without life-threatening bleeding, the first step in management is Trotter's or Hippocratic method, in which the patient is made to sit with his head forward over a bowl/sink and pinch the nares firmly, closing the nostrils.
  • He is also advised to spit out any blood in the mouth as it is emetogenic.

Option B: Topical phenylephrine is contraindicated as it increases blood pressure

  • Phenylephrine being a decongestant is used to decongest the nose before cauterization.

Option C: Commonly from Kiesselbach's venous plexus in the anterio-inferior part of the septum

  • Kiesselbach's plexus is an arterial plexus.

Option D: Foley's nasal tamponade is a treatment option

  • Foley's nasal tamponade is done in the posterior epistaxis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with the complaint of foul-smelling nasal discharge for one week. He is concerned about his condition and prognosis as his father had large nodules in his nose a few years back that extended to his throat but remained painless. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of Rhinoscleroma is made. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition ?

choices.text: Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are seen

questions.solution:
Option B: Saddle nose deformity is seen

  • Saddle nose deformity is not seen in Rhinoscleroma.
  • It can be seen in trauma, leprosy, syphilis, and Wegener's granulomatosis.

Rhinoscleroma

  • Rhinoscleroma is a granulomatous condition.
  • Caused by the gram-negative bar Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis
  • Mainly affects the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.
  • In cutting-edge cases, the obliteration of the nasal cartilage with the development of nodules causes a serious distortion called Hebra's nose.

Features:

  • This chronic granulomatous infectious disease runs through the following stages;

1. Atrophic stage:

  • It resembles atrophic Rhinitis showing the symptoms of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.

2. Granulomatous stage:

  • Large nodules form in the nasal mucosa. Subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and upper lip occurs.

3. Cicatricial stage:

  • This includes nares stenosis, upper lip destruction, and adhesions from the nose to the oropharynx.

Diagnosis

  • Biopsy shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. The latter two are diagnostic features of the disease

Treatment

  • Both streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given together for a minimum period of 4-6 weeks and repeated, if necessary, after 1 month.
  • Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative. Steroids can be combined to reduce fibrosis.
  • Surgical treatment may be required to establish the airway and correct nasal deformity.

Option A: Multiple granulomatous nodules

  • The nodules in Rhinoscleroma are usually nonulcerative.
  • Rhinoscleroma is a granulomatous condition.
  • And affects the nasal cavity and nasopharynx primarily
  • This is correct about Rhinoscleroma, so this can't be the right answer.

Option C: Painless non-ulcerative nodules are formed

  • The nodules are painless due to infiltration of the pain-carrying nerve fibers by the inflammatory cells, which make them nonfunctional.
  • These nodules are nonulcerative.
  • Granulomatous nodules involve nasal mucosa and upper lip giving it a "woody" feel.

Option D: Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are seen

Mikulicz cells are seen in Rhinoscleroma

  • Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli.
  • Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by plasma cells.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has a history of multiple hospitalizations for fever and infection and undergoes immunologic evaluation. Serum CH50 assay shows inappropriately low erythrocyte lysis, and further workup confirms C8 deficiency. Physical examination reveals a cleft lip, a prominent nasal bridge, and a small lower jaw. After further investigation patient is diagnosed with DiGeorge syndrome. Which of the following are true regarding the derivatives of the structure involved in patient's pathology?

choices.text: Eustachian tube develops from 1st pharyngeal pouch
Palatine tonsils develop from 1st pharyngeal pouch
Inferior parathyroid glands develop from the 4thpharyngeal pouch
Parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland develop from the 1st pharyngeal pouch and remnants of the 5th pharyngeal pouch

questions.solution:
Option A: Eustachian tube develops from 1st pharyngeal pouch

  • This is a case of DiGeorge syndrome in which the patient’s serum CH50 assay shows inappropriately low erythrocyte lysis, and further workup confirms C8 deficiency.
  • The physical examination reveals a cleft lip, a prominent nasal bridge, and a small lower jaw.
  • Eustachian tube is derived from 1st pharyngeal pouch.
  • The two lateral Anlagen, also known as the ultimobranchial bodies, are thought to develop as evaginations of the fourth pharyngeal pouches.
  • They become separated from them by attenuation and rupture from the common pharyngobranchial duct.
  • The ultimobranchial bodies fuse with the median thyroid anlage by the sixth.
  • week of development, contributing approximately 10% of the mass of the thyroid gland.
  • It is thought that rarely the ultimobranchial bodies can fail to fuse, resulting in a true 'lateral thyroid lobe,' although this has been disputed.

Option B: Palatine tonsils develop from 1st pharyngeal pouch

  • The palatine tonsils are not developed from the 1st pharyngeal pouch.
  • It is derived from 2nd pharyngeal pouch.

Option C: Inferior parathyroid glands develop from the 4th pharyngeal pouch

  • The inferior parathyroid gland arises from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch, while the superior parathyroids arise from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. So, this statement is incorrect.

Option D: Parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland develop from the 1st pharyngeal pouch and remnants of the 5th pharyngeal pouch

  • Parafollicular C cells are believed to develop from the ventral portion of the 4th pharyngeal pouch and the remnants of the 5th pharyngeal pouch.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 1-year history of intermittent buzzing in both ears. She says she sometimes has episodes of mild dizziness that resolve spontaneously. She has a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and episodes of low back pain. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin and aspirin. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears normal. Weber test shows no lateralization. The structure involved in this pathology is developed from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Reichert's cartilage  

  • It is a case of osteosclerosis.
    • Otosclerosis is the abnormal growth of the bone of the bony labyrinth, primarily at the oval window. It manifests at the stapes.
    • This results in progressive conductive hearing loss because the ossicle's vibrating ability becomes limited. If untreated, the disease progresses to deafness. The treatment of choice is replacing the upper part of the stapes with a prosthesis.
  • Stapes develop from the dorsal end of the Reichert's cartilage (2nd branchial arch). However, the medial surface of the stapes footplate and its annular ligament is derived from the otic capsule (lamina stapedialis), which develops in the mesoderm surrounding the membranous labyrinth.
  • Formation of footplate: The classical theory presumes that the footplate has 2 origins: The tympanic area derived from the stapedial ring and the vestibular area derived from the lamina stapedialis of the otic capsule.

Option A: Quadrate cartilage

  • Quadrate cartilage (maxillary process).
  • Maxilla, pre maxilla, zygomatic bone, squamous part of temporal bone.

Option B: Meckel's cartilage

  • Meckel's Cartilage (Mandibular process).
    • Mandible.
    • Malleus & incus anterior ligament of malleus.
    • Sphenomandibular ligament.

Option D: Lamina stapedialis

  • The medial border of the stapedial ring is in contact with a depression in the lateral wall of the otic capsule. This depression called the lamina stapedial is the future oval window, fusing with the medial border of the stapedial ring to form the stapes footplate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ENT OPD with chief complaints of ear pain (otalgia), decreased hearing, and blood-stained discharge. On otoscopic examination, his left ear tympanic membrane is bulging with blisters, and the light reflex is absent. This condition of the tympanic membrane is caused by which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • Based on the symptoms and otoscopic examination findings described, the likely diagnosis for the 35-year-old male is Acute Otitis Media (AOM) with Tympanic Membrane Perforation.

    Acute Otitis Media (AOM) is a common ear infection that affects the middle ear, usually caused by bacterial pathogens such as Streptococcus pneumoniae. The condition is commonly caused by the bacterium Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Other options are A, C & D are incorrect and to not cause these symptoms.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old male child is brought to the ENT clinic by his parents for a re-screening test for hearing which was failed initially at 1 month age. After a series of examinations and different hearing tests, sensorineural hearing loss is diagnosed. The doctor decides to go for cochlear implantation. Which of the following is the absolute contraindication of cochlear implantation?

1) Michel's aplasia

2) Mondini's dysplasia

3) 8th nerve tumor

4) 8th nerve aplasia
questions.solution:
Option B: Only 1, 3, and 4 are correct

Statements 1, 3, and 4 are the absolute contraindications for cochlear implantation; they are :

  • Michel’s Aplasia (Absence of cochlea); in Michel's Aplasia, there is the complete absence of a bony and membranous labyrinth. Even the petrous apex is absent, but external and middle ears may be completely unaffected. No hearing aids or cochlear implantation can be used.
  • Absent cochlear nerve (8th nerve aplasia).
  • Eight nerve tumor (e.g., Vestibular Schwannoma).

Cochlear implants are auditory implantable prostheses that electrically stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the cochlear nerve directly in circumstances when the cochlear hair cells themselves do not function effectively to give adequate speech intelligibility.

The external components of the cochlear implant, i.e., the transmitter coil (rounded structure held to the skin with a small magnet), the microphone, and the speech.

Indications of Cochlear Implant:

  • Bilateral severe hearing loss (> 70 dB in adults and > 90 dB in children).
  • Patients not benefit from hearing aids given for a severe sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Auditory neuropathy

Option A. Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct

  • This option is wrong because it includes statement no. 2: Mondini's dysplasia, which is a relative contraindication for cochlear implantation and the cochlear implant, can be done.

Option C. Only 1 and 2 are correct.

  • This option is wrong because it includes statement no. 2: Mondini's dysplasia, which is a relative contraindication for cochlear implantation and the cochlear implant, can be done.

  • Also, it does not include statements 3 and 4, which are absolute contraindications for the cochlear implant.

Option D. Only 3 and 4 are correct.

  • This option is wrong because it does not include statement 1, Michel's aplasia, which is an absolute contraindication for the cochlear implant.

questions.text:
Your senior doctor, while examining a patient, uses a slit lamp and focuses on the peripheral cornea near the limbus at an angle of 60 degrees:



Which of the following structures is being examined?
questions.solution:
Option B: Measuring anterior chamber depth

Van Herick’s method

  • Measures anterior chamber depth with a slit lamp, focusing on the peripheral cornea near the limbus at an angle of 60 degrees as shown in the image given in the question.
  • It compares anterior chamber depth with corneal thickness.

Van Herick’s Grading 

  • Grade 4 PAC >= CT
    • Grade 3 PAC = 1/4 to 1/2 of CT
    • Grade 2 PAC = 1/4 of CT
    • Grade 1 PAC < 1/4 of CT

CT: Corneal thickness

PAC: Peripheral anterior chamber depth

  • Grade 4 means the likelihood of angle closure is rare

Option A: Schwalbe’s line

  • The Schwalbe’s line is visible at 10 degrees on gonioscopy which carries a high risk of angle closure.

Option C: Assessing Trabecular meshwork

  • If the trabecular meshwork is visible at 20 degrees on the gonioscopy, there is a possible risk of angle closure.

Option D: Anterior chamber volume

  • At 60 degrees, the Van Herick method detects the depth of the anterior chamber, not the volume.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaint of the need for frequent changes in eyeglass prescriptions. He also experiences sudden worsening or clouding of vision. The doctor advises Computerized corneal mapping. He also observes a V-shaped indentation in the lower eyelid when the patient's gaze is directed downwards. What is the characteristic sign called?
questions.solution:
Option B: Munson Sign

  • The sign discussed in the question stem is the indentation of the lower lid in a downward gaze - Munson's Sign in Keratoconus.
  • Munson's sign is a V-shaped indentation observed in the lower eyelid when the patient's gaze is directed downwards.
  • The medical sign is characteristic of advanced cases of keratoconus.
  • It is caused by the cone-shaped cornea pressing down into the eyelid.

Option A: Rizutti Sign

  • Rizzuti's sign -- In patients with advanced keratoconus, lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side produces a sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus.
  • The sign discussed in the question stem is Munson sign.

Option C: Bow tie pattern

  • Bow tie pattern is seen in cases of optic atrophy when chiasma atrophy takes place.
  • The sign discussed in the question stem is Munson sign.

Option D: Bull's eye sign

  • Seen in maculopathies.
  • The term bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium giving a "bull's-eye" appearance to the macula.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Option B: Wilson's disease

  • The given image shows Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are greenish, gold, or brownish rings around the edge of the corneas. A buildup of copper in the eyes causes Kayser-Fleischer rings. This is a finding of Wilson's disease.

Option A: Keratoconus

  • Keratoconus occurs when cornea thins and gradually bulges outward into a cone shape. A cone-shaped cornea causes blurred vision and may cause sensitivity to light and glare.
  • This is not a finding seen in glaucoma.

Option C: Glaucoma

  • Glaucoma describes a group of conditions in which there is characteristic cupping of the optic disc with corresponding visual field defects, due to retinal ganglion cell loss.
  • It is a progressive condition and is the most common cause of irreversible blindness worldwide.
  • Primary open angle glaucoma (POAG) is a subset of the glaucomas defined by an open, normal appearing anterior chamber angle and raised intraocular pressure (IOP), with no other underlying disease.
  • If there is an identifiable underlying cause for raised IOP, this is termed secondary glaucoma.
  • If the IOP is within normal limits, this is termed normal tension glaucoma (NTG).
  • This is not a finding seen in glaucoma.

Option D: Williams syndrome

  • Williams syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body. This condition is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) problems.
  • People with Williams syndrome typically have difficulty with visual-spatial tasks such as drawing and assembling puzzles, but they tend to do well on tasks that involve spoken language, music, and learning by repetition (rote memorization). Affected individuals have outgoing, engaging personalities and tend to take an extreme interest in other people. Attention deficit disorder (ADD), problems with anxiety, and phobias are common among people with this disorder.

questions.text: A sixty-five-year-old presents to your clinic with the complaint of decreased vision in both eyes. The loss of vision was gradual, and he has not experienced any pain in his eyes. Examination findings reveal a bilateral cataract. Cataract surgery is scheduled. The patient is informed that the left eye will be operated on first, and the right eye will be done 1 week after that. An intraocular lens (IOL) is placed in the eye during the surgery. Which type of lens is shown below?
questions.solution:
Option D: Multifocal Posterior chamber IOL

  • Image in the question shows a multifocal posterior chamber IOL.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is implanted in the eye in place of the crystalline lens that gets opacified in a cataract.
  • An IOL consists of an optic and haptics.
  • Posterior chamber IOL is the most commonly used IOL after cataract surgery.
  • Multifocal IOLs may be refractive or diffractive.
  • Refractive IOLs mainly provide intermediate and distance vision.
  • Diffractive IOLs provide brilliant reading vision and a decent distant vision.
  • There are various rings in the optic zone of a multifocal IOL.
  • This allows the patient to see at various distances according to the multiple focal lengths.
  • Side effects include:
    • Unavoidable halos
    • Glare.

Option A: Crystalens

  • Crystalens is a type of accommodative IOL that is also placed in the posterior chamber.
  • Elastic haptics are present that change the position of the optic when a person tries to accommodate.
  • No rings are present in the optics, helping reduce glare and halos.

Option B: Anterior Chamber IOL

  • A Complicated surgery, with a rupture of the posterior capsule, may necessitate alternative positioning of the IOL.
  • In this scenario, anterior chamber IOLs are used.
  • In the anterior chamber, IOL the haptics supported in the angle.
  • The position of the anterior chamber requires a specific type of lens.
  • Complications include:
    • Uveitis
    • Glaucoma
    • Hyphema

Option C: ICL

  • An Implantable Collamer Lens (ICL) is a Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lens.
  • Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lenses are used as refractive surgery in patients unsuitable for corneal refractive surgery.
  • Has communication ports to allow passage of aqueous from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber and posterior vault (the gap between ICL and the anterior surface of the crystalline lens).

questions.text: A 47-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with progressive bilateral visual disturbances. Visual acuity is 6/6 bilaterally, but she can only read from the right eye's nasal and left eye’s temporal fields. Wernicke's hemianopia pupil is present. The rest of the neurological examination is unremarkable. What is the site of the lesion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Optic Chiasma: The visual information from the nasal field of one eye and the temporal field of the other eye (which corresponds to the outer peripheral vision) decussates at the optic chiasm. In this patient, who can only read from the right eye's nasal and left eye’s temporal fields, the lesion is likely located at the optic chiasm.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Left Optic tract: If the left optic tract were affected, it would cause loss of vision in the right temporal field of the right eye and the left nasal field of the left eye. This does not match the patient's symptoms, where she can read from the right eye's nasal field and the left eye’s temporal field.

Option B: Right Optic tract: Similar to the explanation for option A, a lesion in the right optic tract would not produce the described visual field defects.

Option D: Left Occipital lobe: Lesions in the left occipital lobe typically cause contralateral homonymous hemianopia, where the patient loses vision in the right visual field of both eyes or the left visual field of both eyes. This does not align with the patient's symptoms of specific visual field loss in the right eye's nasal and left eye’s temporal fields.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the Pediatric outpatient department with a painless nodule on the inner surface of his lower eyelid. Her mother reported that it started as a small lesion, progressively increasing in size over several weeks without any pain in the surrounding area. On physical examination, a lipogranulomatous inflammation is noted. Which of the following do you think is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chalazion

  • It is a small swelling or lump on the eyelid which presents as a painless nodule due to obstruction of the sebaceous glands in the eyelid.
  • Obstruction of the Zeis or meibomian eyelid glands, due to which thickened secretions lead to blockage of glands, producing a granulomatous inflammatory response.
  • A patient can present with eyelid discomfort from swelling and even eyelid pain in cases of secondary infection.
  • Lipogranulomatous inflammation is usually present.
  • Diagnosis is mostly made clinically based on the eye exam finding of a painless eyelid nodule.
  • In case of recurrent chalazion or seborrheic blepharoconjunctivitis, rule out sebaceous cell carcinoma.
  • Incision and curettage are done from the conjunctival side.
  • Horizontal incisions are avoided to minimize damage to meibomian ducts.

Option A: Fungal infection

  • Fungal keratitis can occur suddenly from an eye injury or using a contact lens.
  • It can cause vision loss without treatment.
  • The risk of fungal infections is associated with an eye injury, eye surgery, chronic eye disease, contact lenses, fungal bloodstream infection, and immunocompromised people.
  • This patient does not present with features of fungal infection.

Option B: Tuberculosis

  • Ocular TB can also involve any part of the eye and can occur with or without evidence of systemic TB.
  • Tuberculosis and viral agents cause infection and associated inflammation but not lipogranulomatous inflammation.

Option D: Viral infection

  • Most viral infection causes conjunctivitis, which is highly contagious, usually due to adenovirus.
  • Symptoms include irritation, photophobia, and watery discharge.
  • There is no lipogranulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: Treatment of choice of acute dacryocystitis:-
questions.solution:
Acute Dacryocystitis

  • Stages

Cellulitis

↓

Lacrimal Abscess

↓

Fistula formation

Treatment

  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Systemic analgesics
  • Hot fomentation
  • No Surgical intervention

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is referred to the ophthalmology clinic by her primary care physician, complaining of deteriorating vision in her right eye that had started four months prior without accompanying pain. She was a known case of squamous cell carcinoma of the left lung. A detachment was seen in the lower part of the retina during her ophthalmoscopic examination. In addition, any plaques, tumor masses, and metastases were absent. She was then diagnosed with unilateral paraneoplastic exudative retinal detachment. Which of the following condition causes exudative retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Toxemia of pregnancy

  • Pre eclampsia is defined as systolic blood pressure more than or equal to 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure more than or equal to 90 mm Hg or higher, on two occasions at least 4 hours apart in a previously normotensive patient.
  • In addition to this criterion, proteinuria of more than 0.3 gms in a 24-hour urine specimen or a PCR ratio of 0.3 or greater is required to diagnose preeclampsia.
  • The patient may present with retinal involvement as well.
  • Exudative retinal detachment can be found in 1-2% of the cases with preeclampsia/eclampsia.
  • Subretinal fluid accumulates in the space between the neurosensory retina and the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to leakage of vessels resulting in retinal detachment. Exudative retinal detachments have a convex configuration, no retinal breaks, and no holes or tears.

 

Underlying disease classification

Examples

Neoplastic

Choroidal melanoma

Choroidal metastasis

Choroidal haemangioma

Retinoblastoma

Inflammatory

Vogt-Koyanagi – Harada disease

Posterior scleritis

Sympathetic opthalmia

Infectious

Toxoplasmosis

Syphilis

Tuberculosis

Vascular

Coats disease

Malignant hypertension

Eclampsia or pre – eclampsia

Congenital

Morning glory syndrome

Optic nerve head pit

Coloboma

Nanophthalmos

 

Option B: Lattice Degeneration

  • Peripheral retinal degeneration comprises localized retinal thinning, overlying vitreous liquefaction, and marginal vitreoretinal adhesion.
  • Associated with atrophic retinal holes, retinal tears, and retinal detachments.
  • Patients are generally asymptomatic, and the lesions are usually an incidental finding of dilated ocular examination.
  • There can be blurriness in the distance due to myopia, commonly presented with lattice degeneration.
  • The sudden onset of floaters, flashes of light, peripheral field loss, or central vision loss may indicate the presence of retinal detachment.

Option C: CMV Retinitis

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis is an acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)-related opportunistic infection.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is an important ocular AIDS-associated illness. It is a full-thickness retinal infection that can lead to necrosis, retinal breaks and detachments, and blindness.
  • Most patients are without symptoms, but few may experience floaters, flashes and blind spots.

Option D: Diabetic retinopathy

  • Diabetic retinopathy can cause tractional retinal detachment or combined rhegmatogenous-tractional retinal detachment.
  • It does not lead to the development of exudative retinal detachment.
  • It has different stages depending on the severity.
  • Stage 1: background retinopathy
  • Stage 2: pre-proliferative retinopathy
  • Stage 3: proliferative retinopathy
  • Diabetic maculopathy

questions.text: The shoulder joint is formed by the articulation of the Head of the Humerus with the glenoid cavity (or fossa) of the scapula. This gives rise to the alternate name for the shoulder joint – the glenohumeral joint. Which of the following is the most important ligament to maintain its stability?
questions.solution:
Option C: Inferior Glenohumeral ligament

Shoulder joint stability:

  • A humeral head surface area larger than glenoid area: 48 × 45 mm versus 35 × 25 mm
  • Bony stability is limited
    • Relies on humeral head inclination (125 degrees) and retroversion (25 degrees)
    • Also relies on slight glenoid retro tilt
  • Inferior glenohumeral ligament (anterior band) - The most important static stabilizer
  • Superior and middle glenohumeral ligaments: secondary stabilizers to anterior humeral translation
  • Inferior subluxation prevented by negative intraarticular pressure
  • Rotator cuff muscles - Dynamic contribution to stability

Option A: Middle Glenohumeral ligament

  • Inferior glenohumeral ligament (anterior band) - The most important static stabilizer
  • Superior and middle glenohumeral ligaments: secondary stabilizers to anterior humeral translation

Option B: Superior Glenohumeral ligament

  • Inferior not the superior glenohumeral ligament is the most important static stabilizer

Option D: Lateral Glenohumeral ligament

  • Although the lateral Glenohumeral ligament takes part in the stabilization of the shoulder joint, it is not the major stabilizing ligament

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a road traffic accident 30 minutes ago. On examination, there is a loss of sensations in the lateral three and a half fingers. Keeping in view the most likely damaged nerve, which of the following is an additional finding likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of sensation on hypothenar eminence

questions.solution:
Option A: Opponens paralysis

  • This is the case of median nerve injury, and sensation is lost over the area supplied by the median nerve.

Median nerve injury Findings

Injury or compression of the median nerve at the wrist (e.g., Carpal tunnel syndrome) can be tested by

1. Pen test for abductor pollicis brevis there is the inability to touch the pen kept above the palm by thumb abduction

2. Ape thumb deformity (In median nerve palsy, the thumb is adducted and laterally rotated and lies in the same plane as the rest of the finger due to unopposed action of extensor pollicis longus (radial nerve) and adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).

3. Loss of opposition

4. Sensory loss lateral 3½ of digits and 2/3rd palm (autonomous zone is the tip of the index and middle finger)

5. Loss of sensation over the thenar eminence

6. Anterior dislocation of the lunate may cause median nerve compression.

Option B: Loss of sensation on hypothenar eminence

  • Occurs in ulnar nerve palsy
  • This patient has a median nerve lesion

Option C: Atrophy of adductor pollicis

  • Supplied by the ulnar nerve

Option D: Extensor pollicis brevis

  • Supplied by the radial nerve

questions.text: A 33-year-old male is brought to the emergency room after sustaining a road traffic accident three hours ago. He is not able to bear weight on his right lower limb. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, his pulse is 102/min, and his respiratory rate is 16/min. On examination, his right leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. Which of the following maneuver can be used to reduce the fracture of the hip?
questions.solution:
Option B: Allis method

  • This patient has shortened, internally rotated, and adducted right leg after sustaining a road traffic accident, indicating a posterior hip dislocation.
  • It is the most common dislocation of the hip.
  • It is treated with closed reduction.
  • Different manoeuvres are used in closed reduction to treat posterior hip dislocation. These are:
    • Allis manoeuvre
    • Lefkowitz manoeuvre
    • East Baltimore lift manoeuvre
    • Bigelow manoeuvre

  • Allis maneuver: The patient lies in a supine position, with the physician standing above the patient.
  • The physician applies inline traction on the ipsilateral leg, flexing the ipsilateral knee to 90°.
  • At the same time, an assistant stabilizes the pelvis against the stretcher for counter traction.
  • Lefkowitz maneuver: The patient is placed in a supine position.
  • The physician stands on the affected side. He places his knee closest to the patient's knee on the same side in the ipsilateral popliteal fossa.
  • The clinician then flexes the patient's leg over his knee, applying a downward force to reduce the hip.
  • East Baltimore Lift maneuver: The patient is placed in a supine position.
  • The physician stands on the affected side, with the assistant on the opposite side.
  • Then both flex their knees, place their arms under the patient's knee on the same side of the affected hip, and rest their hands on each other's shoulders. 
  • The free hand of either then stabilizes the patient's pelvis.
  • A second assistant standing at the foot end applies a downward force on the ankle. In contrast, the other two apply an upward force, extending their knees. This leads to a reduction in hip dislocation.
  • Bigelow maneuver: The patient lies in a supine position.
  • The clinician grasps the ankle with one hand and places the other forearm under the patient's knee on the affected side.
  • The hip is flexed at 90 degrees with the leg in adducted and internally rotated position.
  • While the assistant stabilizes the pelvis, the physician applies force in line with the femur leading to abduction, external rotation, and hip extension.

Option A: Stimson maneuver

  • It is used to reduce an anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • It does not reduce hip dislocation.

Option C: Kocher’s technique

  • It is used to reduce a shoulder (subcoracoid) dislocation.
  • It has no use in hip dislocation.

Option D: Traction- counter traction technique

  • It is used to reduce elbow dislocation.
  • It has no use in reducing hip dislocation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old basketball player who was trying to prevent a basket by rebounding landed incorrectly and got his knee ligament injury. On examination, he has pain in the knee joint. The anterior drawer sign is positive. Joint aspiration shows hemarthrosis. Which of the following is not true about the damaged ligament?

choices.text: It begins just behind the anterior horn of the lateral meniscus on the tibia
It provides proprioceptive inputs to the knee

questions.solution:
Option A: It begins just behind the anterior horn of the lateral meniscus on the tibia

  • The most likely damaged ligament is an anterior cruciate ligament injury.
  • Anterior Cruciate Ligament begins just behind the anterior horn of the medial meniscus, not the lateral meniscus.
  • The anterior cruciate ligament is taut in extension
  • ACL provides proprioceptive inputs to the knee
  • ACL is Intracapsular and extra-synovial

Option B: It is taut in  extension

  •  Anterior cruciate ligament is taut in extension

Option C: It provides proprioceptive inputs to the knee

  •  ACL provides proprioceptive inputs to the knee

Option D: It is extra-synovial

  • ACL is Intracapsular and extra-synovial

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a rash that began three days ago. She has a low-grade fever and muscle aches. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), her pulse is 85/min, and her blood pressure is 126/89 mmHg. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The given condition is caused by an organism not fulfilling Koch's postulates. Which one of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution:
Option A: Treponema pallidum

  • Treponema pallidum does not fulfill Koch's postulates.
  • Robert Koch proposes Koch's postulates.

Koch’s postulates: A microorganism was accepted as the causative agent of infectious disease only when it satisfied all the following criteria:

  • The microorganism must be present in every case of the disease but absent from a healthy host.
  • The suspected microorganism must be isolated and grown in pure culture from lesions of the disease.
  • The isolated organism, in pure culture, when inoculated in suitable laboratory animals, should produce a similar disease.
  • The same microorganism must be isolated again in pure culture from the lesions produced in experimental animals.
  • Most of the human bacterial pathogens satisfy Koch’s postulates except for
    • Mycobacterium leprae (leprosy)
    • Treponema pallidum (syphilis)
  • Both these bacteria are yet to be grown in cell-free culture media.

Option B: Yersinia pestis

  • It is gram-negative bacilli, a bacterial species that causes the bubonic plague (the Black Death). Prairie dogs, squirrels, and rodents are the reservoir of this bacteria.
  • Flea bites can transmit it.

Option C: Bacillus anthracis

  • A spore-forming, gram-positive rod. Produces anthrax toxin (a multicomponent virulence factor comprised of oedema factor, lethal factor, and protective antigen).
  • Unlike other bacteria, it has a poly-D glutamate capsule.
  • Causes cutaneous anthrax and pulmonary anthrax.

Option D: Helicobacter pylori

  • A gram-negative, microaerophilic, spiral-shaped bacterium that typically infects the stomach. 
  • A common cause of peptic ulcer disease and chronic gastritis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents in the outpatient department with complaints consisting of recurrent infections, eczema and thrombocytopenia He has no history of smoking or drinking. He has no positive family history. There are no positive findings on the physical examination. The resident told the house officer that this condition is a combined B and T cell disorder. Which of the following statements is common between B and T cells?
questions.solution:
Option A: Origin from the same cell lineage

  • Both T and B cells originate from the same cell lineage → lymphoid lineage.
  • Differentiation occurs at different sites;

Central lymphoid organs:

  • T-cell mature in thymus.
  • B-cells mature in the bone marrow.

Peripheral lymphoid organs:

  • T-dependent area in a Lymph Node → para cortical area
  • B dependent area in a Lymph Node → cortical Follicle

Spleen:

  • T-dependent area in an LN → around the periarteriolar lymphoid sheath
  • B dependent area in an LN → Germinal Follicle [marginal Zone]

CD markers:

  • T cells → CD1 to CD8
  • B cells → CD10, CD19 to CD23

Option B: Site differentiation

  • The immature B cells migrate to the spleen, where they can differentiate into T1 and T2 stages.
  • The differentiation of T cells occurs in the thymus.

Option C: Antigenic mark

  • The antigenic markers for B cells are CD19 and IgM.
  • The T cell's antigenic markers are CD3 and T cell receptors.

Option D: Both humoral and cellular immunity

  • Humoral immunity: B cells
  • Cellular immunity: T cells

questions.text: A 75-year-old male, an elderly diabetic patient, is brought to the medical outpatient department by his daughter with complaints of altered mental status, headache, and nasal congestion. He has been suffering from these symptoms for a week now. He is also complaining of blurred vision. On examination, he has facial swelling on one side. On the chest X-ray, cavitary lesions are seen. The doctor orders a fungal screen. The biopsy showed LCB-stained periorbital exudates in severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis and showed obtuse angle branching aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option D: Rhizopus species

  • The most likely diagnosis is Rhizopus species.
  • The clinical scenario given in the question suggests Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis caused by Rhizopus species.
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis is a serious fulminating infection, angioinvasive, thrombosis, and ischaemic tissue necrosis.
  • Other clinical forms of Zygomycosis:
    • Pulmonary
    • Gastrointestinal
    • Disseminated
    • Dermal
    • Cutaneous
  • Points in favour of Rhizopus:
    • Non-septate broad hyphae
    • Obtuse angled branching
    • Forms asexual spores: Sporangia
    • Sexual spores → Zygospores

  • Agents of Zygomycosis -
    • Rhizopus
    • Mucor
    • Absidia
    • Apophysomyces
  • Rhizoids arrangement:
    • No rhizoids: Mucor
    • Internodal arrangement: Absidia
    • Directly opposite to sporangia: Rhizopus
  • Zygomycota is aseptate fungi that cause serious infections, primarily in ketoacidosis diabetic and cancer patients.

 

RHINOCEREBRAL MUCORMYCOSIS

Clinical  features

  • Onset with nasal stuffiness, epistaxis and facial pain.

  • Later, proptosis, chemosis and ophthalmoplegia.

  • Fever and Confusion

  • Black necrotic eschar on the nasal turbinates or palate: very characteristic

Other Options

Option A: Candida

  • Yeast-like fungi that usually has pseudohyphae
  • Does not cause Rhinocerebral mycosis.
  • It is a normal commensal of the oral cavity, gut and vagina.
  • It causes problems only if the immunity is decreased or normal skin or mucous membrane is breached.

Option B: Aspergillus

  • Narrow septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching moulds.
  • In immunocompromised patients, Aspergillus can cause Sino-pulmonary infections.
  • It is found on fruits and vegetables in the form of 'black mould' therefore known as a food spoilage organism.

Option C: Penicillium

  • Hyaline thin septate hyphae, vesicles are absent, and conidia arranged as brush border appearance moulds.
  • Causes allergic reactions and infections in people with a weak immune system.

questions.text: A 30 years old male presented with discrete hypopigmented macules on his upper back. The patient works as a labourer in a steel mill. On examination of skin scrapings with 10% KOH under a microscope, spaghetti and meatball appearances were seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option A:  Tinea versicolor

  • The given clinical and microscopic findings are characteristic of Tinea versicolor.
  • Tinea versicolor is caused by Malassezia furfur.
  • It infects people in hot and humid environments or those who sweat easily.
  •  Malassezia furfur is round in shape and produces filaments that give it a characteristic spaghetti and meatball appearance under the microscope.
  • The yeast-like fungus produces azelaic acid, which causes hypopigmentation of the skin.
  • Examination under Wood’s lamp shows yellow fluorescence produced by the yeast.

Other Options

Option B: Tinea corporis

  • Tinea corporis is caused by dermatophytes.
  • It causes enlarging raised red rings with a central area of clearing on the body.
  • Examination of the infected tissue shows characteristic hyphae formed by the causative fungus species.
  • Tinea corporis can be treated with topical azoles or oral terbinafine.

Option C: Mixed mycotic infections

  • Mixed mycotic functions cause several different symptoms and involve different body areas.
  • It may cause systemic symptoms as well.
  • The microscopic examination of the affected tissue shows multiple different shapes and color colonies.
  • Mixed mycotic infections are not the cause of hypopigmentation in this patient.

Option D: Candidiasis only

  • Candidiasis causes infection of the skin and mucosal tissues.
  • Cutaneous lesions caused by candidiasis are found in the intertriginous areas and under the nails.
  • Candidiasis causes erythematous, scaling or moist lesions with sharply demarcated borders. Papular lesions are most common in candidiasis.
  • Mucosal lesions include oral thrush and vaginitis.
  • Gram-stained smears from lesions show budding gram-positive cells.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the hospital by his wife with a history of high-grade fever with chills and rigors for the previous two days. He also has mild chest pain and a productive cough. X-ray chest showed consolidation in the right lower lobe. The sputum culture is sent to a lab for further confirmation of the diagnosis. The direct smear from sputum is shown in the image below. On the basis of Gram staining, what is the probable cause of infection?
questions.solution:
Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the probable cause of infection.
  • The Gram staining in the Question shows Gram-positive diplococcus, which is a characteristic feature of Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • None of the other organisms in the options given is Gram-positive diplococci. Hence, excluded.
  • The shape of diplococci is lanceolate (lancet) or flame-shaped.
  • The most common causative organism for lobar pneumonia culture is the Draughtsman-like appearance or carrom coin appearance.
  • There are many serotypes of Streptococcus pneumonia, but only a few can cause pneumococcal infections.
  • It is known as one of the main causes of community-acquired pneumonia and also meningitis.

 

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes

  • Gram-positive cocci in chains.

  • They are catalase negative.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes cause suppurative and non-suppurative manifestations, most of which are contagious.
  • They spread through cough, sneezing, or shared food.

Option C: Neisseria meningitidis

  • Gram-negative diplococci, lens-shaped, capsulated

  • They are often found as the causative agent of meningitis.

Option D: Klebsiella pneumonia

  • Gram-negative bacilli, associated with red currant jelly sputum.

  • It is a Gram-negative facultative anaerobe.
  • Klebsiella pneumonia can be dangerous in already immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the physician with complaints of profuse watery diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting for 5 days. The patient specified that his stools looked like rice water. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The condition was diagnosed as cholera by the physician. Which of the following serotype causes the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: V. cholerae O1 and O139

  • This is a case of cholera in which the patient presents with complaints of profuse watery diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting for 5 days.
  • V. Cholerae O1 and O139 cause cholera.
  • Cholerae is serotyped based on 'O' antigen into several 'O' serotypes.
  • V. cholerae O139 has clinical features similar to O1.
  • Known as Bengal V. cholerae, it was isolated from Bengal in 1992.
  • Features of V.cholerae O1 and O139:
  • O1 and O139 produce the cholera toxin (Mechanism is shown in the image below):
  • O1 and O139 cause cholera, with the following features:
  • Rice watery stool.
  • Shortest incubation period: 1-2 days
  • Infective dose: 106-8 bacilli.
  • Transmission: Feco-oral, direct contact.

Option A: V. Cholerae O1

  • Has 2 Biotypes: Classical and El Tor.
  • Three subserotypes: Ogawa, Inaba, and Hikojima.

Option C: V. Cholerae O139

  • Clinical features are similar to O1.
  • Known as Bengal V. cholerae, it was isolated from Bengal in 1992.

Option D: NAG vibrios

  • Non Agglutinable Vibrio ,Not agglutinated in 01 serum ,Does not cause cholera.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male paddy field worker presents to the physician with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, chills, muscle ache, jaundice and vomiting for 5 days. He gives a history of no other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The patient was sent to the laboratory for sample testing, and the microbiologist found the causative organism, as shown in the image below. Which of the following organism is involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Leptospira

  • This is a case of leptospirosis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, chills, muscle ache, jaundice and vomiting for 5 days.
  • Leptospirosis is an infection caused by corkscrew-shaped bacteria called Leptospira.
  • Associated with:
    • R → Rat urine
    • R → Rice [Paddy fieldworkers]
    • R → Rainy water
  • Leptospira interrogates → causes Weil’s disease (Ictero Haemorrhagic fever)

Culture media :

  • EMOJI
  • Fletcher
  • Kortakoff
  • Dark ground microscopy for Spirochetes:

Option A: Treponema pallidum

  • Treponema pallidum appears as slender, spirally coiled bacilli with a tapering end.
  • It is one of the leading causes of syphilis worldwide.
  • It is usually transmitted via sexual intercourse.

Option C: Borrelia

  • Borrelia appears tightly coiled and thin.
  • Relapsing fever is a recurrent fever caused by Borrelia recurrentis.

Option D: Brucella

  • Brucella is a gram-negative coccobacillus, zoonotic.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with a 10-day history of flu-like symptoms, including anorexia, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and malaise. She is sexually active with multiple partners. On examination, there is right upper quadrant pain, yellow discolouration of skin and sclera of the eyes, and dark urine. Her LFTs are deranged, and AST and ALT are markedly elevated. The causative agent was found to be a DNA virus on molecular diagnosis. Which of the following serological marker best correlates in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anti HBc (IgM)

  • Acute Hepatitis B is indicated by Anti HBc (IgM).
  • 10-day history of flu-like symptoms indicates acute infection.
  • Anti-HBc 
    • IgM anti-HBc is a marker of ‘acute Hepatitis B’.
    • Anti-HBc is a marker of ‘chronic Hepatitis B’.

Look at the following graph for an understanding of Hepatitis B antigens:

  • Hepatitis B is a preventable liver infection mostly transmitted through blood, semen, or body fluids.
  • HBV infection symptoms include fever, anorexia, abdominal pain, vomiting, and jaundice. Acute hepatitis might present as fulminant liver failure.
  • Hepatitis B results in injury to hepatocytes and deranged liver function, raising liver enzymes.
  • The treatment of acute cases includes supportive management and Hepatitis B immunoglobulins, while chronic carriers are given antiviral drugs like adefovir, entecavir, interferon alpha, lamivudine, and tenofovir.
  • Hepatitis B vaccination is given at 0, 1, and 6 months.
  • Chronic cases usually complicate Cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option A: HBsAg

HBsAg:

  • Epidemiological marker of hepatitis B infection.
  • The earliest marker is seen in infection.
  • since it is seen in chronic infection, it is ruled out
  • It is present in the serum of patients, and antibodies against this antigen indicate that the patient is non-infectious.

Option B: HBcAg

HBcAg:

  • It is the virus's core protein.
  • It indicates that the infected person has the potential for transmission of disease.
  • HBcAg can’t be detected in serum, but antibody against it can be.

Option C: HBeAg

  • It is a soluble viral protein.
  • Indicates active viral replication.
  • Marker of infectivity for Hepatitis B
  • In acute hepatitis, it disappears soon after ALT peaks.
  • While chronic hepatitis-positive HBeAg indicates a high level of infectivity.

questions.text: An outbreak of severe encephalitis in Malaysia in 1998 and 1999 was caused by the Nipah virus. All are true about this Nipah virus except?
questions.solution:
• Nipah virus is an emerging infectious agent belonging to paramyxoviridae.

  • It was first isolated in Malaysia in 1998, causing encephalitis in domestic pigs, with direct transmission from pigs to humans.

  • There have been Nipah virus infection outbreaks in pigs in Malaysia and Singapore and human disease in Malaysia, Singapore, India and Bangladesh.

  • Typically the human infection presents as an encephalitis syndrome marked by fever, headache, drowsiness, disorientation, mental confusion, coma and death.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency with a high fever, runny nose, and watery eyes for the Last day. He has had a history of progressive fever for the past 5 days, worsening his condition. On examination, his eyes are red, rash on his face, neck, and legs, and general lymphadenopathy. Upon fine needle aspiration (FNA), Warthin- Finkeldey cells are seen. Which of the following condition indicates the presence of these cells?
questions.solution:
Option A: Measles

  • In this case, the patient presents to the emergency with red, watery eyes, a high fever, and a runny nose for the last day. The patient also has had a history of progressive fever for the previous 5 days. There is also a rash on the body upon examination. These symptoms and presentations indicate that patients have a measles infection.
  • There is also general lymphadenopathy for which FNA is performed. The result of this test indicates the presence of Warthin- Finkeldey cells. The cells present in the case of measles and also in HIV infection.
  • These multinucleated giant cells have numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions in the lymphoid tissue of patients suffering from measles.
  • Various vaccines for measles are available that are very effective in function and prevent the onset of this viral infection.

Option B: Rubella

  • It is a toga virus which is also previously known as German measles. It presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash, and arthralgia.
  • It is very similar to measles in presentation, but koplik spots in measles in the differentiating feature. Warthin- Finkeldey cells are also not present in rubella infection.

Option C: Rabies

  • It is a treatable and preventable viral disease that the bite of a rabid animal can transmit. It causes damage to the CNS and ultimately causes damage to the nervous system.
  • It is bullet shaped virus in which Negri bodies (cytoplasmic inclusions) can be found in the hippocampal neurons. This infection causes the progression of the disease. Fever and malaise lead to photophobia, and hypersalivation, which progresses into paralysis, coma, and death.

Option D: Mumps

  • In this infection, the patient’s parotid glands are swollen. Common symptoms include parotitis, orchitis, and meningitis.
  • Vaccine against this viral infection is very effective, and this infection is uncommon.

questions.text: A known case of papillary carcinoma of the right breast had come to your hospital for surgery. A modified radical mastectomy procedure was done, and on the 2nd postoperative day, the patient presents with the following finding, as shown in the figure below. Which nerve would have been damaged during the operative procedure?
questions.solution:
Option B: The long thoracic nerve of Bell

  • The finding in the image given above is winging of the scapula.
  • Winging of the scapula is seen after mastectomy due to long thoracic nerve injury.
  • The long thoracic nerve of the Bell:
    • Courses closed to the chest wall on the axial side of the axilla were encountered during axillary dissection.
    • Also known as the external respiratory nerve of Bell.
    • Innervates serratus anterior - It fixes the scapula to the chest wall during shoulder adduction and arm extension.
    • Division of this nerve results in winged scapula deformity.

Option A: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • Supplies the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles
  • Its injury can cause weakness in the elbow or shoulder flexion, atrophy of the biceps brachii, and pain or paresthesia at the lateral forearm.

Option C: Intercostobrachial nerve

  • Intercostobrachial nerve supplies sensation to the undersurface of the upper arm and skin of the chest wall along the posterior axilla. Injury to this nerve results in cutaneous anesthesia in these areas.

Option D: Thoracodorsal nerve

  • Encountered during axillary dissection
  • Innervates latissimus dorsi
  • Injury can cause weakness of internal rotation and abduction of the shoulder.

questions.text: A 49-year-old post-menopausal female presents to the surgical OPD with complaints of breast heaviness and purulent discharge from her left breast for the past 20 days. On physical examination, a mass is felt in the left breast that is hard and immobile on contracting the ipsilateral pectoralis major. The breast does not fall forward on leaning forward. No skin changes were noted. What is the T stage of this patient's cancer?
questions.solution:
Option B: T4a

  • The breast does not fall forward on leaning forward, which is suggestive of chest wall fixity. Hence the T stage is T4a

Stage

Size of tumor

T1

up to 2 cm

T2

2-5 cm

T3

>5 cm

T4a

Extension to the chest wall (chest wall is formed by Ribs, Intercostal muscles, and Serratus Anterior)

T4b
  • Ulceration
  • oedema including Peau d'orange
  • Satellite nodules

T4c

T4a + T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer

Not included in T4

  • Involvement of the dermis alone
  • Nipple retraction/ deviation
  • Involvement of Pectoralis major/ Pectoralis minor

 

Option A: T3

  •  In the T3  staging of breast cancer, the tumor size is greater than 5cm; however, it has not penetrated the chest wall or the skin.

Option C: T4b

  • Ulceration, ipsilateral satellite skin nodules, or skin edema, including peau d'orange skin appearance in breast skin, is visible.

Option D: T4c

  • In the T4c stage of breast cancer, the combination of T4a and T4b  is seen. In addition to the involvement of the underlying chest wall, skin involvement is noted in T4c.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not exhibit the given histological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option A: Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid

  • The follicular carcinoma of the thyroid does not show psammoma bodies.
  • Psammoma bodies:
    • Psammoma bodies are round concentric lamellated microscopic calcified lesions.
    • It occurs due to dystrophic calcification in the cancer cells. The necrotic cells form the focus for surrounding calcific deposition leading to the formation of a lamellated concentric calcified structure.
    • The ultrastructural study of the formation occurs after the thickening of the base lamina in the vascular stalk of neoplastic papillae, followed by thrombosis, calcification, and tumor cell necrosis. In other cases, it is formed by collagen production and subsequent calcification.
    • It is suggested that psammoma bodies may represent an active biologic process ultimately leading to degeneration/death of tumor cells and retardation of growth of the neoplasm (i.e. acting as a barrier against the spread of neoplasm).
  • Follicular carcinoma show follicles with a lumen devoid of colloid. The hallmark is the presence of capsular and vascular invasion. The image below shows the capsular invasion.

Other Options

Option B: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid

  • Papillary thyroid cancer shows psammoma bodies formed due to thrombosis, calcification, and tumor cell necrosis.

Option C: Meningioma

  • Meningioma show psammoma bodies and are visible as lamellated concentric calcified structures.

Option D: Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary

  • Psammoma bodies are an important microscopic finding seen in ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy presents with a cystic, compressible swelling that is translucent and trans-illuminates in the posterior triangle of the neck.



Which of the following is the most likely etiology in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cystic hygroma

  • This patient is most likely suffering from cystic hygroma.
  • Cystic hygroma is a multi-loculated cystic space lined by endothelial cells.
  • It occurs due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac from the lymphatic system.
  • Cysts are filled with clear lymph and are lined by endothelium.
  • Turner's syndrome is associated with cystic hygroma.
  • Most cystic hygromas involve the lymphatic jugular sacs
  • The most common site is the posterior neck region (Posterior triangle of the neck), as shown in the image below:

  • Other common sites for cystic hygroma development include:
    • Axilla
    • Mediastinum
    • Inguinal and retroperitoneal regions
  • The clinical features of cystic hygroma include:
    • A soft cystic mass on the neck's posterior aspect that distorts the surrounding anatomy can result in acute airway obstruction.
    • Usually manifests in neonates or early infancy (50% present at birth).
    • Brilliantly translucent and trans-illuminates
  • Diagnostics work-up involves ultrasonography
  • The treatment is not indicated in some cases, as some may regress spontaneously. However, surgical excision is indicated occasionally.

Option B: Branchial cyst

  • A branchial cyst presents as a painless mass lateral to the midline, usually anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which does not move with swallowing.
  • However, the mass described in this vignette is found on the neck's posterior aspect, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Option C: Thyroglossal cyst

  • A Thyroglossal cyst is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct that forms during the embryonic development of the thyroid gland.
  • It typically presents as a painless midline neck mass that elevates with swallowing and tongue protrusion. However, the mass described in this vignette is found on the neck's posterior aspect, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Option D: Dermoid cyst

  • It is a mature cystic teratoma on the head, neck, spine, cranium, and abdomen (the most common ovarian tumour in females).
  • However, the dermoid cyst is not translucent and does not typically trans-illuminate, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 6-month-old female infant presents to the surgical outpatient department with a unilateral cleft lip and palate deformity known before birth by 3D ultrasound. Her cleft lip and soft palate were repaired one month ago. Considering the types of cleft lips, which is the most common type of cleft lip?

choices.text: Cleft Lip Combined with Cleft Palate

questions.solution:
Option C: Cleft Lip Combined with Cleft Palate

  • The commonest type of cleft lip is a cleft lip combined with a cleft palate.
  • Cleft lip and cleft palate can occur separately as well as together.
  • These orofacial defects have a multifactorial inheritance.
  • They can be diagnosed on a prenatal ultrasound.
  • A cleft lip can be repaired through the Millard technique and Tennison-Randall technique, while a cleft palate can be repaired through palatoplasty.
  • If the patient has a cleft lip combined with a cleft palate, then the lip is repaired at 6 months, and the palate is repaired at 18 months.
  • The typical distribution of cleft types is:
    • cleft lip alone: 15%
    • cleft lip and palate: 45%
    • Isolated cleft palate: 40%

Option A: Bilateral Cleft Lip

  • A bilateral cleft lip is a common birth defect in which a baby's lip doesn't form properly, resulting in splits (clefts) on both sides of the lip.
  • A bilateral complete cleft lip, which has been previously treated with nasoalvoelar moulding, is repaired with the Millard-Mulliken technique, which employs reconstruction of the orbicularis oris muscle by advancing bilateral muscular segments.

Option B: Midline Cleft Lip

  • A Median or midline cleft lip is defined as any congenital vertical cleft through the centre of the lip.
  • It can occur as a sporadic event or as a part of an inherited sequence of anomalies.
  • It arises due to the incomplete merging of the medial nasal prominences, which form the inter-maxillary segment.

Option D: Unilateral Cleft Lip

  • The unilateral cleft lip deformity is characterized by progressive tissue deficiency and tethering of structures to either side of the cleft.
  • On the medial side, the lip is short, the philtral column is flattened, and the vermilion is narrow.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of sore throat, dysphagia, odynophagia, and hoarseness for six months. He has no history of a chronic medical condition and is not currently on any medications. His BP is 130/85, his pulse is 65/min, and his BMI is 20 kg/m2. A physical examination of the oropharynx reveals an ulcer on the posterior pharyngeal wall. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of pharyngeal carcinoma with the involvement of multiple neck nodes. The surgeon decides to perform a neck dissection for neck nodal involvement. Which of the following neck dissections spares only the spinal accessory nerve?
questions.solution:
Option A: Type 1 modified radical neck dissection
