  • Neck dissection is one of the major surgeries done to remove lymph nodes affected by cancer metastasis. It is done under general anaesthesia.
  • The amount of tissue and lymph node removed depends on how far cancer has been spread.
  • MRND (Modified radical neck dissection)
    • Also known as functional neck dissection, which involves the removal of the lymph nodes I-V
    • All three structures that are involved in the SIS pneumonic are preserved in MRND
    • There are three types of MRND:
      • Type 1 MRND: Spinal accessory nerve is preserved
      • Type 2 MRND: Spinal accessory nerve and internal jugular vein are both preserved
      • Type 3 MRND: All three structures are preserved (aka functional neck dissection)

 

Option B: Selective neck dissection

  • Selective neck dissection involves the cervical lymphadenectomy in which there is the preservation of one or more of the lymph node groups that are routinely removed in the radical neck dissection.
  • The lymph node groups removed are based on the patterns of metastases, which are predictable relative to the primary site of the disease.

Option C: Radical neck dissection

  • Radical neck dissection involves the removal of tissue from the jawbone to the collarbone.
  • Muscles, spinal accessory nerves, salivary glands, and major blood vessels, including all lymph nodes present in the neck and their interconnecting lymphatics, are removed in radical neck dissection.

Option D: Type 4 modified radical neck dissection

  • There are only three sub-types of modified radical neck dissection. Type 1 radical neck dissection spares only the accessory nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old bus driver presents to the hospital with a complaint of pain in the legs. The patient also complains that there is a continuous burning sensation in his left foot. On examination, the doctor notices dilated, tortuous veins on the back side of the left leg. Doppler scan, revealed valve incompetence. The doctor advises him to go for Cockett and Dodd's operation. Cockett and Dodd's operation is for:
questions.solution:
Option B: Sub-fascial ligation

  • Cocket and Dodd's operation is a Sub-fascial ligation of incompetent perforators.
  • Dilated and torturous veins with valve incompetency showed that it is a case of varicose veins.
  • In Cocket and Dodd's operation, perforators are ligated deep to the deep fascia through incisions in the anteromedial side of the leg.
  • It avoids the recurrence of the disease.

Option A: Saphenofemoral flush ligation

  • It is the isolated ligation of the saphenofemoral junction.
  • It is an effective treatment for a chronic leg ulcer.

Option C: Deep vein thrombosis

  • In this, clot forms in the deep vein.
  • For deep vein thrombosis, blood thinners are given.

Option D: Diabetic foot

  • Diabetic foot occurs due to uncontrolled diabetes.
  • Treatment of diabetic foot depends on the condition of the foot.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male who is a known case of hypertension for 30 years and ischemic heart disease presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden-onset excruciating central chest pain radiating to the back, associated with shortness of breath and dizziness. He has unequal blood pressure in the bilateral upper limbs. A thoracic MRA was performed as shown below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Thoracic aortic aneurysm

  • The image of Thoracic magnetic resonance angiography reveals a clear saccular mid-descending thoracic aortic aneurysm with a locally contained leak and periaortic inflammation.
  • An aortic aneurysm is pathological dilatation of the aorta. It can be either an abdominal aortic aneurysm or a thoracic aortic aneurysm.
  • The abdominal aortic aneurysm will present as a palpable pulsatile abdominal amass.
  • Thoracic aortic aneurysms are those occurring distal to the left subclavian vein.
  • A thoracic aortic aneurysm is associated with cystic medial degeneration.
  • Risk factors for thoracic aortic aneurysm: hypertension, bicuspid aortic valve, Marfan syndrome, tertiary syphilis.
  • When a patient presents with sudden onset chest or abdominal pain radiating to the back, it is a sign of leaking, dissection, or imminent rupture.
  • Unequal blood pressure in bilateral arms is another classic presentation in aortic aneurysm rupture.
  • The risk for rupture is increased with the following:
    • Increasing aneurysm size
    • Advanced age
    • History of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
    • Concurrent dissection.
      • Where anticoagulation is not a risk factor for rupture.

Option A: Subclavian Steal Syndrome

  • It refers to the subclavian artery stenosis proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery leads to hypoperfusion distal to the stenosis.
  • Clinical presentation: arm ischemia, pain, paresthesia, vertebrobasilar insufficiency (dizziness, vertigo).
  • Associated with arteriosclerosis, Takayasu's arteritis, and heart surgery.

Option C: Atherosclerosis

  • It is a disease of elastic arteries and large-and medium-sized muscular arteries.
  • It is caused by a buildup of cholesterol plaques in the intima.
  • Most commonly occurs in the abdominal aorta.
  • Symptoms: chest pain, claudication, or can be asymptomatic.
  • It can lead to abdominal aortic aneurysms, ischemia, infarcts, thrombus, and emboli.

Option D: Cardiac tamponade

  • Compression of the heart by fluid accumulation in pericardial space.
  • It leads to decrease cardiac output.
  • Clinical findings include pulsus paradoxus and Beck triad:
    • Hypotension
    • Distended neck veins
    • Distant heart sounds
  • ECG will show low-voltage QRS and electrical alterations.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with hypertension for 20 years but not compliant with medications comes to the emergency room with sharp chest pain radiating to the intra-scapular region. He also has back and abdominal pain radiating to his leg. On examination, the lower limb shows pallor and weak pulses. His CT and MRI of the abdomen show a tear in the wall of the abdomen. He has smoked 20 packs per year. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Descending aortic dissection

  • The patient with Descending aortic dissection presents with chest pain, abdominal pain radiating to the leg, and back pain.
  • The weak pulses of the lower limb are due to low blood supply. The back pain is due to the involvement of dissection to renal arteries. If mesenteric arteries are involved, abdominal pain will also be the presenting feature of aortic dissection.
  • The causative factors in this case are:
    • Hypertension (causing wall tear of the aorta)
    • Non-compliance to anti-hypertensives
    • Age > 60 years
  • The management is to control blood pressure, and if symptoms persist, surgery is indicated, i.e. grafting the damaged part of the aorta.

Option A: Ascending aortic dissection

  • The patient presents with cough, breathing difficulty, or stroke.
  • The pain in the abdomen, leg and back is usually not the presenting feature.  

Option B: Abdominal aortic aneurysms

  • IOC for screening of Abdominal aortic aneurysms is USG
  • Most common symptom: Chronic vague abdominal pain/back(retroperitoneal)
  • Most common and lethal complication of aneurysm: Rupture.

Option D: Thoracic aortic aneurysms

  • The CT scan and MRI show the presence of a tear of the aorta, not the dilatation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female arrives at the medical emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain and a nonproductive cough that has lasted 6 hours. The presence of frequent headaches is the only significant medical history. On admission, the patient has no dyspnea, and physical examination demonstrates a slight decrease in breath sounds over the left hemithorax. Heart sounds are normal, and there is no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema. A chest radiograph demonstrates the presence of a left-sided pneumothorax. Which of the following percentages of pneumothorax needs operative treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: 20%

  • On chest radiography, if symptomatic, pneumothorax of approximately 25% or larger generally requires needle aspiration, and tube thoracostomy is to be done if it fails.
  • Pleurodesis is done in patients undergoing video-assisted thoracic surgery (VATS) to occlude pleural space.
  • Lung collapse occurs when the air pushes on the outside of the lung or air leaks into the dehiscence between the chest wall and lung, this causes pneumothorax. A pneumothorax can collapse a complete lung, or only a portion of the lung collapses.
  • Major causes of pneumothorax include chest injury that is blunt or penetrating, some specific medical procedures, and underlying lung disease that can also cause damage.
  • Major symptoms generally include sudden pain in the chest and shortness of breath. It can be a life-threatening event in some cases. And there might be no obvious reason for it.
  • To treat a pneumothorax, a needle or chest tube is inserted between the ribs to remove the excess air. However, usually, a small pneumothorax can heal on its own.

Option A: 10%

  • Over time a small pneumothorax may go away on its own. The physician may use a needle to escape air around the lung so it can fully expand. The patient only needs some oxygen treatment and rest.
  • Symptoms often resolve within 24 hours, usually even without treatment. In patients with a small pneumothorax, the physical examination may be normal.

Option C:  30%

  • In large (25% or apex to cupula distance > 3 cm) pneumothorax, there are persistent symptoms in the inpatient.
  • Treatment includes chest tube placement.
  • The most definitive initial treatment of a large pneumothorax is the chest tube (or intercostal drain). An area under the axilla, called the "safe triangle", is ideal for inserting a chest tube as the damage to internal organs can be avoided.

Option D: 40%

  • In large pneumothorax (40%), and mostly in cases of tension pneumothorax, chest tubes are the only option to treat as they cannot respond to needle aspiration.
  • In this method, a one-way-valve system allows the air to only escape and not re-enter the chest.

questions.text: A newborn exhibits respiratory distress and cyanosis, accompanied by X-ray evidence of multiple bowel loops within the thoracic cavity and a mediastinal shift, what is the most frequently encountered type of defect associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bochdalek 

  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia: 
    • The overall incidence of Bochdalek hernia is 1:2000 to 1:5000.  
    • It occurs due to the failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus.  
    • Abdominal contents herniate into the thoracic cavity compressing the ipsilateral developing lung.  
    • Patients have respiratory distress and cyanosis at birth.  
    • Clinical features:
      • Includes grunting respiration, chest retractions, dyspnea, and cyanosis with the scaphoid abdomen.  
      • Decreased breath sounds, along with bowel sounds, are heard on auscultating the chest.  
      • Shifting of heart sounds to the right. 
    • Diagnosis:
      • Diagnosis made prenatal at 15 weeks of gestation with ultrasound. 
      • Ultrasound findings include herniated abdominal viscera in the chest, changes in liver position, and a mediastinal shift away from the herniated viscera.  
      • Chest radiograph demonstrates multiple bowel loops in the thoracic cavity along with mediastinal shift. 
    • Management: 
      • Immediate securing of the airway with endotracheal intubation is critical. 
      • To minimize the degree of pulmonary hypertension, inhaled nitric oxide may be administered. 
      • After achieving hemodynamic stability, the diaphragmatic repair is done. 
      • Fetal tracheal occlusion is an experimental prenatal therapy for the treatment of severe congenital diaphragmatic hernia that reverses lung hypoplasia. 

Option B: Morgagni 

  • It is not the most commonly occurring diaphragmatic hernia in newborns. 

Option C: Paraesophageal type I 

  • Paraesophageal type I is also called a Sliding hernia.
  • It is not the most commonly occurring diaphragmatic hernia in newborns. 

Option D: Paraesophageal type III 

  • Paraesophageal type III is also called a Mixed paraesophageal hernia
  • Herniation of both GE junction of fundus of stomach.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with complaints of epigastric pain. The pain is burning in nature, with no associated vomiting or diarrhea. She had multiple similar episodes in the past. There is no recent history of travel or unsafe intercourse. Vital signs are within normal range. The patient has an endoscopy, which reveals a type III gastric ulcer. Which of the following portions of the stomach is most likely associated with a gastric ulcer type III?
questions.solution:
Option C: Prepyloric region

  • According to Modified Johnson's Classification of Gastric Ulcer, Type III gastric ulcer is associated with the prepyloric region of the stomach that is located within 2-3 cm of the pylorus.
  • In this type of ulcer, acid secretion will be high.
  • Its rate of occurrence is 20%.
  • It has the following complications:
  • Bleeding
  • Perforation
  • Obstruction

Option A: Lesser curvature

  • According to Modified Johnson's Classification of Gastric Ulcer, Type I gastric ulcer is associated with lesser curvature near incisura angularis.
  • It is the most common type of gastric ulcer.
  • Its rate of occurrence is 60%.
  • The acid secretion will be low or normal in this ulcer.

Option B: Body

  • According to Modified Johnson's Classification of Gastric Ulcer, Type II gastric ulcer is associated with the body of the stomach and duodenum.
  • Its rate of occurrence is 15%.
  • In this type of ulcer, acid secretion will be high.

Option D: Gastroesophageal junction

  • According to Modified Johnson's Classification of Gastric Ulcer, Type IV gastric ulcer is associated with Gastroesophageal junction (GE junction).
  • Its rate of occurrence is less than 10%.
  • In this type of ulcer, acid secretion will be normal.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with fever and worsening abdominal pain in the left lower quadrant for 3 days has localized peritonitis in the same area, along with early signs of sepsis. His CBC shows a WBC count of 19.7× 10³ per u/L. A plain CT of the abdomen and pelvis reveals a fluid-filled collection (abscess) in the left lower quadrant associated with complicated diverticulitis and adjacent linear air. What is the commonest site of this abscess formation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pelvis

  • The given scenario is a classic case of intraperitoneal abscess formation owing to the rupture of diverticulitis, as is evident by the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity in association with the diverticulitis and fluid-filled collection (abscess).
    • The commonest site of abscess formation is the pelvis owing to being the dependent part of the body while standing erect. Fluid accumulates in the pelvis due to the effect of gravity.

Option A: Lesser Sac

  • It’s very unlikely for an intraperitoneal abscess to accumulate in the lesser sac except for the one resulting from perforation of the posterior wall of the stomach.

Option B: Greater Sac

  • The greater sac is not the dependent part of the body while sitting or standing; therefore, it's less likely for the purulent fluid to accumulate in the greater sac.

Option D: Paracolic Gutter

  • Purulent fluid accumulates in the right and left paracolic gutters only when supine. Even lying supine, the hepatorenal pouch is relatively deeper than the paracolic gutters, thus raising the probability of fluid accumulating and abscess formation in that pouch in bed-ridden patients.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with colicky pain in the lower abdomen. He also complains of absolute constipation. After performing a physical examination, an X-ray is ordered. The abdominal X-ray findings are given below:



Which of the following is the preferred treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Colonoscopic detorsion followed by elective sigmoid colectomy

  • Given Abdominal X-ray: Coffee bean sign / Omega sign / Bent inner tube suggestive of Sigmoid volvulus.
  • Gastrograffin enema shows a narrowing at the site of volvulus and a pathognomonic bird's beak
  • Treatment of sigmoid volvulus:
    • Colonoscopic detorsion
    • After 3 days of sigmoid colectomy (as the risk of recurrence is high)

Option A: Colonoscopy detorsion

  • Colonoscopy detorsion is one of the steps in the management of the volvulus
  • However, the process should be followed by elective sigmoid colectomy

Option B: Elective sigmoid colectomy

  • Elective sigmoid colectomy is done only after the colonoscopy detorsion

Option C: Air enema

  • Air enema is helpful in intussusception cases but not in the case of volvulus

questions.text: A one-year-old child was brought to the pediatric emergency department by his parents with complaints of the passage of a large amount of reddish stool; according to the parents, the stool was jelly-like. On examination, the patient appears lethargic, dehydrated, and agitated. His abdomen was soft and non-tender. Technetium-99 scintigraphy was performed to confirm the diagnosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Meckel’s Diverticulum

  • Meckel’s diverticulum can clinically present with the passage of a large amount of painless fresh per rectal bleeding.
  • Technetium-99 scintigraphy, also known as Meckel’s scan, is done to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Due to persistent omphalomesenteric duct / vitello-intestinal duct.
  • Congenital is found on the anti-mesenteric border of the small intestine.

Option A: Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis

  • The thickening and narrowing of the pylorus part of the stomach cause stenosis in the gastrointestinal pathway.
  • It classically presents in the 2nd or 3rd week of life.
  • It causes projectile and non-bilious vomiting and small, greenish, mucoid, or constipated stools.

 

Option B: Acute Appendicitis

  • Children with acute appendicitis will clinically present with acute onset lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and pyrexia.
  • On examination, tenderness will be found in the right iliac fossa.
  • Treatment: appendectomy.

Option D: Midgut Volvulus

  • Volvulus means twisting or knotting.
  • It can be caused by rotation of the gut around mesentery, causing loss of blood supply to the gut.
  • It clinically presents with acute onset of abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of fresh blood in the stool.
  • An X-ray will show air-fluid levels due to intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old previously well-female was admitted to our hospital with generalized abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. She also gave a history of being operated on for total hip replacement surgery recently. On examination, her abdomen was soft with generalized tenderness and guarding. Laboratory tests showed mild elevation of white cell count. CT scan of the abdomen showed pericholecystic fluid with no gallstones and no gallbladder wall thickening. What is the best next step in the treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cholecystectomy

  • Any blockage of the cystic duct is known as acute cholecystitis. When this occurs in the absence of stones, the diagnosis is acute acalculous cholecystitis
  • The disease process is generally more fulminant than that of calculous cholecystitis and may progress to gangrene and perforation of the gallbladder
  • Ultrasound reveals a thickened gallbladder wall with pericholecystic fluid. HIDA scans make the diagnosis but can have a false positive rate of up to 40%
  • Treatment of choice is cholecystectomy.

Option B: Conservative management

  • Patients of acalculous cholecystitis are at risk of developing gangrene and perforation of the gallbladder.
  • Therefore, cholecystectomy is the procedure of choice.

Option C: Percutaneous cholecystostomy

  • Percutaneous cholecystostomy is done for unstable patients.

Option D: Endoscopic cholangiography + Drainage

  • Acalculous cholecystitis is a fulminant condition; patients are at risk of developing gangrene and perforation of the gallbladder.
  • Therefore, the procedure of choice is cholecystectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best statement about gallstone composition?

choices.text: Most common type of gallstone is mixed
Black stones are hard and radiolucent
Brownstones are most common in the gallbladder
Most common type of gallstone in the Asian population is cholesterol stones

questions.solution:
Option A: Most common type of gallstone is mixed

  • Most common gallstone worldwide is mixed stone > cholesterol stones.
  • Gallstones are classified by their cholesterol content as either cholesterol stones or pigment stones. Pigment stones can be further classified as either black or brown. 
  • Most cholesterol stones (>90%) are radiolucent.
  • Only 10% of the cholesterol stones are radiopaque.
  • In the USA and Europe, 80% are cholesterol or mixed stones, whereas, in Asia, 80% are pigment stones.
  • Pigmented stones are radiopaque and soft

Option B: Black stones are hard and radiolucent

  • Black stones are hard and radiopaque.

Option C: Brownstones are most commonly in the gallbladder

  • Brownstones most commonly occur in the biliary tree and are rare in the gallbladder.

Option D: Most common type of gallstone in the Asian population is cholesterol stones

  • The most common gallstones in Asia / India are pigmented stones.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presented with a history of upper abdominal pain with progressive abdominal distention and edema of the legs accompanied by mild jaundice. She has been on oral contraceptives for 2 years. An abdominal USG shows hepatomegaly and ascites, with evidence of splenic enlargement. The jugular venous pulse is also normal. A venography shows spider web collaterals. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Budd Chiari Syndrome

  • The etiology is Hepatic venous outflow obstruction.
  • It is usually due to Myeloproliferative disorder (e.g., PV), Malignancy (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma), and Oral contraception use/pregnancy.
  • The acute symptoms are Jaundice, hepatic encephalopathy, variceal bleeding, Prolonged INR/PTT, and elevated transaminases.
  • The manifestations are Subacute/chronic Vague, progressive abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites, Mild/moderate elevation in bilirubin, and transaminases.
  • Abdominal Doppler ultrasound shows decreased hepatic vein flow.

Option B: Hepatic hemangioma

  • Hepatic hemangioma, the most common benign liver tumour, is often found incidentally during imaging for other conditions.

Option C: Hepatic adenomas

  • Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumours that often arise in the right lobe of the liver in women on oral contraception (possibly due to the effects of estrogen on hepatocytes, although studies have been inconclusive). However, centripetal enhancement is usually seen on a triphasic CT scan, and no central scar would be present.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma is a malignant liver tumour that usually arises in the setting of chronic liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis, viral hepatitis).
  • Patients are often asymptomatic but may develop weight loss or early satiety.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient comes to the clinic because of pain in the abdomen for the last 1 month. A CT scan of the patient reveals metastatic cancer that has reached the pancreas. Which is the most common primary cancer leading to pancreatic metastasis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Kidney

  • The most common primary cancer site resulting in an isolated pancreatic metastasis is Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
Primary tumour type % of Total
RCC 66
Melanoma 9
Colorectal 8
Sarcoma 6
Breast 4
Ovarian 4
Lung 3
  • Pancreatic metastases are asymptomatic in more than 50% of cases: they are often detected during follow-up investigations after surgery for a primary lesion or as an incidental finding on imaging studies performed for an unrelated condition.
  • At a CT scan, pancreatic metastases may appear as hypervascular lesions, like in renal cell cancer (RCC) metastases, or, as in the case of colon and melanoma metastases, as hypodense masses

Option B: Breast

  • Breast carcinoma can metastasize to the pancreas, but the percentage of Breast carcinoma is 4% Out of the total percentage of metastasis to the pancreas

Option C: Ovary

  • Ovarian cancer is responsible for 4% of metastasis of primary cancer to the pancreas

Option D: Stomach

  • Gastric cancers do not metastasize to the pancreas

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presents to the neurology department with complaints of severe sudden-onset headache associated with vomiting and photophobia for the last 2 hours. He describes his headache as “the worst headache of my life”. He also has neck stiffness. He is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 140/100 mmHg, a pulse rate of 55 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute. His GCS is 10/15, and he has Cushing's triad. His CT brain reveals a hemorrhage due to a rupture of the main artery. Given below is an image of a circle of Willis. Which statement is true about the berry aneurysm on this site?

choices.text: The most common site is the anterior communicating artery-anterior cerebral junction
Rupture of aneurysm usually occurs at the bottom of Willis
Surgical clipping is preferred over endovascular coil occlusion

questions.solution:
Option B: Most common site is the anterior communicating artery-anterior cerebral junction

  • The case mentioned above has features of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and Berry aneurysm is the most common cause of intracranial hemorrhage.
  • The most common site is the anterior communicating artery-anterior cerebral junction in the circle of the Willis.
  • Intracranial aneurysm (saccular ‘berry’ aneurysms)  accounts for around 85% of cases.
  • Intracranial aneurysms are at risk of rebleeding and require prompt intervention, preferably within 24 hours.

Option A: Rare type of intracranial aneurysm

  • The most common type of intracranial aneurysm is Berry's Aneurysm.

Option C: Rupture of aneurysm usually occurs at the bottom of Willis

  • The intracranial aneurysm always has a risk of rupture.
  • The rupture of an aneurysm usually occurs at the apex or dome.

Option D: Surgical clipping is preferred over endovascular coil occlusion

  • Most intracranial aneurysms are now treated with a coil, but a minority require a craniotomy and clipping.
  • Endovascular coil occlusion is preferred over Surgical clipping.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after a bee sting on her right arm 2 hours ago. She feels pain and itchiness in the affected area. On examination, hives are noted on her right arm, and the site around the sting is swollen, erythematous and warm. On review, her temperature is 36.6°C(98°F), her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, her pulse is 100 beats/min, and her respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min. The relevant systemic examination is unremarkable. Which drug will be used as the first-line drug if this patient goes into anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Option C: Epinephrine 0.5 ml of 1:1000 IM

  • Epinephrine works by constricting the blood vessels, which raises blood pressure. 
  • Anaphylactic Shock: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening type I hypersensitivity reaction caused by releasing chemical mediators from mast cells and basophils. Chemical mediators generate widespread vasodilation. 
  • Signs and Symptoms of anaphylactic shock: 
    • Low blood pressure, tachycardia, lightheadedness.
    • breathing difficulties along with wheezing on chest auscultation. 
    • clammy skin, confusion, anxiety, collapsing or losing consciousness.
  • The most common cause of death in anaphylactic shock is laryngeal oedema; therefore, tracheostomy is often done. 
  • Management of anaphylactic shock is as follows:

Option A: Adenosine 12 mg intravenously

  • It is used for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), not for anaphylactic shock.

Option B: Atropine 3 mg intravenously

  • Atropine is used to treat symptomatic bradycardia. 
  • It is not used as a drug for anaphylactic shock.

Option D: Epinephrine 1 ml of 1:10000 intravenously

  • Intravenous epinephrine is given for cardiac arrest, not for anaphylactic shock.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus attends his annual diabetes review. His reports turn out to have an HbA1c of 8.8%. He also has hypertension and currently takes metformin, aspirin and lisinopril. His routine blood tests detect a reduction in his renal function, with his glomerular filtration rate now being less than 30ml/min. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the current status of this patient?

choices.text: Increased risk of developing metabolic alkalosis
Increased risk of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
Increased risk of developing high anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
Option D: Increased risk of developing high anion gap metabolic acidosis

  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease of beta cells of the pancreas.
  • It is characterized by polydipsia, polyphagia, polyuria, fatigue, weight loss, blurred vision, fungal infections, numbness and tingling of hands and feet, diabetic ketoacidosis, and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state.
  • Treatment of DM type 1 includes insulin replacement. Insulin injections are administered subcutaneously in the abdomen, buttocks, arms, or legs.
  • For type-2 DM, the mainstay of treatment is oral hypoglycemic drugs after conservative management with diet, exercise, and smoking cessation fails.
  • Other agents such as non-insulin injectables, insulin replacement, and weight loss therapies are particularly helpful in lowering blood glucose levels.
  • Oral hypoglycemic drugs include:
    • Metformin is a biguanide. It inhibits hepatic gluconeogenesis and the action of glucagon. It increases glycolysis and peripheral glucose uptake by increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is the first-line agent in treating DM type-2 and can be used as a monotherapy alone.
      • Common side effects of metformin include:
        • Gastrointestinal upset,
        • Vitamin B-12 deficiency.
        • Lactic acidosis(high anion gap metabolic acidosis). Lactic acidosis is particularly severe in patients with renal insufficiency, so it should be used cautiously. It can also cause weight loss. So, a patient taking metformin with decreased glomerular filtration rate has an increased risk of developing high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
    • Sulfonylureas increase insulin release by the pancreatic beta-cells. These are associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain.
    • Thiazolidinediones increase insulin sensitivity and levels of adiponectin. These can cause weight gain, edema, and heart failure.
    • Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors block the absorption of glucose in proximal convoluted tubules. These are associated with glycosuria and an increased risk of urinary tract infections.
    • Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors decrease intestinal absorption of glucose. These can cause gastrointestinal upset.
    • DPP-4 inhibitors block GLP-1 leading to decreased glucagon release.

Option A: Increased risk of developing metabolic alkalosis.

  • Metformin increases the production of lactic acid in the body, leading to metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.

Option B: Decreased risk of developing retinopathy.

  • A patient who has elevated levels of HbA1c indicates poor glycemic control. So, the risk of diabetic complications such as retinopathy is greater

Option C: Increased risk of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

  • Elevated lactic acid levels in the body due to metformin use cause a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis
  • Normal anion-gap metabolic acidosis is caused by diarrhoea, renal tubular acidosis, acetazolamide use, Addison's disease etc.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents to his primary health care physician for further evaluation of hypercalcemia detected incidentally during a routine medical check-up. She is asymptomatic and denies constipation, palpitation, or bone pains. Her laboratory investigations are as follows: 


	
		
			
			Haemoglobin
			
			
			12.2 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Serum
			
			 
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			0.7 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Proteins
			
			 
		
		
			
			Total
			
			
			7.0 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Albumin
			
			
			4.1 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Calcium
			
			
			13.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Phosphorus
			
			
			2.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Alkaline phosphatase

			PTH
			
			
			130 U/L

			72
			
		
	


After administration of normal saline, her serum calcium is 12 mg/dl. The rest of the laboratory investigations, including the cancer screen, are normal. What is the most likely indication for surgery in this patient?

choices.text: Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

questions.solution:
Option D:  Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

  • This clinical vignette is about a patient suffering from primary hyperparathyroidism, the most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (as also seen in this patient).
  • The patient is asymptomatic, but her serum calcium level is more than 11 mg/dL, higher than the normal upper limit. Therefore, this patient needs surgery for the treatment of her condition.
  • Normal calcium levels: 9-11 mg %

Role of surgery in the management of hyperparathyroidism:

  • A more aggressive surgical approach should be considered in most patients due to concerns of subtle neuropsychiatric symptoms, long-term skeletal effects, and potential for cardiovascular deterioration.

Option A: Age >50 years

  • Age of less than 50 years is an indication for surgery of primary hyperparathyroidism

Option B: 24-hour urine for calcium >100 mg/day

  • Urinary excretion of > 400 mg/day of calcium is an indication of surgery

Option C: Osteopenia on bone density testing

  • T score in bone density test between -1 to -2.5 indicates osteopenia

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with complaints of intermittent headaches and palpitations for three months. She also complains of having intermittent abdominal pain. On examination, her blood pressure is 155/95mmHg, and she is noted to have profuse sweating. On workup, with an MRI abdomen, she is found to have an adrenal tumour on the right side. Further workup with nuclear imaging reveals metastasis to the liver. Which of the following is the best treatment for managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: I131-MIBG

  • The patient’s clinical history & findings confirm the diagnosis of malignant Pheochromocytoma.

  • The first line management of malignant Pheochromocytoma is I131- MIBG at monthly intervals over three to six cycles.

  • This is followed by the Averbuch Chemotherapy protocol, including dacarbazine, cyclophosphamide and vincristine.

Option A: Alpha blockers

  • Alpha-blockers followed by beta blockers are given before surgical management of benign Pheochromocytoma.

Option B: Chemotherapy

  • Chemotherapy is not a stand-alone treatment for Pheochromocytoma. Instead, it is to be done after I131- MIBG as an adjuvant treatment.

Option C: Bulk-reducing surgery

  • Surgical resection of the tumour is the treatment of choice in case of a localised pheochromocytoma with no metastasis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to your clinic with complaints of severe weakness, loss of interest, weight loss and nausea for the last several months. Her temperature is 97°F, her blood pressure is 100/63 mmHg, and the pulse is 100 beats per minute. On examination, she has skin darkening at elbows, knees, neck, and gums. Her laboratory reports show a low Na+ level and a high K+ level. On further evaluation, she is found to have low cortisol and increased ACTH. What is the most common cause of the condition this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Option D: Addison’s disease

  • This patient has signs and symptoms suggesting Addison’s disease or primary adrenal insufficiency. She has low sodium and increased potassium due to decreased release of mineralocorticoids from the adrenal gland.
  • Her serum cortisol levels are low, causing the symptoms she is experiencing, including low energy, low serum glucose and low blood pressure.
  • She has a darkening of her skin due to the release of MSH with ACTH from the pituitary gland in the case of primary adrenal insufficiency.
  • The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency globally is autoimmunity. Antibodies are formed against the cells of the adrenal gland, and their destruction leads to decrease production and release of adrenal hormones.
  • In developing countries, the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency is Tuberculosis.

Option A: Adrenal Adenoma

  • An adrenal adenoma is a benign tumour of adrenal glands. 
  • Most adrenal adenomas are silent and do not produce any symptoms. However, some of the adrenal adenomas can produce some symptoms due to excess production of adrenal hormones (not under-production).

Option B: Cushing Syndrome

  • Cushing syndrome is the condition of increased production of cortisol. 
  • There can be different causes of excess production of cortisol, including Cushing disease, adrenal tumour, secondary tumour, or excess intake of cortisol from outside.

Option C: Hypopituitarism

  • Hypopituitarism can cause decreased ACTH, which can ultimately cause the decreased release of cortisol from the adrenal gland. This patient has high ACTH and low cortisol, showing that the disorder is affecting the adrenal gland directly and not the pituitary gland.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female presents to the clinic with a beefy red tongue. Laboratory investigations reveal a haemoglobin of 8.9 g/dL. The doctor suspects Plummer Vinson Syndrome. Which of the following is not associated with Plummer Vinson syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option C: Common in elderly male

  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome is also known as sideropenic dysphagia
  • It is prevalent in postmenopausal women
  • It presents with a classic triad of post cricoid dysphagia:
  • Oesophagal webs
  • Iron deficiency anaemia with beefy-red tongue due to hypertrophic glossitis
  • Koilonychia

Option A: Esophageal webs

  • The formation of oesophageal webs results from repeated epithelial damage brought on by iron deficiency, which causes the mucosa to atrophy and the pharyngeal muscles to deteriorate.

Option B: Premalignant

  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome has increased risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma of upper GI tract

Option D: Dysphagia

  • Dysphagia to solids is seen here. 
  • Dysphagia is caused due to thin web in the post-cricoid area

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to the office with the complaint of diarrhoea for the past 3 months. Her stools are bloody. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is made. Which of the following is associated with ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Can involve any site of GIT

questions.solution:
Option B: Strictures are rarely seen

  • Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon.
  • It commonly involves the rectum and may extend proximally and continuously to involve other parts of the colon. 
  • Patients with ulcerative colitis usually present with diarrhoea, which is frequently associated with blood.
  • Associated symptoms include colicky abdominal pain, urgency, and tenesmus.
  • Patients with mainly distal disease may have constipation accompanied by frequent discharge of blood and mucus.
  • Patients may also have a fever, fatigue, and weight loss.
  • Ulcerative colitis primarily involves the intestine but may be associated with several extraintestinal manifestations
  • Stricture formation is not seen and is more familiar with Crohn’s disease.

Option A: Can involve any site of GIT

  • Ulcerative colitis usually involves the colon.
  • The rectum is spared.
  • Crohn’s disease can involve any part of the GIT.

Option C: Histopathology shows non-caseating granulomas

  • Crohn's disease, rather than UC colitis, involves any part of the gut.
  • Moreover, Non-caseating granuloma is seen in CD, not in UC.

Option D: Inflammation is transmural

  • Only mucosa and submucosa are involved in UC.
  • Transmural inflammation is seen in CD.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presented with anaemia & pallor and was found to have acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL). He is on induction chemotherapy with vincristine, L-asparaginase, prednisolone, daunorubicin & intrathecal methotrexate. Which of the following is the most important prognostic marker in patients with ALL?
questions.solution:
Option C: Response to treatment

  • Response to treatment is the most important prognostic marker in ALL.

Option A: Leucocyte count >50000/uL

  • Leucocyte count >50000/uL is associated with a poor prognosis.

Option B: Hyperploidy

  • Hyperploidy is a favourable prognostic factor.

Option D: Organomegaly

  • Organomegaly has a poor prognosis, which indicates the spread of cancer.

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic alcoholic man complains of a burning sensation in the mouth. On examination, he has thickened, dry, smooth tongue without the filiform papillae. Mean corpuscular volume(MCV) is 100 fl. Which of the following should be the first line of approach in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Estimation of Vitamin B12 levels

  • The above-given scenario is likely a case of Vitamin B12 deficiency; hence estimation of Vitamin B12 levels should be the first step. Its deficiency may cause bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration (demyelination) of the spinal cord's cervical and thoracic posterior and lateral (pyramidal) tracts.

 

                                                                    

 

Glossitis

Option B: Brush biopsy

  • It consists of the oral brush biopsy instrument used to rapidly obtain a transepithelial specimen.
  • The sample is spread onto an enclosed glass slide and fixed; the computer system detects potentially abnormal cells by searching for a combination of abnormal cellular morphology unique to the oral epithelium.
  • Brush biopsies are utilized routinely in the detection of precancerous and cancerous lesions.
  • This patient has more likely glossitis due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option C: Start Antifungal therapy

  • The MCV of 100fL and burning sensation suggest glossitis due to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Antifungal therapy is the treatment of oral thrush, which is a white plaque on the tongue that can be scrapped off.

Option D: Incisional biopsy

  • An incisional biopsy is performed on patients with abnormal growth, such as lumps, tumours, and lesions.
  • This patient has more likely glossitis due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male with a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for 25 years presents to his primary physicians with complaints of headache, easy fatigability and hot flushes and pruritus on his legs after taking a bath. His family history is noncontributory, and the physical examination is unremarkable, with no hepatosplenomegaly. Full blood count shows hemoglobin: 21.9g/dl, RBCs: 6.9 × 106/µL, MCV: 60μm3, Hct 55%, WBCs: 16.1 × 103/µL & PLTs: 101 × 103/µL. Further investigations reveal JAK2 mutation. Based on the history and laboratory investigations, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Polycythemia Vera

  • Polycythemia vera (PV, polycythemia rubra vera) is one of the chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), collectively characterized by clonal proliferation of myeloid cells with variable morphologic maturity and hematopoietic efficiency.
  • Signs and symptoms of PV include:
    • Pruritus - following a warm bath or shower.
    • Erythromelalgia - burning pain in the feet or hands associated with erythema, pallor and cyanosis in the presence of peripheral pulses.
    • Transient visual disturbance - transient ocular blindness (amaurosis fugax)
    • Thrombosis and haemorrhage - an increased risk of thrombosis (CVA, MI) and haemorrhage.
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms - epigastric distress, peptic ulcer disease and gastroduodenal erosions.
  • Pathological and laboratory features include:
    • Hemoglobin > 15 g/dl
    • Hematocrit > 36%
    • WBCs > 3000/microL
    • PLTs > 70/microL
    • Elevated Lactate dehydrogenase
    • Decreased serum erythropoietin levels
  • The diagnosis of PV is based on WHO criteria as given:
    • Major criteria
      • Increased haemoglobin level (>16.5 g/dL in men or >16.0 g/dL in women), hematocrit (>49 per cent in men or >48 per cent in women), or other evidence of increased red cell volume
      • Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity for age with trilineage growth (panmyelosis), including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic, mature megakaryocytes (differences in size)
      • JAK2 V617F or JAK2 exon 12 mutation
    • Minor criterion
      • Serum erythropoietin level below the reference range for normal

Option A: Primary Myelofibrosis

  • Primary myelofibrosis is characterized by pancytopenia (decreased count of all cell lines) and hepatosplenomegaly.

Option B: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia

  • Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) is characterized by an unusual rise in WBCs, more than 100,000/microL.
    • BCR-ABL 1 kinase domain mutations are consistent with CML, and these are caused by the swapping of part of the chromosomes between chromosomes 9 and 22.

Option D: Essential thrombocytosis

  • Essential thrombocytosis is characterized by
    • A persistently elevated platelet count of more than 450,000/microL.
    • Megakaryocytic hyperplasia
    • Splenomegaly
    • A clinical course of thrombotic or hemorrhagic manifestations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of dizziness, chest pain and shortness of breath for the past few hours. On examination, JVP rises paradoxically with deep inspiration. All of the following conditions can be considered for diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Atrial fibrillation

  • Atrial fibrillation is an irregular heart rhythm characterized by rapid, chaotic atrial contractions. It does not directly affect the filling of the heart during inspiration or cause Kussmaul's sign.

other options

Option A: Constrictive pericarditis

  • JVP rises on deep sign
  • Kussmaul's sign is seen where the right side of the heart is not functioning correctly.
  • In Constrictive pericarditis, the Right side of the heart will not normally function due to calcification.

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy

  • In Restrictive cardiomyopathy, the heart's right side will not normally function due to fibrosis. As a result, Kussmaul's sign is seen

Option C: Tricuspid stenosis

  • Kussmaul's sign is seen in Tricuspid stenosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to breathlessness and palpitations for 2 days. It is associated with fatigue. Her past medical history includes a history of rheumatic fever (RF) at the age of 15 years. She was prescribed penicillin at that time, but she had been non-compliant. She has no family history of heart disease. Her blood pressure is 123/82mmHg, her pulse is 63/min, and her BMI is 23kg/m2. Auscultation reveals a mid-systolic click followed by a late-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mitral valve prolapse

  • Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is also called Floppy valve syndrome or Barlow syndrome.
  • Causes of MVP include:
  • Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve apparatus
  •  Marfan syndrome
  •  Ehler Danlos syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Anteroposterior diameter decrease
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Ostium secondum atrial septal defect (ASD)​​​​​​​
  • The patients present with palpitations, lightheadedness, shortness of breath and fatigue.
  • The mitral valve presents with mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur.
  • The mid-systolic click occurs due to extra tension generated in the chordae tendineae during exercise.
  • The late systolic murmur occurs due to the leakage of blood into the left atrium.
  • Chest x-ray, echocardiograms, ECG, and cardiac catheterization are used to diagnose mitral valve prolapse.
  • Treatment includes using beta-blockers, diuretics, antiarrhythmics, anticoagulants and antibiotics.
  • Complications include mitral valve regurgitation and arrhythmias.
  • Mitral valve repair or replacement is required in cases of severe mitral regurgitation.

Option B: Hamman-rich syndrome

  • Hamman-rich syndrome is an idiopathic interstitial lung disease.
  • It progresses rapidly and may lead to ARDS and fulminant respiratory failure.

Option C: Rheumatic aortic regurgitation

  • Rheumatic aortic regurgitation causes an early diastolic murmur.
  • A mid-diastolic murmur will be heard in severe aortic regurgitation, called the Austin flint murmur.

Option D: Congenital mitral stenosis

  • The mitral valve controls blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle of the heart, and the narrowing of this valve is known as mitral stenosis.
  • Congenital mitral stenosis leads to mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented to the physician’s office complaining of fatigue, dyspnea, and chest pain. On physical examination, the blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg, and the pulse is 55 beats per minute. An urgent ECG is done, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Second degree AV block type1, intranodal
Second degree AV block type 2, infranodal

questions.solution:
Option C: Second-degree AV block type 2.

Second degree AV block (Mobitz type II)

  • Mobitz type II occurs due to an infra-nodal conduction defect (in the bundle of His) leading to a widened QRS complex, bundle branch block or a fascicular block.
  • It is seen in patients with structural heart disease, such as myocardial ischemia, fibrosis, or sclerosis of the myocardium.
  • Symmetry in PR interval before and after the missed beat indicates second-degree AV block type 2.
  • A suddenly dropped beat leads to a risk of sudden cardiac death. As it has the potential to progress to a complete heart block, it can lead to death.
  • The patients present with fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain, presyncope or syncope and even cardiac arrest. Physical examination reveals bradycardia, hypotension, diaphoretic and pale.

Option A: First-degree AV block, Intranodal

  • ECG changes that include a PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds without atrial to ventricular conduction disruption suggest first-degree AV block.

Option B: Second-degree AV block type 1

  • In Second degree AV block type 1: Occurs due to defective conduction in the AV node leading to a progressive Serial lengthening of PR interval before and after the missed beat.

Option D: Third-degree AV block

  • In Third degree AV block, there is a  complete dissociation between atria and ventricles.
  • It occurs due to a loss of coordination between the SA node and the ventricles via the AV node due to the defect in the distal conduction to the AV node.
  • The ventricles escape by either the AV node junctional escape or the fascicular or ventricular escape.
  • The ventricular rate is 40 beats per minute, and the atrial rate is 100 beats per minute.

questions.text: Certain infectious diseases lead to multisystem involvement. A number of diseases cause atrioventricular nodal block due to the involvement of the cardiac tissue. Which of the following diseases does not cause AV nodal block or any other cardiac complication?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cat scratch disease

  • It is a lymph node infection brought on by a cat bite or scratch.
  • Bartonella henselae bacteria is the root cause of cat scratch illness.
  • A primary lesion is a small painless erythematous papule or pustule that develops at the inoculation site within days to 2 weeks.
  • The presenting symptoms are a red lump on the skin, weariness, and pain. Nearby lymph nodes (axillary/epitrochlear nodes) could enlarge, which is usually painful and suppurate.
  • It causes neurological involvement (encephalopathy, seizures, and peripheral/facial palsies). However, it does not cause AV nodal block.
  • It causes neurological involvement (encephalopathy, seizures, and peripheral/facial palsies). However, it does not cause AV nodal block.

other options

Option A: Chagas disease

  • Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan T.cruzi.
  • It has caused chronic cardiomyopathy and/or digestive tract dysfunction over decades.
  • In patients with cardiomyopathy, bundle branch blocks are usually the first signs. They may cause no symptoms until severe conduction system disease sets in, leading to arrhythmias and left ventricular dysfunction.

Option C: Lyme disease

  • Within several weeks after the onset of the illness, a few patients develop cardiac involvement. The most common abnormality is a fluctuating degree of the atrioventricular block (first-degree Wenckebach or complete heart block).
  • Other patients have more diffuse cardiac involvement, including ECG changes indicative of acute myopericarditis, left ventricular dysfunction, cardiomegaly or fatal pancarditis.
  • This cardiac muscle involvement is for only a few weeks; however, it may recur in untreated patients.

Option D: Toxoplasmosis

  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by the intracellular parasite Toxoplasma gondii.
  • There is clinically evident lymphadenopathy, encephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonitis in both acute and chronic diseases.
  • Immunocompetent are asymptomatic. In contrast, congenitally infected children develop severe neurologic complications, e.g. hydrocephalus, microcephaly, mental retardation and chorioretinitis.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of sharp chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. She has been coughing up blood intermittently, which worsens the pain. She has osteoporosis, for which she takes raloxifene. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


	
		
			pH
			7.52
		
		
			PCO2
			25 mm Hg
		
		
			PO2
			65 mm Hg
		
		
			O2 saturation
			92%
		
	


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pulmonary embolism

  • This patient, with sudden onset of sharp chest pain, shortness of breath, and hemoptysis, is most likely having a pulmonary embolism.
  • DVT is the most common cause of pulmonary embolism (PE). Certain medications, including raloxifene (which this patient is taking for osteoporosis) increases the risk of DVT and PE. In PE, occlusion of one or more of the pulmonary arteries leads to a ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
  • This leads to an increased A-a gradient and hypoxemia. Hypoxemia results in hyperventilation and subsequent respiratory alkalosis because of low PCO2 levels, as shown in this patient's arterial blood gas analysis.
  • The Wells' criteria are widely used to stratify the patients for PE. It helps the physician by providing an estimated pre-test probability of PE, thus enabling the physician to choose what further testing is required to confirm the diagnosis of PE. The Well's criterion is summarized in the following table:
Table 1. Well's criteria
Clinical feature Wells score
Clinical signs and symptoms of DVT  3
Pulmonary embolism most likely diagnosis  3
Heart rate >100 beats per minute  1.5
Immobilisation at least three days or surgery within past four weeks 1.5
Previous DVT or pulmonary embolism  1.5
Haemoptysis  1
Malignancy treatment within six months or palliative 1
DVT, deep venous thrombosis
A Well's score > 4 warrants imaging

Depending upon the Well's score of the patient, the treatment for a suspected case of pulmonary embolism can be tailored as:

Option A: Aortic dissection

  • Aortic dissection does not present with hemoptysis. Rather, it presents with tearing chest pain radiating to the back and blood pressure discrepancy in both arms, which are not seen in the vignette.

Option B: Acute Cor-pulmonale

  • This results from an altered structure (hypertrophy/dilation) or impaired functioning of the right ventricle caused by a primary disorder of the respiratory system such as COPD, cystic fibrosis, interstitial lung disease and pulmonary embolism.
  • The primary respiratory disorder causes acute/chronic pulmonary hypertension, which causes acute/chronic right heart failure. This patient does not have the features of right heart failure.

Option D: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

  • ARDS is a severe inflammatory reaction characterized by non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema and injury to alveolar capillaries and endothelial cells. The important causes include systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), trauma, inhalation injury, aspiration pneumonitis, pulmonary infarction, and transfusion-related acute injury. This patient with no such risk factor is unlikely to have ARDS.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with a stiff neck and decorticate posturing. His blood pressure was 104/60 mmHg with a pulse rate of 126 beats per minute and a temperature of 39°C. Chest and abdominal examinations were unremarkable. After further investigations, he was diagnosed with acute primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. What is the most likely source of infection?

choices.text: Diving or swimming in contaminated water
Using human excrement as vegetable fertilizer

questions.solution:
Option A: Diving or swimming in contaminated water

Primary Amoebic Encephalitis

  • The fulminant central nervous system (CNS) infection known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is caused by the free-living amoeba Naegleria fowleri, which thrives in warm waters of lakes and rivers.
  • PAM develops after inhaling contaminated dust or aspirating water infected with trophozoites or cysts invade the olfactory neuroepithelium. Children and young adults who are otherwise healthy and have recently swum in lakes or heated swimming pools are most likely to get an infection.
  • The use of polluted water for nasal irrigation does occasionally happen.
  • It is diagnosed via a wet mount of cerebrospinal fluid showing motile trophozoites.
  • The treatment of choice is miltefosine and amphotericin B.

Option B: Intravenous drug abuse

  • In injection drug users, CNS infections frequently result in excessive morbidity and death.
  • Embolisation from infected valvular vegetations may result in cerebral infarction, intracranial bleeding, and brain abscess development in injection drug users with infective endocarditis.
  • Without infective endocarditis, localised intracranial infections, such as brain abscesses and spinal epidural abscesses, can develop due to bacteremia that seeds the brain or epidural region.

Option C: Using human excrement as vegetable fertiliser 

  • Because the helminth eggs exist in faeces and may thus be passed from one sick person to another person, using human excrement in agriculture is associated with common parasitic worm illnesses that have faecal-oral transmission of disease, such as ascariasis.

Option D: Eating raw fish or seafood

  • Cholera, anisakiasis, vibrio vulnificus, salmonella, bacillus cereus and listeriosis are the infection caused by eating raw fish or seafood.

questions.text: A young man with a history of hydrophobia and altered sensorium is brought to the ER by his neighbour. Upon examination, the patient was awake and alert but in great distress, with just a slight posterior neck soreness and intact extraocular movement. There was no sign of respiratory distress. A rabies clinical diagnosis was made, and ocular scrapings were taken. Which test is best to confirm his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Viral culture

  • The rabies virus presents as an acute infection of the central nervous system.
  • Individuals can be distinguished between five general stages: incubation, prodrome, acute neurologic phase, coma, and death.
  • The incubation time is typically between one and three months, although it can be as short as ten days or as long as two years.
  • Early diagnosis is challenging. Rabies should be suspected in human cases of unexplained viral encephalitis with a history of animal bites.
  • A diagnosis can be made using virus isolation from saliva, positive immunofluorescent using skin biopsy from hairy skin over the nape of the neck, or virus-neutralising antibodies (from cerebrospinal fluid, serum, or a patient who has not received a vaccine).
  • The rabies virus antigen is found in cutaneous nerves at the base of hair follicles.
  • Corneal impression smears are a low diagnostic yield and hence are not performed.

Option A: Seller’s stain for Negri bodies

  • Eosinophilic inclusions known as "Negri bodies" are seen in the cerebellum's Purkinje cells and the hippocampus's pyramidal neurons.
  • Seller's stain for Negri bodies is used in postmortem examinations to help diagnose.

Option B: Indirect immunofluorescence

  • Utilising a direct immunofluorescence test to look for rabies antigen in a skin biopsy taken from the nape of the neck is one of the quickest ways to detect rabies ante mortem in people.
  • Many individuals are vaccinated and hence positive for antibodies in serum.
  • Indirect immunofluorescence is not used to diagnose rabies infection.

Option C: Real-time PCR

  • For intra vitam diagnosis in humans, RT-PCR is especially helpful as a diagnostic method. It is necessary to standardise and practise extremely strict quality control.
  • PCR should only be used in conjunction with other traditional procedures because it can result in false positive or negative results.
  • The mention of real-time PCR is curtailed to the skin, CSF, and salivary samples.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient who is a known case of AIDS, has presented to OPD with abnormal tissue growth under the skin, in the lining of the mouth and nose. Upon examination, they are usually red or purple tend to be of vascular origin. Which of the following Organism is responsible for this ?
questions.solution:
• Kaposi’s sarcoma is a multicentric neoplasm consisting of multiple vascular nodules appearing in the skin, mucous membranes, and viscera in a patient with AIDS
  • It is caused by HHV-8 ( Human herpes virus -8) aka Kaposi’s sarcoma–associated herpesvirus (KSHV)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and cough for the past 3 days. After an extensive workup, a diagnosis of COVID-19 infection has been made. Which of the following are the criteria for admission of an elderly with Covid-19 infection?
questions.solution:
Option A: Respiratory rate 25 breaths/min

ADMISSION CRITERIA

  • Worsening symptoms:
    • Mental confusion
    • Difficulty breathing
    • Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
    • Bluish colouration of face/lips
    • Dehydration
    • Decreased urine output
  • These patients need to be admitted to a Dedicated Covid Health Centre or Dedicated Covid Hospital
  • Clinical assessment parameters are Respiratory Rate >24 breaths/min
  • SpO2 < 94% on room air.

Option B: Oxygen saturation 96% at room air

  • Oxygen saturation less than 94 is an indication to admit the patient.

Option C: Intermittent Pain in the chest

  • Persistent pain in the chest or pressure sensation is one of the criteria for admission.

Option D: Presence of hypertension

  • Hypertension alone does not indicate the admission of patients with COVID-19 infection.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is brought to emergency after 2 episodes of seizure in the past 4 hours. His medical history is consistent with ESRD due to diabetes for the past 5 years. He is on biweekly dialysis. He has missed the past two dialysis. Which of the following abnormality is likely to present in ESRD patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hyperkalemia

  • Chronic kidney disease and end-stage kidney disease are common causes of hyperkalemia due to the associated deficit or absence of functioning nephrons.
  • Hyperkalemia is more common in oliguric acute kidney injury; distal tubular flow rate and Na+ delivery are less limiting in non-oliguric patients.
  • Hyperkalemia, out of proportion to GFR, can also be seen in the context of a tubulointerstitial disease that affects the distal nephron, such as amyloidosis, sickle cell anaemia, interstitial nephritis, and obstructive uropathy.
  • Hereditary renal causes of hyperkalemia have overlapping clinical features with hypoaldosteronism, hence the diagnostic label pseudohypoaldosteronism (PHA).

Option B: Hypokalemia

  • Hyperkalemia rather than hypokalemia is associated with ESRD.
  • Hypokalemia is likely seen in hyperinsulinemia and the use of beta-agonist drugs such as salbutamol.
  • Hyperaldosteronism, such as Conn's syndrome, also causes hypokalemia

Option C: Metabolic alkalosis

  • CKD is associated with metabolic acidosis rather than metabolic alkalosis.
  • The anion gap is usually high due to lactate formation.

Option D: Hypovolemic hypornatremia

  • Hypervolemic rather than hypovolemic hyponatremia is associated with CKD due to water retention.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with loose stools for the last 4 days. On examination, his eyes are sunken; mucous membranes are dry and capillary refill is delayed. His BP is 90/60 mmHg, and he has had little urine output for 3 days. On baselines, his RFTs are deranged. The patient is managed on lines of hypovolemic shock. After days in the hospital, his condition improved, and the patient started having excessive diuresis. There is no previous history of polyphagia, polydipsia and polyuria. Which of the following is the cause of the patient's recent symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Recovery phase of AKI

Previously managed on lines of hypovolemic shock and decreased urine output, now has polyuria with no previous significant medical history leads to a probable cause of polyuria as the recovery phase of AKI

  • The patient had a hypovolemic shock which caused AKI, and the patient is now recovering from it and is in the recovery phase of AKI
  • Tubular dysfunction may persist in this phase and is manifested by sodium wasting and polyuria unresponsive to vasopressin.
  • The mechanism of diuresis is not completely understood. Still, it may, in part, be due to the delayed recovery of tubular cell function in the setting of increased glomerular filtration.
  • Serum creatinine and urea levels may not decrease for several days. The duration of polyuria is proportional to the duration of oliguria/anuria and may last up to several weeks.
  • This phase of AKI is associated with a considerable risk of dehydration and severe loss of electrolytes, particularly potassium and calcium.

Other options

Option A: Diabetes Mellitus

  • Polyuria in diabetes occurs when you have excess sugar levels in the blood.
  • Normally, when your kidneys create urine, they reabsorb all sugar and direct it back to the bloodstream.
  • With diabetes, excess glucose ends up in the urine, where it pulls more water and results in more urine.
  • In diabetes Mellitus, there will be symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia and polyphagia. There will be other signs like shiny shins and hair loss on distal lower limbs.

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism

  • Excess parathyroid hormone causes hypercalcemia by increasing bone resorption and renal calcium reabsorption.
  • Excess calcium causes symptoms of abdominal pain, fractures, depression, kidney stones and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus causes polyuria
  • There are no signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia in question, so hyperparathyroidism is less likely

Option D: Anxiety

  • Anxiety can cause increased fluid intake and diuresis.
  • For anxiety to be a cause of polyuria, any stress factor like exams or any other factor should be present
  • There will be no signs of dehydration in polyuria due to anxiety
  • The patient had AKI and recovering from it, so most likely, it is due to the recovery phase of AKI

questions.text: An 18 year old girl with primary amenorrhea having a karyotype of 45X0 presents with infantile uterus. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Primary amenorrhea with karyotype of 45 XO with an infantile uterus is suggestive of TURNER SYNDROME

Management

  • Screen for associated abnormalities: cardiac (30% have coarctation of aorta), renal (esp.horseshoe kidney), autoimmune abnormalities (thyroiditis), diabetes, hypertension and hearing loss
  • Growth hormone therapy: accelerate growth velocity and improves final height
  • Gonadal steroids: start with estrogen therapy and add progesterones to induce puberty

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation is expected after how many hours of the ‘Peak’ of the ‘Upstroke’ in this diagram here:
questions.solution:
Option B : From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours and from the peak it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

The midcycle LH surge is responsible for a dramatic increase in local concentrations of prostaglandins and proteolytic enzymes in the follicle. These substances progressively weaken the follicular wall and ultimately allow a perforation to form.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with the complaint of blood from her c-section scar. On examination, there is blood collection and oozing from a small swelling on a cesarean section scar. She states that the swelling increases in size and becomes painful during her periods. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Complete excision

  • History is suggestive of scar endometriosis.
  • It is the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue in a previous surgery scar.
  • The management is complete excision.
  • Scar endometriosis:
    • Rare form of extragenital endometriosis
    • Presentation: tender hypertrophic scar, hyperpigmented skin, cyclical pain
    • Treatment is complete excision
  • Management of extragenital endometriosis
  • If complete excision is possible, this is the treatment of choice.
  • When this is not possible, long-term medical treatment is necessary using the same principles of medical treatment for pelvic endometriosis.
  • Drugs used for the treatment of pelvic endometriosis include
    • OC pills 
    • Progesterone
    • Progesterone IUD
    • Danazol
    • GnRH analogues
    • Mifepristone.
  • Surgical treatment of Bladder endometriosis -excision of the lesion and primary closure of the bladder wall.
  • Ureteral lesions may be excised after stenting the ureter,
  • Abdominal wall and perineal endometriosis -complete excision of the nodule.
  • Appendicular endometriosis-Appendectomy.

Option B: Oral contraceptive pills

  • OC Pills are used for the medical management of endometriosis. However, this is usually done for pelvic endometriosis, where surgical excision (such as that for ovarian chocolate cyst ) is not possible or advisable, more commonly for pain associated with endometriosis causing pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia.

Option C: GnRH analogues

  • OC Pills and GnRH analogues are used for medical management, usually in cases of pelvic endometriosis.

Option D: Steroids

  • Steroids have no role in the management of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with breast cancer underwent surgery and is now on chemotherapy with tamoxifen. Which of the following long-term side effects is an essential concern during the use of this drug?
questions.solution:
Option A: Endometrial carcinoma

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to prevent and treat breast cancer.
  • These drugs act like estrogen(agonist) on some tissues and block the estrogen effect on some tissues (antagonist).
  • It blocks the effects of estrogen on breast cells that are hormone receptor-positive.
  • It is useful in all stages of breast cancer.
  • It may increase the risk of endometrial cancer by changing the uterus lining because it acts as an estrogen agonist in the endometrial cavity. Increased exposure to estrogen may lead to hyperplasia, polyps, and even cancer.
  • Decreases the risk of osteoporosis because it slows down bone loss by increasing bone density.
  • Both tamoxifen and raloxifene reduce the risk of breast cancer in high-risk women by approximately 50% and are approved for this indication.
  • Tamoxifen acts as an estrogen agonist in the endometrium, increasing the risk of endometrial polyps, hyperplasia, and cancer, whereas no endometrial stimulation is seen with raloxifene.
  • Raloxifene is the preferred drug for osteoporosis treatment over tamoxifen in postmenopausal women.
  • Side effects of tamoxifen include menopausal symptoms like hot flushes, headache, nausea, and dizziness.
  • It also increases the risk of deep venous thrombosis (DVT).

Option B: Ovarian CA

  • This option is incorrect because tamoxifen does not increase ovarian carcinoma risk.

Option C: Causes cardiotoxicity

  • This option is incorrect because tamoxifen does not cause cardiotoxicity.
  • Its common side effects are increased bone or tumor pain, headache, dizziness, nausea, etc.

Option D: Increased risk of osteoporosis

  • This option is incorrect because tamoxifen use decreases the risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

  • The patient is a 68-year-old woman with abdominal distention, pain with bilateral adnexal masses, and induration in the rectal pouch. Bilateral adnexal masses in postmenopausal must raise suspicion of epithelial ovarian cancers. Most common of which are serous cystadenomas/ carcinomas. Induration in the rectal pouch suggests locally advanced disease and favors a malignancy.
  • The picture below shows the Serous cystadenocarcinoma.

  • Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant tumors of ovaries and the most common tumors associated with a bilateral origin.
  • The peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer is about 60. About 30% of ovarian neoplasms in postmenopausal women are malignant.
  • Mostly unilocular
  • Bilateral in >50%
  • Mostly malignant
  • Surface growth present
  • Psammoma Bodies are present in 40-45%

​​​​​​​

Option B: Krukenberg’s tumors of the ovaries

  • Krukenberg’s tumors are also bilateral but are associated with another primary malignancy (most commonly gastric carcinoma) and are less common than epithelial tumors.
  • Hence, it is not the correct option.

Option C: Malignant ascites

  • It is ruled out as there is no shifting dullness. Please note that serous cystadenocarcinomas do present with ascites quite commonly.
  • So, it is a false statement.

Option D: Meig's syndrome

  • Meig's syndrome is ascites and pleural effusion associated with fibroma of the ovary, which is again ruled out due to the absence of ascites.
  • So, it is not a true option.

questions.text: Which of the following ultrasound findings does not indicate PCOD?

choices.text: ≥20 Follicles that are 2-9 mm in size in one or both ovaries
Necklace of pearl pattern of Follicles

questions.solution:
Option B : Cysts arrange around the periphery of ovary giving Necklace of pearl appearance on USG is Characteristic of PCOD. The ovarian volume is usually >=10 cc, although not necessary for diagnosis.

Rotterdam PCOS Diagnostic Criteria for PCOS diagnosis :

The presence of two of the three criteria is sufficient to diagnosis PCOS:

menstrual cycle anomalies (amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea),

clinical and/or biochemical HA, and/or

Ultrasound appearance of polycystic ovaries after all other diagnoses are ruled out.

 

The sonographic criteria for PCOS morphology

Presence of 20 or more follicles (newer criteria mention 20 follicles instead of 12 since with better USGs, even smaller follicles can now be picked up) in either ovary measuring 2 to 9 mm in diameter

and/or increased ovarian volume (>10 mL).

Thickened ovarian stroma

A single ovary meeting these criteria is sufficient to affix the PCO morphology

Option A : PCOS is characterized by small follicles which do not grow in size and hence do not ovulate, these are arranged in the periphery. These are ≥20 Follicles which are ≤9 mm in size in either ovary.

Option C : PCOS is characterized by small follicles which do not grow in size and hence do not ovulate, these are arranged in the periphery appearing as a necklace of pearls.

Option D : Ovarian stroma is thickened in response to increased LH and is responsible for productions of excess androgens in PCOD.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with abnormal menstrual bleeding and a pelvic mass undergoes a hysterectomy. The image shows the gross specimen removed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Leiomyoma.

  • The image shows a gross hysterectomy specimen showing a fibroid/ leiomyoma.
  • This can present as abnormal uterine bleeding (usually menorrhagia) and pelvic mass.
  • Recognition is based on a solid, well-defined lesion, inside a pseudo capsule, without any surrounding invasion, with a whirling pattern, which differentiates it from malignancy and adenomyosis.
  • Fibroids are the most common uterine tumours and are made of smooth muscle with varying amounts of fibrous connective tissue.
  • Fibroids are classified as submucosal, intramural, or subserosal; the latter may become pedunculated and simulate ovarian tumours.
  • Although most fibroids are asymptomatic, patients may present with abnormal menstrual bleeding, pressure on adjacent organs, pain, infertility, or a palpable abdominal-pelvic mass.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most accurate imaging technique for detecting and locating fibroids.

Option B: Adenomyosis

  • Adenomyotic uterus appears  asymmetrically enlarged, globular uterus due to associated myometrial hypertrophy reflected by thickened myometrium, with trabeculated cut surface with ill defined hypertrophic swirls of smooth muscle and petechia-like gray foci of endometrium.
  • A clear demarcation or capsule is absent, unlike as shown in the specimen in the question, which suggests fibroid

Option C: Ovarian neoplasm
