  • The image in the question shows a solid benign looking growth arising from the uterus, hence ovarian neoplasm is unlikely, which are mostly cystic and are seen adjacent to the ovary.

Option D: Carcinoma of the uterus

  • Carcinoma is a malignant condition, hence a clear demarcation or capsule as evident in the picture, is unlikely

questions.text: In the perspective of the busy life schedule in modern society, the accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation resulting in no offspring for a couple to be declared infertile is:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A - One year-  90% of couple who are cohabiting for at least one year with out contraception will have a conception. This is on monthly conception rates of 20 – 25 % in normal young couples attempting pregnancy.

Infertility is defined as inability to conceive even after 1 year of regular unprotected intercourse
 

  • The most common causes of infertility are:
    • A woman's age
    • Male (sperm) factor
    • Ovulation disorders
    • Tubal disease
    • Endometriosis
    • Anatomical factors such as fibroids and other uterine abnormalities
    • Factors such as antibodies to sperm may also reduce the ability to conceive
    • Combination of male and female factors
  • Other options : B,C and D Are incorrect

questions.text: What findings would be expected in a patient diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism type of infertility?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oligospermia

  • This is a case of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism : 
  • Here the defect lies in the hypothalamus or pituitary which produces less GnRH and subsequently less LH and FSH which causes less stimulation of testes and decreased production of sperms and testosterone.
  • Features
  1. LH ↓ & FSH ↓
  2. ↓ Testosterone
  3. Oligozoospermia
  4.  High prolactin levels

Option A : High LH and FSH

  • LH and FSH are low in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Option B : High Testosterone

  • Testosterone is low in this type

Option D : Low PRL

  • Prolactin is usually high due to decreased hypothalamic inhibition of release of prolactin from posterior pituitary.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents to the physician 1 day after a history of intercourse with her boyfriend. She is a university student and doesn't want a child until graduation. She stated they were not desirous of pregnancy and used a condom. However, they found it ruptured from one end after removal. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg within 72 hours

  • In this case, the patient presented with a history of unprotected intercourse 1 day ago with failure of barrier contraception. This is a valid indication for emergency contraception.
  • - Levonorgestrel is DOC for emergency contraception
    • - 0.75 mg tablets (2 tablets) 12 hours apart.
    • - 1.5 mg tablet (1 tablet) within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.
  • (This protocol of 1 tablet has now replaced the 0.75 mg 2 tablets protocol)
  • This is the only method approved by the drug controller of India for use as an emergency contraceptive.

Emergency contraceptives

  • IUCD: Can prevent implantation up till the 5th day of unprotected intercourse
  • Progesterone-only pill: LNG 1.5 mg: can reduce tubal motility and make endometrium 'Out of Phase" for embryo implantation.
  • Combined pill: the Yuzpe regimen can prevent embryo implantation since the estrogen component makes the endometrium unreceptive.
  • Mifepristone, antiprogestin and RU 486 prevent implantation.
  • Ulipristal acetate (SPRM): Selective progesterone receptor modulator.

 

Option A: Multiload insertion

  • Multiload insertion is very effective but not the most convenient method of emergency contraception.

Option C: High-dose oral contraceptive pill

  • High-dose oral contraceptive pills are also used as an emergency contraceptive, but the drug of choice is levonorgestrel.

 

Option D: Mifepristone followed by misoprostol

  • Mifepristone and misoprostol are used for medical abortion in early gestation, after confirmation of pregnancy, but not for emergency contraception.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination, there is mucopurulent discharge extruding from the cervix. The discharge, when examined under the microscope, shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Option A: Neisseria Gonorrhoea

  • The patient, in this case, has Cervicitis.
  • Chlamydia Trachomatis and Neisseria Gonorrhoeae are two significant causal organisms.
  • Clinical manifestation
  • Discharge: In some instances, mucopurulent yellowish discharge can be visualised oozing from the endocervix.
  • Cervical hypertrophy and oedema
  • Cervical ectopy
  • Friable cervix: easily bleeds when touched
  • Urethritis, bartholinitis, and proctitis symptoms may be present.
  • Cervicitis investigations
  • Gram staining on cervical swabs: gonococcal Cervicitis reveals gram-negative diplococci, but chlamydia cervicitis exhibits the absence of gram-negative diplococci with more than 30 poly-morphonuclear neutrophils per field. This test is neither sensitive nor specific.
  • In enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA), detection of antigens is 60%-80% and 80%-85% specific, respectively.
  • Nucleic Acid Amplification Technique (NAAT) is the most sensitive and specific (99%)
  • Complications
  • Ascending infections: pelvic inflammatory disease, endometritis, salpingitis
  • Septicemia: fever, meningitis, endocarditis, tenosynovitis, polyarthralgia
  • Perihepatitis: adhesions with an anterior abdominal wall called Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.
  • Long-term complications: infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain.
  • Treatment: It involves treatment of both partners

For Nesseria

  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose
  • Cefixime 400 mg single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose
  • A single dose of ceftriaxone (250mg IM) and azithromycin 1 gm (single dose) for both partners treat Neisseria and Chlamydia.

Option B: Chlamydia Trachomatis

  • Chlamydia Trochamatis is also a leading cause of Cervicitis
  • However, the discharge in chlamydia cervicitis is yellowish with a strong odour.
  • Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms.
  • Chlamydia cervicitis exhibits the absence of gram-negative diplococci with more than 30 poly-morphonuclear neutrophils per field.
  • They have 2 forms:
  • Elementary body: It is small and dense. It is infectious and enters the cell via endocytosis. It transforms into the reticulate body.
  • Reticulate body: It replicates in the cell by fission and reorganises into elementary bodies.
  • A single dose of ceftriaxone (250mg IM) and azithromycin 1 gm (single dose) for both partners treat both Neisseria and Chlamydia.
  • Treatment:
  • Azithromycin 1 gm single dose
  • Doxycycline : 100 mg BD x 7 days
  • Erythromycin: 500 mg BD x 7 days
  • Ofloxacin : 200 mg BD x 7 days

Option C: Candida Albicans

  • Candida Albicans caused Candida Vulvovaginitis
  • There is inflammation.
  • There is thick, white “cottage cheese” discharge also present.
  • Pseudohyphae may be visualised on microscopy.
  • The pH is usually normal (acidic), i.e. 4.0–4.5.

Option D: Trichomonas Vaginalis

  • Trichomonas Vaginalis causes Trichomonas Vaginitis.
  • There is inflammation of the vagina.
  • A strawberry cervix may also be present.
  • There is a frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge.
  • There are motile pear-shaped trichomonads on microscopy.
  • The pH is usually greater than 4.5

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with complaints of primary amenorrhea. Her height is 153 cm, weight is 51 kg. She has well-developed breasts. She has no pubic or axillary hair and no hirsutism. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C : Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • The above history suggests a diagnosis of Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome/Testicular Feminization Syndrome
  • XY ( Karyotype Male and Phenotype Female)
  • Testosterone is produced but androgen receptors are defective
  • Affected individuals typically present with
    • Bilateral Testes
    • Breast development
    • Pubic or axillary hair absent
    • Female External genitalia, a blindly ending vagina, No müllerian derivatives (i.e., uterus and fallopian tubes)
    • Because the patient is a genetic male, testes are present & sertoli cells make antimüllerian hormone (AMH), thus, müllerian regression occurs normally ( Reason for absent uterus & tubes in a phenotypic normal female).

Option A : Turner syndrome is associated with short stature and breast development is absent due to absence of estrogen production from ovaries which are streak.

Option B : Stein-Levinthal syndrome or PCOS may rarely present with primary amenorrhea, more commonly presents with oligomenorrhea or secondary amenorrhea, however, here pubic and axillary hair will be normal and may even be associated with hirsutism.

Option D ; Premature ovarian failure presents with secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 13 year old girl is brought by her mother with pain in her lower abdomen. She has not attained menarche yet. Ultrasound suggests a vagina full of heterogenous content pushing the bladder anteriorly and rectum posteriorly. Which of the following could be a cause?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of hematocolpos. Hematocolpos is defined as vagina filled with blood which is seen in imperforate hymen.

Imperforate hymen

  • Outflow tract obstruction preventing the drainage of menstrual blood,
  • Uterus present, Breast development normal, Normal external genitalia
  • Karyotype 46XX
  • FSH LH Normal
  • Pubic Hairs normal
  • Clinical Features
    • Primary amenorrhoea with cyclical pain
    • This results in the accumulation of blood in the vagina leading to hematocolpos
    • In long standing cases it can even lead to hematometra..
  • On Examination Bluish bulging membrane
  • Rx -Cruciate incision

NOTE: hematocolpos may also be seen in other vertical fusion defects causing obstruction to menstrual blood outflow like transverse vaginal septum but not in any lateral fusion defects as mentioned in the question.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the given image :
questions.solution:
Option C: Bartholin cyst

The diagnosis of Bartholin cyst in the image is made by

  • its location, unilateral cyst on either side of the labia minora

Bartholin's cysts or Abscesses

  • Bartholin glands are located on each side of the vaginal openings. They secrete fluid that lubricates the vagina
  • The obstruction of glands results in pooling back of the fluid to be secreted, leading to the formation of Bartholin gland cyst
  • They result from ductal opening obstruction followed by accumulation of mucus or pus within the gland duct,

Bartholin's abscess

  • results due to polymicrobial infections-Bacteroides species, Peptostreptococcus species, Escherichia coli, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in a Bartholin's cyst

 

Option A: Dermoid cyst

  • A dermoid cyst is a congenital tissue growth containing cells of multiple lineages, thus forming various structures like hair, skin, and bone within the growth

 

 

Option B: Serous cystadenoma

  • Serous cystadenoma is an ovarian mass and will not be found in the vaginal or vulvar region, as shown in the diagram and its histology; it is ovarian and has ciliated epithelium covering it

 

 

Option D: Condyloma

  • Condyloma is formed by Human papillomavirus; it is fleshy hypertrophic growth called warts. They can be located in the anogenital as well as other regions

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, presents for an antenatal check-up. A routine obstetric scan suggests a placenta previa and oligohydramnios. An MRI on follow-up reveals a placenta accreta. Which of the following is the most common predisposing factor for placenta accreta?
questions.solution:
Option D: Placenta previa

  • These syndromes describe the abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • ‘Accrete syndromes’ thus include any placental implantation with abnormally firm adherence to myometrium because of” Partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and Imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • Placenta accrete syndromes arise from abnormal placental implantation and adherence and are classified according to the depth of placental ingrowth into the uterine wall. These include placenta accreta, increta, and percreta
  • Placenta accreta indicates that villi are attached to the myometrium. Placenta increta, villi invade the myometrium, placenta percreta defines villi that penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa. In clinical practice, these three variants are encountered as a ratio of 80:15:5, respectively

Risk Factors:

  • The two most important risk factors are an associated placenta previa and a prior cesarean delivery, with placenta previa being a more important predisposing factor.
  • MR imaging has proved useful for the evaluation of ‘placenta Accrete’

Option A: Oligohydramnios

  • Oligohydramnios is a risk factor for fetal malformations and miscarriages.

Option B: Recent curettage

  • A recent curettage can increase risk of abnormal placentation, but not the most common predisposing factor.

Option C: Previous caesarean section

  • Previous caesarean section is a very important predisposing factor for morbidly adherant placenta due to implantation and adherance of the placenta over the scar, but placenta previa is the most important factor as morbid adherance does not occur in placentas which are implanted at a normal site.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with a complaint of headache for the last 2 days. Her BP is 190/110 mmHg. The urine dipstick test is positive for protein (+2). She is admitted for evaluation and management. Which of the following is the drug of choice for preventing seizures in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option B: Magnesium sulphate

  • This patient with increased BP, headache and positive urinary proteins on the dipstick suffers from preeclampsia. She is at risk of developing seizures and progressing to eclampsia.
  • The 1st line drug to prevent seizures in these patients is magnesium sulphate.
  • Preeclampsia is one of the hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.
  • Preeclampsia occurs when blood pressure increases to 140/90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).
  • Patients with preeclampsia are at risk of developing seizures and progressing to eclampsia.
  • Intrapartum and postpartum administration of magnesium sulfate help prevent seizures in women with mild preeclampsia.
  • MgSO4 increases the seizure threshold, thereby preventing the progression to eclampsia.

Option A: Phenytoin

  • Although phenytoin is an anticonvulsant, it is not indicated during pregnancy because of its teratogenic effect.

Option C: Diazepam

  • Although diazepam has an anticonvulsant effect, it is not the DOC for seizures in pregnancy.

Option D: Nifedipine

  • It is an antihypertensive drug. It does not have anticonvulsant properties.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primipara at term gestation presents with labor pains. On vaginal examination, cervical dilation is 3 cm, 60% effacement, liquor is meconium stained. The fetal heart rate is 102 bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Oxytocin drip to accelerate labor pains
IV drotaverine to improve cervical dilatation
Start oxygen and shift to OT for emergency LSCS

questions.solution:
Option D : Fetal heart rate lesser than 110 is fetal distress and after the initial resuscitation, the best management is Cesarean section. Fetal distress is the commonest cause of Cesarean section in modern obstetrics.

  • Also, 'meconium in the liquor' indicates present or recent fetal strain. If the fetal heart rate is reassuring and patient is likely to deliver soon, then we can do amnio-infusion to dilute the meconium in the liqour with strict fetal monitoring and expedite delivery.
  • Here since the patient is only 3 cm dilated and delivery is not imminent, it is advisable to perform an emergency LSCS, this reduces the chances of 'Meconium aspiration syndrome " of the new born which can lead to pneumonitis in the fetus and secondarily hypoxic injury to the brain.

Option A : Augmentation of labour is not appropriate here as even with good contractions, delivery is not imminent here as the patient is only 3 cms dilated, and would take atleast a few hours to deliver vaginally, within which meconium aspiration is likely.

Option B : IV drotaverine is an antispasmodic drug, used to enhance cervical dilation during labor and to relieve smooth muscle spasms in gastrointestinal tract, urinary system, and gall bladder. It is structurally related to papaverine, and is a selective inhibitor of phosphodiesterase-4. It is only known to enhance cervical dilatation but not as fast as required in this case.

Option C : Vacuum cannot be applied at 3 cm dilatation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, at 38 weeks of gestation, was brought with labor pains and delivered a live baby vaginally. APGAR score was 7 and 8 on 1 and 5 minutes of the delivery. The baby weighs 2 kg. Which neonatal complication is less likely expected?
questions.solution:
Option C : Birth weight of <2.5 kg is low birth weight and since the baby is born at term, it is suggestive of a growth restricted fetus (IUGR). IUGR babies are at risk of hypoglycemia and not hyperglycemia.

Neonatal complications in IUGR

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypoxia and acidosis
  • Hypothermia
  • Meconium aspiration syndrome
  • Polycythemia
  • Congenital malformations
  • Sudden Infant Death syndrome (SIDS)

Option A : Growth-restricted fetuses more commonly pass meconium due to the intra uterine stress; therefore aspiration is a concern at the time of delivery.

Option B : Infants with IUGR have less subcutaneous fat deposition; therefore, hypothermia and hypoglycemia are a potential concern.

Option D : In addition, growth-restricted fetuses compensate for poor placental oxygen transfer by having a polycythemia that can then result in multiorgan thrombosis at or after birth. At the time of delivery, such infants may suffer from hypoxia due to placental insufficiency.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman, G2P0A1, is at 30 weeks gestation. Her fundal height measures 25cm. An obstetrical ultrasound examination reveals a 4 quadrant amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4cm. Which of the following fetal conditions is associated with the finding?
questions.solution:
Option D : AFI <4 cm is suggestive of Oligohydramnios

  • The only option of the provided that leads to oligohydramnios is Renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios can be caused by -

  1. Renal anomalies
  2. Uteroplacental insufficiency: IUGR
  3. ACE inhibitors
  4. Premature rupture of membranes
  5. Amniocentesis (leak)
  6. Pre-eclampsia
  7. Amnion nodosum
  8. NSAIDs
  9. Post term pregnancy
  10. over estimated gestational age

Option A, B, C : Duodenal atresia, open spina bifida, tracheo-esophageal fistula are all causes of polyhydramnios as they are all associated with open meninges or mucosal surfaces which exude fluid and cause polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the accident and emergency department with complaints of blurry vision, heavy bleeding from the vagina, and swelling and pain in the perennial region. She looks confused and disoriented. Her blood pressure s 90/60 mm Hg, and her pulse is 105/min. Examination reveals pallor in the eyes and mucosal membrane. She gives a history of spontaneous vaginal delivery, after which she was discharged from the hospital. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Uterine massage is the first step in the management
Injection of Oxytocin given to the patient

questions.solution:
Option C: Manual removal of placenta

  • This patient’s presentation with blurry vision, heavy bleeding, hypotension and confusion after delivering a baby most likely suggests postpartum haemorrhage ( PPH)
  • PPH can be managed medically and surgically.
  • However, manual removal of the placenta is not a management step of PPH; rather, it is done in the case of retained placenta.

 

Option A: Uterine massage is the first step in the management

  • Uterine massage is an integral part of the management of PPH. After the placenta has been delivered, uterine massage can help the uterus contract. This is done by placing a hand on the woman's lower belly and repeatedly rubbing or squeezing the area to stimulate the uterus.

 

Option B: Injection of Oxytocin given to the  patient

  • Oxytocin aids in the uterus's contraction, reducing excessive postpartum bleeding. It is administered to the mother via injection into a vein or muscle during or right after the baby's birth.

 

Option D: B-Lynch suture

  • A type of compression suture used in obstetrics is known as the B-Lynch suture or B-Lynch technique. When there is a serious postpartum haemorrhage, it is utilised to compress an atonic uterus physically.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of fever, chills, cough, and headache. Which of the following study pattern is best for establishing the natural history of disease?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Cohort studies

  • The Natural history of disease is best established by cohort studies.
  • A cohort study gives the strongest evidence of association.
  • The strength of association in a cohort study is calculated by:
    • Relative risk
      • Best indicator as it has lower biases as compared to other studies.
    • Attributable risk.
    • Population attributable risk.

Option A: Randomized control trials

  • Random: Equal & known chance.
  • Controlled: Comparison group.
  • This trial is used for new drugs or vaccines.

Option B: Clinical trials

  • CLINICAL TRIAL has 4 phase
    • Healthy Human Volunteers (HHV)
      • To evaluate the safety & nontoxicity of the drug.
    • Patients
      • For Efficacy
    • Patients
      • Comparison with an existing drug in the market.
      • New drug launched in the market.
    • Patients
      • Long-term & rare side effects

Option C: Descriptive studies

  • It refers to observational studies of the distribution of disease in terms of
    • Person
    • Place
    • Time
  • This study describes the distribution of a set of variables without regard to causal or other hypotheses.
  • Personal factors include
    • Age
    • Gender
    • Educational level
    • Ethnicity
    • Occupation.

questions.text: In an investigation to study the effect of smoking on renal cell cancer, it is observed that 30 of the 50 patients were smokers as compared to 10 out of 50 control subjects. What is the odd's ratio of renal cancer associated with smoking?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 6.0

  Renal cell cancer Present (cases) Renal cell cancer absent (controls)
Exposure to smoking present 30 10
Exposure to smoking absent 20 40
Total 50 50
  • Odds ratio = ad/bc = 30 x 40/20 x 10 = 6
  • Interpretation of Odds ratio = 6 i.e Renal cell cancer cases have a 6 times higher chance of reporting a history of exposure to smoking as compared to healthy people in the study.

questions.text: A 4-month-old male patient presented with weakness and decreased movement of the left lower extremity. He received OPV with DTaP at the local health center 1 month before presenting those symptoms. The physician diagnosed the condition as VAPP. Which of the following statement is an incorrect statement regarding Vaccine Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP)?

choices.text: Onset of flaccid paralysis within 4 to 30 days of receipt of OPV
No specific treatment available, only supportive care
Presence of wild polio virus in stool

questions.solution:
Option D: Presence of wild poliovirus in stool

  • The presence of wild poliovirus in stool is not associated with  Vaccine Associated Poliomyelitis (VAPP).
  • The live attenuated poliomyelitis in the vaccine resembles the wild virus in the laboratory.
  • Since 1999, wild poliovirus type-2 has not been reported.
  • The presence of wild poliovirus in the stool is associated with wild poliovirus Type 1 or Type 3.

Option A: It is Acute flaccid paralysis

  • Vaccine Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP) is an adverse event following exposure to OPV.
  • It results in acute flaccid paralysis within 4-30 days of receiving OPV.

Option B: Onset of flaccid paralysis within 4 to 30 days of receipt of OPV

  • The onset of flaccid paralysis within 4 to 30 days of receipt of OPV is seen with Vaccine Associated Poliomyelitis (VAPP).
  • The Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio is frequently associated with P3 followed by P2 and P1.

Option C: No specific treatment is available, only supportive care

  • No specific treatment is available, only supportive care is given.

questions.text: The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is an attempt to measure the quality of life or well-being of a country. All of the following components are measured in PQLI except?

choices.text: Life expectancy at 1 year of age

questions.solution:
Option C: Income (real GDP per capita)

  • Income (real GDP per capita) is not a component of PQLI.
  • Whereas, it is a component of HDI.

Option A: Life expectancy at 1 year of age

  • The life expectancy at 1 year of age is one of the three components of PQLI. 
  • The PQLI measures social, political, and economical policies.

Option B: Infant mortality rate

  • The infant mortality rate is one of the three components of PQLI. 

Option D: Literacy rate

  • The literacy rate is also a component of PQLI. 
  • PQLI does not measure economical growth.

questions.text: Identify the type of time distribution shown in the Photograph below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Seasonal trend

  • The given image is showing peaking of disease in September of every year; which is showing seasonal fluctuation in the occurrence of a disease known as Seasonal trends.
  • Examples of diseases showing seasonal trends: Measles, URI, and GIT infections.

Other options

Option A: Epidemic

  • An epidemic occurs when a disease spreads quickly across a community, affecting a significant number of people in a little amount of time.
    • Single exposure, point source epidemic - Staph. food poisoning
    • Multiple exposures, point source epidemic - Typhoid
    • Propagated epidemic - Tuberculosis

Option C: Secular trend

  • In the Secular trend, the majority of communicable diseases are reducing with time.
  • Whereas non-communicable diseases are slowly rising.
  • So gradual decrease of communicable & gradual increase of non-communicable is also a secular trend of the disease.

Option D: Cyclical trend

  • A recurrent pattern that occurs often, such as seasonal variations in the abundance of insect vectors or respiratory diseases among elementary school students.  
  • The disease occurs after a gap of fixed years
    • Measles shows a cyclical trend once every 2-3years
    • Rubella shows a cyclical trend once every 6-8years
    • Influenza shows the maximum cyclical trend.

questions.text: Health promotion is the process of enabling people to increase control over and improve their health. "Ottawa Charter of Health Promotion" incorporates all of the following key action areas except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Build a social security system

  • Building social security system is not included in the five key action areas of the Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion.

Option A: Build healthy public policy

  • Building healthy public policy is also a key action area of the Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion.
  • Beyond medical care, there is health promotion. It acts by directing them to acknowledge their responsibility for health and be aware of the health implications of their decisions.

Option B: Strengthen community action for health

  • Strengthening the community action for health is also a key action area of the Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion.
  • Health promotion works through effective and concrete community action in making decisions, planning strategies, setting priorities, and implementing them to achieve better health.

Option D: Reorient health services

  • Reorienting health services is also a key action area of the Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion.
  • The responsibility for health promotion in health services is shared among health professionals, individuals, health service institutions, community groups, and governments.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presented to the OPD with frequent urination, burning sensation and blood in urine. The physician sent him for screening suspecting some diagnosis. In which of the following disease, Screening procedure increases the overall survival maximum?
questions.solution:
Option C: Colon cancer

  • Colonic cancer has highest 5-year survival rate post-screening.
  • This can be known by Kaplan Meier survival analysis.
  • Screening of colonic cancer is done by colonoscopy.
  • From above mentioned option colon cancer has highest 5-year post-screening survival rate.

SCREENING TESTS OF OTHER OPTIONS

Option A: Prostate cancer

  • Prostate specific antigen + DRE

Option C: Lung cancer

  • Chest x-ray

Option D: Ovarian cancer

  • Transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) & CA-125 blood test.

Learning Objective

  • Colonic cancer has highest 5-year survival rate post-screening among the different cancer mention above, according to Kaplan Meier. Screening of colonic cancer is done by colonoscopy.

questions.text: In a population having mid-year population of 1000, there are 150 children less than 15 years and 50 elderly more than 65 years of age. Calculate dependency ratio?
questions.solution:
Option C: 0.25

Dependency ratio:

  • Also known as " societal dependency ratio".
  • The proportion of persons above 65 of age and children below 15 years of age are considered to be dependent on the economically productive age group (15-64 years).

Dependency ratio = (Proportion of ppl in < 15yrs of age + > 65yrs of age) / Proportion of ppl in 15-64 yrs of age

= 150+50/800

= 0.25

Learning Objective

  • Dependency ratio defined as the proportion of persons above 65 of age and children below 15 years of age are considered to be dependent on the economically productive age group (15-64 years).

questions.text: A community medicine intern posted in a rural PHC was asked to calculate the maternal mortality ratio for a given population. Which of the following is the correct definition of maternal death?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option C: Till 42 days after delivery

  • Maternal death is defined as the Death of a woman anytime in pregnancy, during labor/delivery, or within 42 days of delivery.

Other options

Option A: Till delivery

  • Maternal death is the death of a woman not only till delivery but till 6 weeks postpartum.

Option B: Till 1 week after delivery

  • Maternal death is defined as the Death of a woman anytime in pregnancy, during labor/delivery, or within 6 weeks (not 1 week) of delivery.

Option D: None of the above

  • This is not the correct option. Options (a) and (b) are incorrect because they do not encompass the full maternal death review period of 42 days after delivery.

questions.text: A rural PHC was screening all the neonates of the village for any neonatal disorders. Which of the following is the most common neonatal disorder screened?
questions.solution:
Neonatal hypothyroidism

  • Most common neonatal disorder to be screened is Neonatal hypothyroidism (NNH).
  • Congenital hypothyroidism leads to serious sequelae, including severe mental retardation, which can be prevented if medical treatment is given within the first 1-2 months of life.
  • Blood sample is collected from umbilical cord Blood /from heel prick after 24hrs of birth.
  • As a single method, T4 is more useful (greater precision and reproducibility)
  • Congenital Hypothyroidism is one of the most common preventable cause of mental retardation.
  • Hence, neonatal screening & early supplementation of thyroid hormones can prevent this mental retardation.

Learning Objective

  • The object of screening newborns is primarily to detect infants with treatable genetic, developmental and other abnormalities, and secondarily, to provide their parents with genetic counselling.
  • Most common neonatal disorder to be screened is Neonatal hypothyroidism (NNH).
  • Congenital hypothyroidism leads to serious sequelae, including severe mental retardation, which can be prevented if medical treatment is given within the first 1-2 months of life.

questions.text: An Anganwadi worker is monitoring the children of the village. Which of the following indicator is used for growth monitoring at Anganwadi center?
questions.solution:
Option C: Weight for age

  • The child’s actual weight is compared with the ideal weight at that age.
  • The weight for age is an age-dependent index.
  • It is an easy-to-do and commonly used parameter.
  • It is used for growth monitoring at the Anganwadi center

Other options

Option A: Height for age

  • If the height for age is <90% of expected or <-2 SD or <-2 Z score, it is termed as Stunting.
  • The presence of stunting indicates Chronic PEM.
  • The height for age is not affected in Acute PEM.
  • For Overall nutritional status and growth monitoring, the Weight for age growth chart is used in ICDS Program.

Option B: Mid-arm circumference

  • Mid-upper arm circumference is commonly measured in children aged 6 months to 5 years of age.
  • As this is the time during which the subcutaneous fat goes away and the protein takes its place, it remains fairly constant from 6 months to 5 years of age.
  • In the Indian setting, 15-17 cm is taken as a normal MUAC value.
  • WHO/ARNOLD classification:
  • If the MUAC < 12.5cm, it indicates Moderate PEM.
  • If the MUAC < 11.5cm, then it indicates Severe PEM.

Option D: Weight for height

  • The weight for height is a parameter in which the age of the child is not used and hence it is an age-independent index.
  • If the weight for height is <-2SD or <-2 Z score, it indicates Wasting.
  • If the weight for height is <-3SD or <-3 Z score, it indicates Severe wasting.
  • The term wasting indicates Acute protein energy malnutrition or acute undernutrition.
  • Weight for height is not affected in chronic PEM.
  • For Overall nutritional status and growth monitoring, the Weight for age growth chart is used in ICDS Program.

questions.text: Subacute combined degeneration (SCD) is a rare neurological complication characterized by demyelination of the dorsal and lateral spinal cord. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord is due to a deficiency of which of the following vitamin?
questions.solution:
Option D: Vitamin B12

  • Subacute combined degeneration of the cord is due to a deficiency of Vitamin B12.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency:
    • Megaloblastic anemia
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord
    • Peripheral neuropathy
    • Infertility
    • Atrophic glossitis

Option A: Vitamin B1

  • Thiamine deficiency can lead to Beri-Beri and Wernicke- Korsakoff syndrome.

Option B: Vitamin B6

  • Pyridoxine/Vitamin B6 leads to microcytic anemia.
  • It can lead to epileptic convulsions in infants.

Option C: Folic acid

  • Folic acid / Vitamin B9 deficiency leads to Megaloblastic Anemia and Neural tube defects.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe social factors, such as poverty, old age, or crime that support social disorganization?
questions.solution:
Option B: Social pathology

  • Social pathology is a term used to describe social factors, such as poverty, old age, or crime that support social disorganization.
  • At the same time, the term refers to the study of these factors and the social problems they may lead to.

Other options

Option A: Social physiology

  • Social physiology does not define the systematic study of human disease and social conditions/factors.

Option C: Socialized medicine

  • Socialized medicine: Medical service & education provided by State but regulated by professional groups (not the government).

Option D: Social medicine

  • Investigate social, environmental & genetic factors affecting disease patterns & disability.
  • Promote methods to prevent diseases & health measures that are protective.

questions.text: What is the upper-class score on Kuppuswamy Socioeconomic status scale?
questions.solution:
Option D: 26-29

  • Upper class according to Modified Kuppuswamy Scale 26-29.
  • Socioeconomic classes under Modified Kuppuswamy Scale:
    • Upper: 26-29
    • Upper middle: 16-25
    • Lower middle: 11-15
    • Upper Lower: 05-10
    • Lower: 01-04

Option A: 5-10

  • A total score of 5-10 is classified as Upper lower class.

Option B: 11-15

  • A total score of 11-15 is classified as Lower middle class.

Option C: 16-25

  • A total score of 16-25 is classified as Upper middle class.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male working in a factory visited the OPD with a disturbance in hearing. What is the suggested level of noise that people can tolerate without damage to their hearing?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option B: 85 dB

  • The daily maximum tolerable sound level to the human ear is 85-90 dB.
  • Permanent hearing loss: >100 dB.
  • Hospital ward, the permissible level of sound: is 22-35 dB.
  • Normal conversation: 60-70 dB.
  • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB

Other options

Option A: 60 dB

  • Normal conversation sound level 60-70 dB.
  • The daily maximum tolerable sound level to the human ear is 85-90 dB.

Option C: 110 dB

  • The daily maximum tolerable sound level to the human ear is 85-90 dB.

Option D: 120dB

  • Permanent hearing loss can occur with prolonged exposure to sound levels>100 dB.

questions.text: The United Nations International Children Emergency Fund organized a 'GOBI campaign' to encourage 4 strategies for a child health revolution. What does ‘O’ stands for in GOBI?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oral rehydration therapy

  • UNICEF is promoting the GOBI campaign to encourage 4 strategies for a child health revolution, where O stands for Oral rehydration therapy.
  • UNICEF (United Nations International Children Emergency Fund):
  • UNICEF is promoting the GOBI campaign to encourage 4 strategies for a child health revolution:
    • G: Growth charts (to better monitor child development)
    • O: Oral rehydration (to treat mild and moderate dehydration)
    • B: Breastfeeding
    • I: Immunization (against TB, polio, diphtheria, Pertussis, tetanus, and measles)
  • GOBI campaign is now GOBI-FFF:
    • Family Planning
    • Female education
    • Food supplementation

Opton A: Oral contraceptives

  • Oral contraceptive is not a part of GOBI.
  • O in GOBI stands for Oral rehydration therapy.

Option C: Obesity

  • O in GOBI stands for Oral rehydration therapy (not obesity).

Option D: Occupational hazards

  • Occupational hazards are not a part of the GOBI campaign.
